componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And Ms. Katharine Kenny, you may begin your conference.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer, and good morning. Thank you, all for joining our fiscal 2015 fourth quarter and year-end earnings conference call.As always, on the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our E
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer, and good morning. Thank you, all for joining our fiscal 2015 fourth quarter and year-end earnings conference call.
As always, on the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them.
For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ending February 28, 2014, a new one will be out shortly, filed with the SEC.
Before I turn it over to Tom, I just want to ask you all to remember [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. As you saw by now, we had both a record fourth quarter and a record fiscal year. During the year, total revenues grew to more than $14 billion and we sold nearly 1 million to
componenttext:
Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. As you saw by now, we had both a record fourth quarter and a record fiscal year. During the year, total revenues grew to more than $14 billion and we sold nearly 1 million total vehicles, more than 591,000 retail cars and 376,000 wholesale cars through our in-store auctions. Here's some of the key highlights for the year.
Used unit comps up 4% and total used units grew by over 10%. Wholesale vehicle gross profit, up 16%, driven by a 10% increase in units sold and an increase in wholesale growth gross profit per unit of $54 per car.
Cap income, up 9% to more than $367 million. Tom will give some more details on that in a moment. Excluding the items we highlighted in the press release, net income for the fiscal year increased 16% and EPS grew 21%.
Our data indicates that for the calendar year 2014, we increased our share of the 0 to 10-year old used vehicle market by approximately 5%. We continue -- we also continue to focus on returning value to shareholders through our stock repurchase program. During fiscal 2015, we bought back 17.5 million shares at a cost of a little over $900 million. Since we began the program in fiscal 2013, we have purchased more than 30 million shares.
Now on to some of the key drivers for the fourth quarter. Used unit comps, up 7%, driven by an increase in traffic, as well as an improvement in conversion. Total used units grew by 12%. Also, growth gross profit up 22%, reflecting a 12% increase in units sold and an increase of $83 in gross profit per unit. Cap quarterly income, up 12% to $90 million and again, excluding the items we shared in the press release, net income for the fourth quarter increased 20% and earnings per share up 28%.
With that, I'll turn it over to Tom and he'll give you some details around CAF. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. CAF recorded another solid year with 9% income growth to $367 million and growth in average managed receivables of 19%. As Tom mentioned, in the fourth quarter, CAF income was $90.4 million, up 12% compared to the fou
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. CAF recorded another solid year with 9% income growth to $367 million and growth in average managed receivables of 19%. As Tom mentioned, in the fourth quarter, CAF income was $90.4 million, up 12% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2014 and Q4 average managed receivables grew 18% to $8.3 billion.
CAF's weighted average contract rate, that rate that we charge to customers was flat for last year's fourth quarter at 72.2% [ph]. This rate continue to be relatively stable at around 7% for the last couple of years. The allowance for loan losses grew to about $82 million. This represents 1% of managed receivables, which is relatively consistent with last year, but during the quarter and the year, CAF income did benefit from favorable loss experience.
CAF net penetration was 40.9% compared to  40.1% in last year's fourth quarter. This figure includes originations from our subprime test and to get back on those originations, this quarter's penetration would have been 40.2%, which is similar to last year.
Net loan dollars originated in the quarter rose 16% [ph] to $1.2 billion, due to a combination of CarMax's unit sales growth, our modestly higher penetration and a small increase in the average amount financed.
Finally, we intend to continue with our subprime test. Recall that our primary goal for this investment was to gain knowledge regarding the space and we expect these learnings would prove invaluable. While performance to date is in line with our expectations. We believe the receivables to see them deeper into their life, including maturing through a full tax season will better equip us to assess our long term strategy.
On average, the term of these contracts nearly 70 months and the fiscal year-end, the average term in our books for the loan is less than 7 months. We're comfortable continuing to originate at the current target volume, which is 5% of CarMax's subprime sales or a little less than 2% of CAF originations.
Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As far as mix of sales, sales of 0 to 4-year old vehicles grew to approximately 75% of our total sales, the same as the third quarter by over 5 percentage points higher than last year's fourth quarter. Sales of SUVs and trucks as a percentage w
componenttext:
Thank you. As far as mix of sales, sales of 0 to 4-year old vehicles grew to approximately 75% of our total sales, the same as the third quarter by over 5 percentage points higher than last year's fourth quarter. Sales of SUVs and trucks as a percentage was similar to last year.
SG&A for the quarter increased approximately 11% to $330 million, contributing to this growth was the addition of 18 stores since the beginning of the fourth quarter of last year and a $9 million increase in share-based compensation expense.
On a per-unit basis, SG&A decreased $23 to $21.86 compared to 2,209 in the fourth quarter of fiscal '14. During the fourth quarter, we opened 1 store in our new Cleveland market, in Katharine's hometown.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Since the fourth quarter, we opened 2 more stores, in Minneapolis, a new market for CarMax; and 1 yesterday in, New Jersey, which is part of our Philadelphia market. In addition to these 2, we plan to open 12 more stores in fiscal '16, plus the relocation
componenttext:
Since the fourth quarter, we opened 2 more stores, in Minneapolis, a new market for CarMax; and 1 yesterday in, New Jersey, which is part of our Philadelphia market. In addition to these 2, we plan to open 12 more stores in fiscal '16, plus the relocation of our store in Rockville Maryland.
In regard to our small format test? We've now opened 5 stores and as a group, they are performing at or above our expectations. We expect a small format stores to be a part of our store openings going forward. Of our 14 store openings in fiscal '16, there will be 3 small format, including our first small format front store with production, full production capability in the back and that will be in Gainesville, Florida.
Also, we now plan to open between 13 and 16 stores annually over the next 3 years. Store traffic was up once again in the quarter and our web traffic also, continued to expand. For the fourth quarter, average monthly web visits grew over 9% compared to last year's fourth quarter to over 14.5 million visits. And visits to our mobile site now represents approximately 32% of the total, while visits utilizing our mobile represent represents another 16% of the total.
And with that, we will open up for questions. Operator?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look year-over-year, we're at 17 versus 17 6, as a percent of subprime in the business. Last year's fourth quarter is when we really first started feeling any changes in behavior. And as I mentioned I think on the last call, we've see
componenttext: Well, I think if you look year-over-year, we're at 17 versus 17 6, as a percent of subprime in the business. Last year's fourth quarter is when we really first started feeling any changes in behavior. And as I mentioned I think on the last call, we've seen pretty consistent behavior out of our partners for the last several quarters. The key thing that we're looking at is the quality of their offers and what that translates to, and how many of the customers that receive offers from them, actually convert to a sale. Our subprime partners cannot control the nature of what's coming into them because the Tier 2 lenders are looking at it ahead of time and have the first look at that. So on the basis of conversion of offers, we're, their behavior to be very consistent and we're very happy with. Performance.

So can you talk about kind of what you expect to do on the remodels? If there's anything operationally that, that will affect or is it more cosmetic? And then the reload, just where is that and is there the opportunity for more re-lows in the CarMax system?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first of all, over our history, we've constantly spend capital on keeping our stores up-to-date and renovating them over time. Since we launched the next 10 concepts, I forget 4, 5 years ago now, we now gone back in and we're applying some of thi
componenttext: Sure. So first of all, over our history, we've constantly spend capital on keeping our stores up-to-date and renovating them over time. Since we launched the next 10 concepts, I forget 4, 5 years ago now, we now gone back in and we're applying some of this technology changes with some more digital screens and digital capabilities in the stores, as well as open seating, which we really had prior to nextgen, but we think it's a much more efficient use of floor space and so the conversions are a little more expensive than they have been, because we're doing a combination of technology and converting whether it's cubes or offices into floor space, we just finished converting our Richmonde store, it looks fantastic, and I feel the store in the chain. I think we completed 3 or 4 full -- of these types of convergence and they're a little bit more expensive than the money that would have been spent, so we just thought we would call it out and we plan to do another 17 this year. In terms of the operational changes, it doesn't change much operationally, but I think it provides a better experience for our customers and a better working environment for our associates as well. So we've been pretty pleased of what we have done so for  and we'll gauge the results going forward and see how much more aggressive we want to spend. In terms of the relo, that's our Rockville store. Our Rockville store was originally a competitor who built a kind of a copy cat. It's a very small footprint. I think it's only on 5 acres or so and it's been a very successful store for us. This is just a situation where the lease was up for renewal and we took the opportunity to move. We're really only moving a short distance away from that store to a much bigger facility and that store's been very successful for us, but was really undersized the whole time we had it. At this time, we don't have any other plans for relos, this 1 was just more opportunistic as the lease came up.

componenttextpreview: We're making a lot of changes and we are evaluating how best to spend our money, but that will be an ongoing process for us. So continued strong effort on TV. We're pretty much out of print and have been for a long time and continuing to try to optimize o
componenttext: We're making a lot of changes and we are evaluating how best to spend our money, but that will be an ongoing process for us. So continued strong effort on TV. We're pretty much out of print and have been for a long time and continuing to try to optimize our paid search, as well as trying to improve our SEO or search engine optimization through organic search. And continuing to test, using outside partners as well. So a similar mix, but we'll see what happens going forward.

componenttext: Good morning, it's Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs. Go figure. My primary question here relates to wholesale, so you had from what I can tell is the highest level of wholesale profitability per vehicle you ever had in the fourth quarter. You also had the biggest year-on-year increase in hopes so gross profit per vehicle that you've had in about 5 years. Just curious whether there's anything in the backdrop other than your stellar execution that would lead to that kind of pop in the wholesale profit number?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, thank you for calling our execution, stellar. Really good execution continues to build year-over-year. You're right, it's the first fourth quarter we've ever had that exceeded $1,000 in profit per car. We've had 2 first quarter that have done that
componenttext: First, thank you for calling our execution, stellar. Really good execution continues to build year-over-year. You're right, it's the first fourth quarter we've ever had that exceeded $1,000 in profit per car. We've had 2 first quarter that have done that in the past. As our reputation builds, it's a great place for dealers to come and buy this type of product. I think our stores do a great job of marketing and it's always a balancing act between the wholesale margin and making sure we have a very strong buy rate. Remember lots of the customer that are selling up these costs are also buying a car from us. So good barometer for how fair we're being with our customers as our buy rate, which I just mentioned, it was very strong at 30%. So again, this is -- wholesale is always a balance with retail. It's never a stand-alone business that can be managed separately. Always have to pay attention on what's happening on the retail side. So I'm really proud of the stores and how well they've executed. We have some stores that are particularly tight on space and have to manage running -- some stores are running 2 auctions a week now out in California and we've just -- the stores have done a fantastic job of managing relationships and making sure we get great attendance. And that's led to a great performance.

Just noticed your cash balance, it's one of the lowest you've had in quite some time and in light of the store growth and the renovations and remodels and everything you're working out from that perspective, is that something that's temporary or how should we think about that from the fourth quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean as far as the cash balance goes, I can kind of walk you through we did this year. If you look, we went through $600 million in cash plus took out a $300 million term loan, that's $900 million. Our stock buyback during the year was a little bit grea
componenttext: I mean as far as the cash balance goes, I can kind of walk you through we did this year. If you look, we went through $600 million in cash plus took out a $300 million term loan, that's $900 million. Our stock buyback during the year was a little bit greater than our $917 million. So what that means is all the other spend that we had during the year, CapEx, needs for CAF and inventory, which totaled, again another $900 million were covered by cash flow in the core business. So as far as liquidity goes, I mean, we're in an environment where we feel pretty good about our banks wanting us to step up the whereabouts step-up and leave up to their commitments on our revolving credit facility. We've got the $1 billion facility. We'll managed to some amount of liquidity that we can run the business with. But I think the decline of the cash balance was planned and deliberate, and the business is still generating a lot of cash and if you kind of close that, it reflects that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Aram. So we've used technology in our stores from the very beginning in a combination of things, both for our associates and for our customers. So we employ a lot of use of data and the ability to deliver that data back to our employees, that's th
componenttext:
Thanks, Aram. So we've used technology in our stores from the very beginning in a combination of things, both for our associates and for our customers. So we employ a lot of use of data and the ability to deliver that data back to our employees, that's the moment they need it to make good decisions. We have lots of ability to attract customers through the process and make future decisions based on that's, so I think we've done a pretty good job of utilizing technology in our stores, so that our associates can deliver a great customer experience. In terms of customer-facing, it's something that we continue to invest in and we'll continue to invest in more going forward. We want to make sure that we can communicate with our customers, however, it is if they want to communicate with us. I've talked in the past about being a little bit behind in terms of Marbella. We'll continue to invest there. We've made lots of improvements over time to our pictures and the quality of our pictures. We used to take 1 then 9, we're up to around 40. We have high definition pictures. We have zoom capability. We've adjusted our landing Pages to be more personalized and we'll continued to mix some  efforts in that regard as well. And I think you'll see us do a lot more stuff at as it relates to mobile. And touchscreen, it's more than 50% of our total hits to our website are now coming from either a mobile device or a tablet and it's something that we need to make sure that the customer has a fantastic experience if they want to communicate with us in that format. So those are the kinds of things we continue to invest in and we've testbed online capabilities, which is a lot -- you see a lot of niche type things from various, whether they're competitors or people who enable our competitors'. Things such as online credit applications, which we're testing. The ability to transfer a car from one location to another without speaking to sales consultant. The ability to put a credit card payment down to have those cars transferred, which we're doing. You can go online and put a car on hold, you can make an appointment with our sales consultants, so we've done a lot of stuff to make sure our customers can do more and more of the process from home. They can fill out a good chunk of the paperwork before they show up at our store.
But all of these things are the types of stuff that we need to continue to invest in. But I think we've made a lot of nice progress, but we got a long way to go.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask about productivity in terms of used units sold per dealership. And I guess, the way I was thinking about it is pre-recession, you guys averaged about 4,800 units, which was well over 4,000 of 0 to 4-year old cars by my math. Just lookin
componenttext: Just wanted to ask about productivity in terms of used units sold per dealership. And I guess, the way I was thinking about it is pre-recession, you guys averaged about 4,800 units, which was well over 4,000 of 0 to 4-year old cars by my math. Just looking ahead in coming years. You think the supply of 0 to 4-year old vehicle is going to grow by about 25%, 30% over the next 5 or 6 years and ultimately, could drive a 10% to 15% tailwind if you were a throughput. Can you just comment on that at all, about maybe what's some of the risks are to that or is there something that I'm missing? And then secondarily, just love to get your thoughts around the profitability on a dealership level. If you are able to get that kind of throughput, any structural impediments to retail EBIT margins, going up in that environment?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, on your comment about throughput, annualized of 0 to 4-year old cars, we've never just 0 to 4-year-old cars. We've always been 0 to 10, so it's a much broader spectrum of vehicle than you stayed in there. That number did change over time as I state
componenttext: First, on your comment about throughput, annualized of 0 to 4-year old cars, we've never just 0 to 4-year-old cars. We've always been 0 to 10, so it's a much broader spectrum of vehicle than you stayed in there. That number did change over time as I stated in my comments, 0 to 4-year old cars represent 75% of our results. That was 70% just a couple of years ago, so it's moved by about 5 points, but you kind of have to look at a much broader spectrum of inventory to look at total sales for CarMax and it does look like you would see a supply movement in 0 to 4 just based on movement and Star, and as I've said, before we have historically had higher share in the 0 to 4-year old segment. So is there a potential tailwind? Probably, but there's -- another factor in there is consumer behavior and they will trade out as cars as much as they used to when you have population growth and new drivers and things like that. So there's lots of different variables and factors, and I don't think you can just say that we expect whatever the number you said, 20% or 10 -- i forgot what number you said there, but I don't think we can just expect that as an increase in sales. In terms of how did the stores handle it, we've been deliver exceptionally high volumes on of some pretty limited space on our stores and all comp sales are more profitable than sales wants you've cleared all of your expenses. So it's very, very profitable for the company to continue to deliver comp sales out of existing facilities because a lot of your fixed overhead remains constant. You really just have to add some favorable overheads. So we're really pleased with the comps we delivered over the last couple of years. I think it's one of the great parts of our business model is that our stores continue to grow. As I said, we gained 5% sure during the year, that's on top of the 17% share gain in the year prior. But once again, that silver, 0 to 10-year old cars, so I think our stores are well primed to take advantage of supply increases if that translates to sales and then they're well positioned to turn that into better than average profits because they're all on top of base that's already covered and fixed overhead.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Seth, that's a good question. We get that frequently. It was roughly 50-50 in terms of conversion and traffic. And I always thought that over time, it'll be 50-50. It doesn't line up all that time. Sometimes it all comes from conversion, sometimes it all
componenttext: Seth, that's a good question. We get that frequently. It was roughly 50-50 in terms of conversion and traffic. And I always thought that over time, it'll be 50-50. It doesn't line up all that time. Sometimes it all comes from conversion, sometimes it all comes from traffic, just happen to be one more that matched up. As we've looked at over a very long period of time and the way we think about it going forward is I would like to be able to continue to increase traffic to our stores, and I'd like to be able to do better with the traffic that we have. And in terms of what are we doing to improve conversion, we have some really fantastic people in our stores that are dedicated and committed everyday to giving the customer a great experience. We've tried to do a good job of providing additional training. Some of the stuff I talked about earlier in terms of technology as it relates to information and capabilities that our associates have, we've improved over the last several years and plan to continue to improve going forward. So I really think it's just a testament to our 20,000 dedicated employees in the stores who work really hard to every day to try to be more and more efficient and give the customer a better experience. Hope that turns into higher sales, and then they in turn, go and tell all their friends and become spokespeople for CarMax. It's worked for us in the past and I expect it to keep working going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: On store openings for the upcoming year, you've got enough skew towards existing markets over new, and I was just curious if longer-term, are you going to look to focus more on growing existing over new or reverse and focus more on new later on?
componenttext: On store openings for the upcoming year, you've got enough skew towards existing markets over new, and I was just curious if longer-term, are you going to look to focus more on growing existing over new or reverse and focus more on new later on?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's an ever-changing landscape for us as we continue to get more data and existing markets, it gives us more comfort with going back into those markets. But we have a healthy mix of new markets as well and one thing to take into account, when we go into
componenttext: It's an ever-changing landscape for us as we continue to get more data and existing markets, it gives us more comfort with going back into those markets. But we have a healthy mix of new markets as well and one thing to take into account, when we go into a metro market like Philadelphia, Minneapolis or this year will be entering Boston, those are intentionally multi-year place for us to really grow out the market, so when you see us go back into Philly with, New Jersey store this year, that's just part of the long-term Philadelphia plan. It looks like a skew towards an existing market, but those are existing markets that are clearly under stored and we're not where we expect to be long term. So I expect to be a mix going forward. Some of the big ones that we have come into the next 3 years or so, Boston, San Francisco and Seattle are places where we have no presence and it's taken us 15 years to get to 10 stores in LA and you'll see us continue to learn more, figure out places where we're -- zip codes where were missing and then try to figure out the best store in pattern to go into those bigger metro markets. So I don't read too much into that because some of -- as I said, some of it is just planned because the markets are bigger and more stores are required to fill them out.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015

componenttext: Just want to sneak one more in, it seems like given the harsh weather on a year-over-year basis, you may have lost some day sales and maybe mixed your comp was even stronger in retrospect, but just wanted to maybe ask for your, kind of your view on the weather, if you will.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: As you probably know, James, we never not like to use weather as an excuse, but it was really cold. And we did have a lot of stores closed, particularly in the back half of February. As far as attributing sales loss, we generally think we get it back beca
componenttext: As you probably know, James, we never not like to use weather as an excuse, but it was really cold. And we did have a lot of stores closed, particularly in the back half of February. As far as attributing sales loss, we generally think we get it back because when we're closed, everybody else is closed. It's not like milk, if you didn't sell it, you didn't sell it or a grocer. It's such an infrequent purchase. If we're closed, generally all the competition is closed as well. So I can't attribute a specific sales lost to it, but we probably would have done a little better if it wasn't so cold. We had a bunch of stores closed in the back half, particularly in the back half of February, but as I said, I think generally, we get those sales back.

componenttextpreview: I mean, we didn't see much. So I mean, whether it's regional or -- I feel like we had a really good quarter and a really good year. We've got a lot of questions around gas prices and is it potential that gas -- lowering gas prices would drive sales toward
componenttext: I mean, we didn't see much. So I mean, whether it's regional or -- I feel like we had a really good quarter and a really good year. We've got a lot of questions around gas prices and is it potential that gas -- lowering gas prices would drive sales towards kind of SUVs and V8 and we really didn't see much of that either. So I think possibly because we have such a wide range of inventory and we appeal to such a broad range of customers that some of those impacts are muted with us. But who knows? I also think in terms of gas prices that people do not expect gas to be this cheap and a car is a long term purchase. So although you might see some shifting, it really hasn't affected us as much as you might think. Prices are going to go back up so.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael for Rod. Just wanted to see if you could discuss some of the factors that went into, you guys getting increased confidence in raising your store growth plans over the next 3 years from 10 to 15 to 13 to 16.
componenttext: Michael for Rod. Just wanted to see if you could discuss some of the factors that went into, you guys getting increased confidence in raising your store growth plans over the next 3 years from 10 to 15 to 13 to 16.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you recall coming out of the recession and getting back into a growth plan, we wanted to have a face build up. We wanted to make sure that we build up our infrastructure and by infrastructure I mean the ability to go out and source real state.
componenttext: Sure. So if you recall coming out of the recession and getting back into a growth plan, we wanted to have a face build up. We wanted to make sure that we build up our infrastructure and by infrastructure I mean the ability to go out and source real state. The ability to make sure that we provide experience, management and to all the stores. When we spend a lot of dollars on relo to make sure that, that first customer that works through the door gets a great experience at CarMax. And our build up over the few years, we opened 3 in the first year, then 5, then 10, then 13 for 2 years in a row. And so this is kind of in-line with continuing as the base has also gotten bigger during that time. I think we've added 50 stores since 2011. Increased the company size from 90-ish stores to 145 or so. So and we opened 13 this year and we plan on opening 14 next year. So it's right in the -- just kind of in the of what we delivered. And we wanted to give ourselves some flexibility, there is a big complicated stores. Sometimes 1 or 2 might slip in or out over a year, so we like to put a range around it, but we don't plan on opening 10 anymore. So we're -- that's kind of a range we think we can deliver over the next few years. So it's confidence and all the things that I've talked about and that's the reason we raised the range.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we hit on that a little earlier, but as Tom mentioned, I think our goal is to be in it programmatically. If you look at what happened in Q4, we bought back fewer shares, spent less dollars at an elevated stock price we put some buffers to our
componenttext: Yes, I think we hit on that a little earlier, but as Tom mentioned, I think our goal is to be in it programmatically. If you look at what happened in Q4, we bought back fewer shares, spent less dollars at an elevated stock price we put some buffers to our program based on our estimation of valuation. But in general, we want to be in the market on a continuous basis and programmatically move towards capital structure that's got a little bit more leverage in it. And I think you'll see us doing that over the next couple of years.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have a follow-up question from the line of Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We have a follow-up question from the line of Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow-up on 2 things. One was inventory per store, which I had up kind of low double digits, so I was just trying to understand, how much of that might be anticipated buildout as you increase the unit growth versus like a desire to actuall
componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up on 2 things. One was inventory per store, which I had up kind of low double digits, so I was just trying to understand, how much of that might be anticipated buildout as you increase the unit growth versus like a desire to actually increase sale rates and have more cars in the lot? And then secondly, with CapEx going from $310 million to $360 million, can you just help to understand how much of that is related to the remodels versus the new store acceleration and what the major buckets are spend there?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. What was your first question again? Inventory. So inventory in the quarter was up. Remember last year, we were behind on where we wanted to be so some of it is kind of I would call it an easy comparison because we were behind on inventory. This year
componenttext: Sure. What was your first question again? Inventory. So inventory in the quarter was up. Remember last year, we were behind on where we wanted to be so some of it is kind of I would call it an easy comparison because we were behind on inventory. This year, we did a much better job of building and we also had a bunch of new stores. So a lot of times when you look, when we're in a build mode, when we get a car done and saleable, we make it salable in the store that finished it, so some stores have elevated inventory in anticipation of the store opening when we shipped the cars over to the new store. So if you look at our total sales increase for the quarter, I think it was 12%. And you would expect inventory to go up kind of commensurate with that number and then we have another during the quarter, 7% of comps and I know inventory is slightly higher than when we add those 2 things together, but that I think is more of a reflection of, we're a little behind where we wanted to be last year. And then your second question?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on the CapEx side, just understanding the step-up year-over-year in CapEx spend, how much is related to the new store openings increasing versus remodels and the major buckets and spend in the $360 million?
componenttext: Just on the CapEx side, just understanding the step-up year-over-year in CapEx spend, how much is related to the new store openings increasing versus remodels and the major buckets and spend in the $360 million?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the major buckets in the $360 million, roughly $80 million of it would be in existing stores, $40 million of that would be in normal maintenance and the other $40 million would be in the remodels that we talked about and all the rest goes to those ne
componenttext: Yes, the major buckets in the $360 million, roughly $80 million of it would be in existing stores, $40 million of that would be in normal maintenance and the other $40 million would be in the remodels that we talked about and all the rest goes to those new stores and remember CapEx is always our best guess at the year. We have a lot of movement and a lot of timing during the year, particularly in new stores and new construction. So that's our best guess and what we'll spend this year, and that's roughly the breakdown.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And Ms. Katharine Kenny, you may begin
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And Ms. Katharine Kenny, you may begin your conference.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer, and good morning. Thank you, all, for joining our fiscal 2015 fourth quarter and year-end earnings conference call. As always, on the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our E
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer, and good morning. Thank you, all, for joining our fiscal 2015 fourth quarter and year-end earnings conference call. As always, on the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them.
For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ending February 28, 2014. A new one will be out shortly, filed with the SEC.
[Operator Instructions] Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. As you saw by now, we had both a record fourth quarter and a record fiscal year. During the year, total revenues grew to more than $14 billion and we sold nearly 1 million to
componenttext:
Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. As you saw by now, we had both a record fourth quarter and a record fiscal year. During the year, total revenues grew to more than $14 billion and we sold nearly 1 million total vehicles, more than 591,000 retail cars and 376,000 wholesale cars through our in-store auctions. Here's some -- here are some of the key highlights for the year.
Used unit comps, up 4%, and total used units grew by over 10%. Wholesale vehicle gross profit, up 16%, driven by a 10% increase in units sold and an increase in wholesale growth -- gross profit per unit of $54 per car.
CAF income, up 9% to more than $367 million. Tom will give some more details on that in a moment. Excluding the items we highlighted in the press release, net income for the fiscal year increased 16% and EPS grew 21%.
Our data indicates that for the calendar year 2014, we increased our share of the 0- to 10-year-old used vehicle market by approximately 5%. We continue to -- we also continue to focus on returning value to shareholders through our stock repurchase program. During fiscal 2015, we bought back 17.5 million shares at a cost of a little over $900 million. Since we began the program in fiscal 2013, we have purchased more than 30 million shares.
Now on to some of the key drivers for the fourth quarter. Used unit comps, up 7%, driven by an increase in traffic as well as an improvement in conversion. Total used units grew by 12%. Wholesale growth -- gross profit, up 22%, reflecting a 12% increase in units sold and an increase of $83 in gross profit per unit. CAF quarterly income, up 12% to $90 million. And again, excluding the items we shared in the press release, net income for the fourth quarter increased 20% and earnings per share, up 28%.
With that, I'll turn it over to Tom and he'll give you some details around CAF. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. CAF recorded another solid year with 9% income growth to $367 million and growth in average managed receivables, 19%. As Tom mentioned, in the fourth quarter, CAF income was $90.4 million, up 12% compared to the fourt
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. CAF recorded another solid year with 9% income growth to $367 million and growth in average managed receivables, 19%. As Tom mentioned, in the fourth quarter, CAF income was $90.4 million, up 12% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2014. And Q4 average managed receivables grew 18% to $8.3 billion.
CAF's weighted average contract rate, that rate that we charge to customers, was flat for last year's fourth quarter at 7.2%. This rate continued to be relatively stable at around 7% for the past couple of years. The allowance for loan losses grew to about $82 million. This represents 1% of managed receivables, which is relatively consistent with last year. But during the quarter and the year, CAF income did benefit from favorable loss experience.
CAF net penetration was 40.9% compared to 40.1% in last year's fourth quarter. This figure includes originations from our subprime test. And if you back up those originations, this quarter's penetration would have been 40.2%, which is similar to last year. Net loan dollars originated in the quarter rose 16% [ph] to $1.2 billion, due to a combination of CarMax's unit sales growth, our modestly higher penetration and a small increase in the average amount financed.
Finally, we intend to continue with our subprime test. Recall that our primary goal for this investment was to gain knowledge regarding the space, and we expect these learnings would prove invaluable. While performance to date is in line with our expectations, we believe allowing the receivables to season deeper into their life, including maturing through a full tax season, will better equip us to assess our long-term strategy.
On average, the term of these contracts is nearly 70 months, and at fiscal year-end, the average term on our books for the loans is less than 7 months. We're comfortable continuing to originate at the current target volume, which is 5% of CarMax's subprime sales or a little less than 2% of CAF originations.
Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As far as mix of sales, sales of 0- to 4-year-old vehicles grew to approximately 75% of our total sales, the same as the third quarter but over 5 percentage points higher than last year's fourth quarter. Sales of SUVs and trucks as a percentage
componenttext:
Thank you. As far as mix of sales, sales of 0- to 4-year-old vehicles grew to approximately 75% of our total sales, the same as the third quarter but over 5 percentage points higher than last year's fourth quarter. Sales of SUVs and trucks as a percentage was similar to last year.
SG&A for the quarter increased approximately 11% to $330 million. Contributing to this growth was the addition of 18 stores since the beginning of the fourth quarter of last year and a $9 million increase in share-based compensation expense.
On a per-unit basis, SG&A decreased $23 to $2,186 compared to $2,209 in the fourth quarter of fiscal '14. During the fourth quarter, we opened 1 store in our new Cleveland market and Katharine's hometown.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Since the fourth quarter, we opened 2 more stores: one In Minneapolis, a new market for CarMax; and one yesterday in Turnersville, New Jersey, which is part of our Philadelphia market. In addition to these 2, we plan to open 12 more stores in fiscal '16,
componenttext:
Since the fourth quarter, we opened 2 more stores: one In Minneapolis, a new market for CarMax; and one yesterday in Turnersville, New Jersey, which is part of our Philadelphia market. In addition to these 2, we plan to open 12 more stores in fiscal '16, plus the relocation of our store in Rockville, Maryland.
In regard to our small-format test. We've now opened 5 stores and as a group, they are performing at or above our expectations. We expect the small-format stores to be a part of our store openings going forward. Of our 14 store openings in fiscal '16, there will be 3 small format, including our first small-format front store with production -- full production capability in the back and that will be in Gainesville, Florida.
Also, we now plan to open between 13 and 16 stores annually over the next 3 years. Store traffic was up once again in the quarter and our web traffic also continued to expand. For the fourth quarter, average monthly web visits grew over 9% compared to last year's fourth quarter to over 14.5 million visits. And visits to our mobile site now represent approximately 32% of the total, while visits utilizing our mobile app represent another 16% of the total.
And with that, we'll open it up for questions. Operator?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll ask just a couple of questions here. So a question, I guess, and a follow up. First off, just a point of clarification. You mentioned the subprime test and the continuation of that test. So are you now planning to go above the prior stated $70 mil
componenttext: So I'll ask just a couple of questions here. So a question, I guess, and a follow up. First off, just a point of clarification. You mentioned the subprime test and the continuation of that test. So are you now planning to go above the prior stated $70 million size in the test? And if so, I mean, how should we think about, I guess, what could be the new volume relative [ph] to the initial goal? And then I'll come back for the [indiscernible]

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian, I'm sorry if I wasn't clear. But I think in the release, we'd say we did $72 million up to the end of fiscal 2015. So that gives you -- that's what we did through the year. What I meant -- what I said is we're comfortable continuing at the sam
componenttext: Yes, Brian, I'm sorry if I wasn't clear. But I think in the release, we'd say we did $72 million up to the end of fiscal 2015. So that gives you -- that's what we did through the year. What I meant -- what I said is we're comfortable continuing at the same pace, which is about 5% of the subprime business that CarMax does. So if subprime continues to be a similar number of our sales as last year, it would be a similar pace of volume for us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then also on this follow-up, also on the subprime business, as you look at not just what you're originating, but what your partners are originating as well, any commentary there about kind of the willingness of your partners to l
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then also on this follow-up, also on the subprime business, as you look at not just what you're originating, but what your partners are originating as well, any commentary there about kind of the willingness of your partners to lend? I guess a couple of quarters where we saw some type of disruption. Just with a lot of grumbling to market that's going on out there, are you seeing any shifts at all in the willingness of your partners to lend subprime-based accounts?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look year-over-year, we're at 17% versus 17.6% as a percent of subprime in the business. Last year's fourth quarter is when we really first started feeling any changes in behavior. And as I mentioned I think on the last call, we've se
componenttext:
Well, I think if you look year-over-year, we're at 17% versus 17.6% as a percent of subprime in the business. Last year's fourth quarter is when we really first started feeling any changes in behavior. And as I mentioned I think on the last call, we've seen pretty consistent behavior out of our partners for the last several quarters. 
The key thing that we're looking at is the quality of their offers, and what that translates into is how many of customers that receive offers from them actually convert to a sale. Our subprime partners cannot control the nature of what's coming into them because the Tier 2 lenders are looking at it ahead of time and have the first look at that. So on the basis of conversion of offers, we see their behavior to be very consistent and we're very happy with their performance.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think this might be -- in the press release, you indicated you're doing 15 remodels this year and 1 relo. And I don't really remember any remodeling program at CarMax. So can you talk about kind of what you expect to do in the remodels? If there's an
componenttext: So I think this might be -- in the press release, you indicated you're doing 15 remodels this year and 1 relo. And I don't really remember any remodeling program at CarMax. So can you talk about kind of what you expect to do in the remodels? If there's anything operationally that, that will affect? Or if it's more cosmetic? And then the relo, just where is that? And is there the opportunity for more relos in the CarMax system?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first of all, over our history, we've constantly spent capital on keeping our stores up-to-date and renovating them over time. Since we launched the next-gen concept, I forget, 4, 5 years ago now, we've now gone back in and we're applying some of
componenttext:
Sure. So first of all, over our history, we've constantly spent capital on keeping our stores up-to-date and renovating them over time. Since we launched the next-gen concept, I forget, 4, 5 years ago now, we've now gone back in and we're applying some of those technology changes with some more digital screens and some digital capabilities in the stores as well as open seating, which we really had prior to next gen, but we think it's a much more efficient use of floor space. And so the conversions are a little more extensive than they have been, because we're doing a combination of technology and converting, whether it's cubes or offices into floor space. We just finished converting our Richmonde store. It looks fantastic, and that be all the store in the chain. I think we completed 3 or 4 full -- of these types of convergence and they're a little bit more expensive than the money that would have been spent, so we just thought we would call it out and we plan to do another 17 this year. 
In terms of the operational changes, it doesn't change much operationally, but I think it provides a better experience for our customers and a better working environment for our associates as well. So we've been pretty pleased with what we've done so for and we'll gauge the results going forward and see how much more aggressively we want to spend. 
In terms of the relo, that's our Rockville store. Our Rockville store was originally a competitor who built a kind of a copy cat. It's a very small footprint. I think it's only on 5 acres or so and it's been a very successful store for us. This is just a situation where the lease was up for renewal and we took the opportunity to move. We're really only moving a short distance away from that store to a much bigger facility. And that store's been very successful for us, but was really undersized the whole time we had it. At this time, we don't have any other plans for relos. This one was just more opportunistic as the lease came up.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC capital.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think the last couple of quarters, you talked about Tier 2 becoming a bit more aggressive in terms of their lending, and that was that subprime penetration was starting to moderate a little bit. But as subprime penetrations kind of rebounded, at leas
componenttext: So I think the last couple of quarters, you talked about Tier 2 becoming a bit more aggressive in terms of their lending, and that was that subprime penetration was starting to moderate a little bit. But as subprime penetrations kind of rebounded, at least, sequentially the last 2 quarters, does that mean Tier 2's pulled back a bit? Or should we just view that as more overall credit availability when you kind of look at the overall market.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Scot, this is Tom. I think it's -- you're better to view it as Tier 3 stabilizing versus reading anything into overall credit availability. Tier 2's still doing very strong for us and as I said, we're happy with our partners. We brought in some new partne
componenttext: Scot, this is Tom. I think it's -- you're better to view it as Tier 3 stabilizing versus reading anything into overall credit availability. Tier 2's still doing very strong for us and as I said, we're happy with our partners. We brought in some new partners. We have a really good, diverse stable of finance partners in Tier 2 and it's performing well for us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an idea of kind of what Tier 2 has done on the penetration rate, kind of on a year-over-year basis, Tom?
componenttext: Can you give us an idea of kind of what Tier 2 has done on the penetration rate, kind of on a year-over-year basis, Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Typical, what we've seen is something in the low 40s for CarMax Auto Finance, and we said 20% to 25% gets financed outside the CarMax system and the rest, being kind of split between Tier 2 and Tier 3. I'd say that in the current environment, we're lookin
componenttext: Typical, what we've seen is something in the low 40s for CarMax Auto Finance, and we said 20% to 25% gets financed outside the CarMax system and the rest, being kind of split between Tier 2 and Tier 3. I'd say that in the current environment, we're looking at kind of the lower end of that 20% to 25% for other. And so Tier 2 and Tier 3 are doing 35%, and we said Tier 3 was at 17%, so that gives you a pretty good flavor.

So some of the -- most of the changes just be subtraction of Super Bowl year-over-year. But in terms of kind of a regular scheduled spend, it was in line with what we were trying to accomplish.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
