componenttext: And any change in priorities under the new leadership?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're making a lot of changes and we are evaluating how best to spend our money, but that'll be an ongoing process for us. So a continued strong effort on TV. We're pretty much out of print and have been for a long time and continuing to try to optimize o
componenttext: We're making a lot of changes and we are evaluating how best to spend our money, but that'll be an ongoing process for us. So a continued strong effort on TV. We're pretty much out of print and have been for a long time and continuing to try to optimize our paid search, as well as trying to improve our SEO, or search engine optimization, through organic search and continuing to test, using outside partners as well. So a similar mix, but we'll see what happens going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Matt Fassler, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: It's Matt Fassler, Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt.
componenttext: Matt.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Go figure. My primary question here relates to wholesale. So you had, from what I can tell, is the highest level of wholesale profitability per vehicle you've ever had in the fourth quarter. You also had the biggest year-on-year increase in wholesale gros
componenttext: Go figure. My primary question here relates to wholesale. So you had, from what I can tell, is the highest level of wholesale profitability per vehicle you've ever had in the fourth quarter. You also had the biggest year-on-year increase in wholesale gross profit per vehicle that you've had in about 5 years. Just curious whether there's anything in the backdrop, other than your stellar execution, that would lead to that kind of pop in the wholesale profit number.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, thank you for calling our execution stellar. Really good execution continues to build year-over-year. You're right, it's the first fourth quarter we've ever had that exceeded $1,000 in profit per car. We've had 2 first quarters that have done that
componenttext:
First, thank you for calling our execution stellar. Really good execution continues to build year-over-year. You're right, it's the first fourth quarter we've ever had that exceeded $1,000 in profit per car. We've had 2 first quarters that have done that in the past. But as our reputation builds, it's a great place for dealers to come and buy this type of product. I think our stores do a great job of marketing and we -- it's always a balancing act between the wholesale margin and making sure we have a very strong buy rate. Remember, lots of the customer that are selling up these cars are also buying a car from us. So a good barometer for how fair we're being with our customers is our buy rate, which I just mentioned, it was very strong at 30%. 
So again, this is -- wholesale is always a balance with retail. It's never a stand-alone business that can be managed separately. You always have to pay attention to what's happening on the retail side. So I'm really proud of the stores and how well they've executed. We have some stores that are particularly tight on space and have to manage running -- some stores are running 2 auctions a week now out in California. And we've just -- the stores have done a fantastic job of managing relationships and making sure we get great attendance. And that's led to great performance.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Has the fact that prices, based on some of the Manheim Indices, have been particularly resilient, maybe that's depressingly [ph] so, kind of been a part of the profitability per store here? Or would say that it's independent of that?
componenttext: Has the fact that prices, based on some of the Manheim Indices, have been particularly resilient, maybe that's depressingly [ph] so, kind of been a part of the profitability per store here? Or would say that it's independent of that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's a factor, too. It -- usually this time of year, coming out of the winter, you start to see some movement up in the Manheim Index and we see that as well. So that's always a little bit of a tailwind for us in terms of margin when we see
componenttext: No, I think that's a factor, too. It -- usually this time of year, coming out of the winter, you start to see some movement up in the Manheim Index and we see that as well. So that's always a little bit of a tailwind for us in terms of margin when we see an appreciating market. I don't think it was up that much in the last report. But it's typically a time of the year when we see some appreciation.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, just by way of follow-up and hopefully, you'll consider this a public service request rather than a question. Just a little bit of color on the capitalized interest add-back and just what that number is and why -- what would've looked different
componenttext: And then, just by way of follow-up and hopefully, you'll consider this a public service request rather than a question. Just a little bit of color on the capitalized interest add-back and just what that number is and why -- what would've looked different this quarter versus prior quarters?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, the only thing we'd really say about that, it was a miss on our part. We're required to capitalize interest on construction projects and net it against other interest expense. So you saw the 8.9% in Q4. 6.9% of that related to periods before Q4
componenttext: Yes, Matt, the only thing we'd really say about that, it was a miss on our part. We're required to capitalize interest on construction projects and net it against other interest expense. So you saw the 8.9% in Q4. 6.9% of that related to periods before Q4 this year. We looked back at other periods and made the determination that the impact's not material on any earlier period. So it's just something we'll be doing going forward but it was a miss.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it would've showed up in prior periods and you showed it here. It's a catch-up, if you will.
componenttext: So it would've showed up in prior periods and you showed it here. It's a catch-up, if you will.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Matt, it all would've been in this year.
componenttext: And Matt, it all would've been in this year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of James Albertine with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of James Albertine with Stifel.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had a quick sort of housekeeping item. Just noticed your cash balance is one of the lowest you've had in quite some time. And in light of the store growth and the renovations and remodels and everything you're working on from that perspective, is t
componenttext: I just had a quick sort of housekeeping item. Just noticed your cash balance is one of the lowest you've had in quite some time. And in light of the store growth and the renovations and remodels and everything you're working on from that perspective, is that something that's temporary? Or how should we think about that from the fourth quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, as far as the cash balance goes, I can kind of walk you what through we did this year. If you look -- we went through $600 million in cash plus took out a $300 million term loan. That's $900 million. Our stock buyback during the year was a little
componenttext: I mean, as far as the cash balance goes, I can kind of walk you what through we did this year. If you look -- we went through $600 million in cash plus took out a $300 million term loan. That's $900 million. Our stock buyback during the year was a little bit greater than $917 million. So what that means is all the other spend that we had during the year, CapEx, needs for CAF and inventory, which totaled -- again totaled over another $900 million, were covered by cash flow in the core business. So as far as liquidity goes, I mean, we're in an environment where if you feel pretty good about our banks' willingness to step up live up to their commitments on our revolving credit facility, we have a $1 billion facility, we'll managed to some amount of liquidity that we can run the business with. But I think the decline of the cash balance was planned and deliberate, and the business is still generating a lot of cash. And if you look kind of closely at it, it reflects that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we've talked in the past about moving towards a more optimal capital structure, so this is just us kind of delivering on stuff that we've already talked about.
componenttext: And we've talked in the past about moving towards a more optimal capital structure, so this is just us kind of delivering on stuff that we've already talked about.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very good. Just a quick follow-up, if I may. Just any thoughts on the Wells Fargo announcement with the capping of subprime loans. And if we start to see that elsewhere, how should we sort of think about that broadly over the market?
componenttext: Very good. Just a quick follow-up, if I may. Just any thoughts on the Wells Fargo announcement with the capping of subprime loans. And if we start to see that elsewhere, how should we sort of think about that broadly over the market?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm always hesitant to talk about anything outside of CarMax with regard to subprime, because everybody things about subprime differently. And if you recall, Wells Fargo is not one, what we call our subprime partners. But I'm sure in the Tier 2 space
componenttext:
Yes, I'm always hesitant to talk about anything outside of CarMax with regard to subprime, because everybody things about subprime differently. And if you recall, Wells Fargo is not one, what we call our subprime partners. But I'm sure in the Tier 2 space, they originate loans that some people would define as subprime. So that's one thing. 
I mean, that's really evidence of why we keep a diverse stable of partners to make that our customers have access to financing and access to good credit offers at all times. And I think we felt like we're in pretty good shape there. 
Also, historically, we believe that our partners have opted to direct volume towards CarMax at the expense of other places because they like the origination channel, the clarity of information, the knowledge about what the asset's really worth, et cetera. We've observed in tough times before that we felt like we were less impacted than other folks. Who knows what that means going forward, but that's probably as much color as I can give you.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Aram Rubinson with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Aram Rubinson with Wolfe Research.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Question for you on technology, if it's okay. I think you said your web traffic was up 9%. I know a lot of retailers have web traffic up a lot more than their own sales. And so irrespective of that, I'm hoping you could give us a little lens or window int
componenttext: Question for you on technology, if it's okay. I think you said your web traffic was up 9%. I know a lot of retailers have web traffic up a lot more than their own sales. And so irrespective of that, I'm hoping you could give us a little lens or window into kind of technology as you're using it incrementally to run your own business and enable sales. And also, maybe from the competitive standpoint, what you're seeing out there in terms of technology or apps or things like that, that might be causing any pressure down the road?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Aram. So we've used technology in our stores from the very beginning in a combination of things, both for our associates and for our customers. So we employ a lot of use of data and the ability to deliver that data back to our employees at the mom
componenttext:
Thanks, Aram. So we've used technology in our stores from the very beginning in a combination of things, both for our associates and for our customers. So we employ a lot of use of data and the ability to deliver that data back to our employees at the moment they need it to make good decisions. We have lots of ability to track customers through the process and make future decisions based on that. So I think we've done a pretty good job of utilizing technology in our stores so that our associates can deliver a great customer experience. 
In terms of customer facing, it's something that we continue to invest in and we'll continue to invest in more going forward. We want to make sure that we can communicate with our customers, however it is that they want to communicate with us. I've talked in the past about being a little bit behind in terms of mobile. We'll continue to invest there. We've made lots of improvements over time to our pictures and the quality of our pictures. We used to take 1 then 9. We're up to around 40. We have high-definition pictures. We have zoom capability. We've adjusted our landing pages to be more personalized and we'll continue to make some efforts in that regard as well. And I think you'll see us do a lot more stuff as it relates to mobile and touchscreen. It's more than 50% of our total hits to our website are now coming from either a mobile device or a tablet and it's something that we need to make sure that the customer has a fantastic experience if they want to communicate with us in that format. So those are the kinds of things we continue to invest in. 
And we've tested online capabilities, which is a lot -- you see a lot of nichey-type things from various -- whether they're competitors or people who enable our competitors. Things such as online credit applications, which we're testing. The ability to transfer a car from one location to another without speaking to a sales consultant, the ability to put a credit card payment down to have those cars transferred, which we're doing. You can go online and put a car on hold. You can make an appointment with our sales consultants. So we've done a lot of stuff to make sure our customers can do more and more of the process from home. They can fill out a good chunk of the paperwork before they show up at our store. But all these things are the types of stuff that we need to continue to invest in. But I think we've made a lot of nice progress, but we got a long way to go.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask about productivity in terms of used units sold per dealership. And I guess, the way I was thinking about it is pre-recession, you guys averaged about 4,800 units, which was well over 4,000 of 0- to 4-year-old cars by my math. Just looki
componenttext:
Just wanted to ask about productivity in terms of used units sold per dealership. And I guess, the way I was thinking about it is pre-recession, you guys averaged about 4,800 units, which was well over 4,000 of 0- to 4-year-old cars by my math. Just looking ahead in coming years, we think the supply of 0- to 4-year-old vehicles is going to grow by about 25%, 30% over the next 5 or 6 years and ultimately, could drive a 10% to 15% tailwind in your throughput. Can you just comment on that at all, about maybe what some of the risks are to that? Or is there something that I'm missing? 
And then secondarily, just love to get your thoughts around profitability on a dealership level. If you are able to get that kind of throughput, any structural impediments to retail EBIT margins going up in that environment?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, on your comment about throughput annualized of 0- to 4-year-old cars, we've never been just 0- to 4-year-old cars. We've always been 0 to 10, so it's a much broader spectrum of vehicles than you stated there. That number did change over time. As I
componenttext:
First, on your comment about throughput annualized of 0- to 4-year-old cars, we've never been just 0- to 4-year-old cars. We've always been 0 to 10, so it's a much broader spectrum of vehicles than you stated there. That number did change over time. As I stated in my comments, 0- to 4-year-old cars represent 75% of our sales. That was 70% just a couple of years ago, so it's moved by about 5 points. But you kind of have to look at a much broader spectrum of inventory to look at total sales for CarMax. And it does look like you would see a supply movement in 0 to 4, just based on movement and SAR [ph]. And as I've said, before we have historically had higher share in the 0- to 4-year-old segment. So is there a potential tailwind? Probably, but there's -- the other factor in there is consumer behavior and will they trade out a car as much as they used to when you have population growth and new drivers and things like that. So there's lots of different variables and factors, and I don't think you can just say we expect whatever the number you said, 20% or -- I forgot what number you said there. But I don't think we can just expect that as an increase in sales. 
In terms of how did the stores handle it. We've been able to deliver exceptionally high volumes out of some pretty limited space in our stores and all comp sales are more profitable than sales, once you've cleared all of your expenses. So it's very, very profitable for the company to continue to deliver comp sales out of existing facilities because a lot of your fixed overhead remains constant. You really just have to add some favorable overheads. 
So we're really pleased with the comps we delivered over the last couple of years. I think it's one of the great parts of our business model, is that our stores continue to grow. As I said, we gained 5% share during the year. That's on top of the 17% share gain in the year prior. But once again, that's over 0- to 10-year-old cars. So I think our stores are well primed to take advantage of supply increases, if that translates to sales. And then they're well positioned to turn that into better-than-average profits because they're all on top of a base that's already covering fixed overhead.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question's around comp sales growth. Tom, you spoke to traffic, conversion driving the comp. Maybe you can break that down. How much of it was traffic and how much was conversion? And related to that, what was driving the better conversion?
componenttext: My question's around comp sales growth. Tom, you spoke to traffic, conversion driving the comp. Maybe you can break that down. How much of it was traffic and how much was conversion? And related to that, what was driving the better conversion?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Seth, that's a good question. We get that frequently. It was roughly 50-50 in terms of conversion and traffic. And I always thought that over time, it'll be 50-50. It doesn't line up all that time. Sometimes it all comes from conversion, sometimes it all
componenttext:
Seth, that's a good question. We get that frequently. It was roughly 50-50 in terms of conversion and traffic. And I always thought that over time, it'll be 50-50. It doesn't line up all that time. Sometimes it all comes from conversion, sometimes it all comes from traffic. This happened to be one where it matched up. As we've looked at over a very long period of time and the way we think about it going forward, is I would like to be able to continue to increase traffic through our stores, and I'd like to be able to do better with the traffic that we have. 
And in terms of what are we doing to improve conversion, we have some really fantastic people in our stores that are dedicated and committed everyday to giving the customer a great experience. We've tried to do a good job of providing additional training. Some of the stuff I talked about earlier in terms of technology as it relates to information and capabilities that our associates have, we've improved over the last several years and plan to continue to improve going forward. So I really think it's just a testament to our 20,000 dedicated employees in the stores who work really hard every day to try to be more and more efficient and give the customer a better experience. Hopefully, that turns into higher sales, and then they, in turn, go and tell all their friends and become spokespeople for CarMax. It's worked for us in the past and I expect it to keep working going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. So [indiscernible] primarily your training, would you say there's any difference in the quality of the credit offers or the credit availability that's affected the conversion trends over the last few quarters?
componenttext: Got it. So [indiscernible] primarily your training, would you say there's any difference in the quality of the credit offers or the credit availability that's affected the conversion trends over the last few quarters?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's another thing that is constantly on the move. It's a combination of what we do, a combination of what our partners do. I think Tom mentioned this is -- this was a relatively stable year compared to some in the past where we've seen some movements,
componenttext: That's another thing that is constantly on the move. It's a combination of what we do, a combination of what our partners do. I think Tom mentioned this is -- this was a relatively stable year compared to some in the past where we've seen some movements, whether it's up or down from some of the lenders. We saw a big pullback during the recession. We saw some changes over the last couple of years in subprime up or down. But this year has been relatively stable in terms of credit.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Rick Nelson with Stephens.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Rick Nelson with Stephens.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, a couple of franchise dealers have opened stores recently in your market. So if you could comment per the impact that they might be having and how you respond from a competitive standpoint, overall thoughts on those concepts?
componenttext: Tom, a couple of franchise dealers have opened stores recently in your market. So if you could comment per the impact that they might be having and how you respond from a competitive standpoint, overall thoughts on those concepts?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Rick. I know Sonic opened some stores in the Denver market and Asbury opened some stores in the Florida market. We're clearly more established in Florida. We've been there for much longer period of time. Neither of those concepts have been o
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Rick. I know Sonic opened some stores in the Denver market and Asbury opened some stores in the Florida market. We're clearly more established in Florida. We've been there for much longer period of time. Neither of those concepts have been open very long, so its very difficult for us to read any results or impacts at this time. When we have some, we'll be happy to share it, but both of those concepts have been open for a very short period of time and I really can't comment on their performance. But I don't -- Sonic's been open for less than last 6 months and Asbury's been open, I think, around 1 year. So the stores are a little bit smaller than ours. Some of them are closer than others. But so far, it's too early to comment.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and the market share gains that you talked about, 0- to 10-year-old bucket, can you discuss where the gains are the biggest? And is it in that sort of 4-year-old bucket or the high -- the more aged vehicles?
componenttext: Okay, and the market share gains that you talked about, 0- to 10-year-old bucket, can you discuss where the gains are the biggest? And is it in that sort of 4-year-old bucket or the high -- the more aged vehicles?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rick, I actually don't know the answer to that. I'm not sure we have it in that level of detail. We generally get the whole market. You saw that we said it's through calendar year this year. This is the data that we have bought. And the reason we have gon
componenttext: Rick, I actually don't know the answer to that. I'm not sure we have it in that level of detail. We generally get the whole market. You saw that we said it's through calendar year this year. This is the data that we have bought. And the reason we have gone to yearly announcements is the data is very, I would call it, unstable in the short term. So we're pretty confident in the direction and the number. But in terms of dividing it very specifically, we haven't really done that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King & Associates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I see that your average selling price for retail was down about $600 sequentially. Is that a function of mix? Or are you seeing maybe some declining pricing trend? And in relation -- related to that, when you're out buying cars at auctions, what sort of t
componenttext: I see that your average selling price for retail was down about $600 sequentially. Is that a function of mix? Or are you seeing maybe some declining pricing trend? And in relation -- related to that, when you're out buying cars at auctions, what sort of trends are using right now in terms of supply and price trend?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's mostly seasonality. We see a seasonal drop in the fourth quarter. Really, fourth quarter over fourth quarter, our average retails were up slightly. So not really much there. If you look at our mix sequentially of 0- to 4-year-old cars, it di
componenttext:
Yes, that's mostly seasonality. We see a seasonal drop in the fourth quarter. Really, fourth quarter over fourth quarter, our average retails were up slightly. So not really much there. 
If you look at our mix sequentially of 0- to 4-year-old cars, it didn't really move very much. It did move from this year's fourth quarter compared to last year's fourth quarter by almost 5 points, which would lead you to believe that maybe prices would go the other direction. So I think it's more just seasonal movement and nothing really else to read into there. 
In terms of what we're seeing at the auctions. This is a time of the year when we always see appreciation in the marketplace. If you look at the most recent Manheim Index, there really hasn't been very much movement. But if we were just thinking of it as a normal year, we would come out at January and head into the spring and expect some appreciation in the market, probably into early summary. And then, we would see a normal decline through the fall if this is a normal year. But we don't like to make a lot of predictions about where the market's going to go. I think we've talked in the past about our ability to adjusted moves and adapt to whatever the market brings to us, and we plan our inventory on a weekly basis. So what we're seeing right now in the wholesale marketplace not really out of line with what we would have expected.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of anticipation, I guess, of lots -- an influx of more supply of the wholesale coming from off-lease vehicles and trade ins, et cetera. Are you guys seeing a more plentiful supply when you go to auctions every weekly, or not necessarily?
componenttext: There's a lot of anticipation, I guess, of lots -- an influx of more supply of the wholesale coming from off-lease vehicles and trade ins, et cetera. Are you guys seeing a more plentiful supply when you go to auctions every weekly, or not necessarily?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily. Remember, too, that leases that are originated in -- I think, lease percentage is at a pretty high clip right now, somewhere around 30% in the industry. We won't see those cars for 2 or 3 years. So I think a lot of people look at lease pe
componenttext: Not necessarily. Remember, too, that leases that are originated in -- I think, lease percentage is at a pretty high clip right now, somewhere around 30% in the industry. We won't see those cars for 2 or 3 years. So I think a lot of people look at lease percentages and think, "Oh, you're going to see a big influx of cars," when it's really 2 or 3 years down the road. And what we've seen in the past -- and we've been at this for 20 years. And we've seen percentages in the 30s and we've seen lease percentages in the teens. What ends up happening is eventually, those cars end up available for purchase and we've done a nice job figuring out how to have access to them.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. First, on the subprime pilot program, just wanted to make sure that the extension doesn't really rule out a meaningful expansion of the program later. And can you highlight any specific areas that you feel need more time to eva
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. First, on the subprime pilot program, just wanted to make sure that the extension doesn't really rule out a meaningful expansion of the program later. And can you highlight any specific areas that you feel need more time to evaluate versus what you were expecting earlier?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me address the first. I think as I said, the results to date are in line with what our initial expectations were. This is a different asset class for us so we're interested in seeing how it performs. Because it's new to us, we're willing to be patient
componenttext:
Let me address the first. I think as I said, the results to date are in line with what our initial expectations were. This is a different asset class for us so we're interested in seeing how it performs. Because it's new to us, we're willing to be patient and ensure that we understand it completely before we do anything else. It does not rule out us doing a larger amount in the future. 
But if you remember, when we rolled this out 1 year ago, we said that there was 3 things we're looking for: one is learning, which we're definitely gaining on that. I think it's going to benefit our business, whether or not we're in this space. But the other was a risk diversification play, and we have 3 partners in the subprime space who are doing an awesome job. Any decisions we make will be contemplating the impact on them, and I would not expect us to ever intend to be the sole player in this space like we are in the prime space. That's probably as much color as I can give you about what where our intentions would go.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, makes sense. And on competition, this is perhaps a more longer-term strategic question. Over the last 12 months, we've seen emergence of a few peer-to-peer used vehicle platforms that try to pass on SG&A savings to customers. I'm sure these new start-
componenttext: No, makes sense. And on competition, this is perhaps a more longer-term strategic question. Over the last 12 months, we've seen emergence of a few peer-to-peer used vehicle platforms that try to pass on SG&A savings to customers. I'm sure these new start-ups are only in a few markets right now, but one can imagine them going after the high-volume used markets first, where you and your peers already have a presence. So my question really is, what do guys think about these new business models versus the brick-and-mortar strategy in general?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We look at every part of competition and in terms of peer-to-peer, one thing to remember is that is a huge chunk of the market already and always has been. About 1/3 of all cars sold in the U.S. are sold from consumers to consumer, whether it's you sell a
componenttext:
We look at every part of competition and in terms of peer-to-peer, one thing to remember is that is a huge chunk of the market already and always has been. About 1/3 of all cars sold in the U.S. are sold from consumers to consumer, whether it's you sell a car by putting a sign in your yard or you're listed online or you used to put it in the newspaper or whatever you do, so that's always been 1/3. One could argue that, that's where those sales would come from since they're already happening and it's just such a giant piece. It's by far the biggest piece of -- the biggest percentage of cars sold are sold from peer-to-peer already. 
A lot of what do in our -- when we make a cash offer to every customer on every single car, I think we probably have tapped into that as well as anybody, by getting some of those cars that maybe would've been sold peer to peer. But it's something we keep a very close eye on and will watch very closely and see if there's an opportunity somewhere for us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of David Whiston with Morningstar.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of David Whiston with Morningstar.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: On store openings for the upcoming year, you've got a definite skew towards existing markets over new. And I was just curious if longer term, are you going to look to focus more on growing existing over new or reverse and focus more on new later on?
componenttext: On store openings for the upcoming year, you've got a definite skew towards existing markets over new. And I was just curious if longer term, are you going to look to focus more on growing existing over new or reverse and focus more on new later on?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's an ever-changing landscape for us. As we continue to get more data in existing markets, it gives us more comfort with going back into those markets, but we have a healthy mix of new markets as well. And one thing to take into account, when we go into
componenttext:
It's an ever-changing landscape for us. As we continue to get more data in existing markets, it gives us more comfort with going back into those markets, but we have a healthy mix of new markets as well. And one thing to take into account, when we go into a metro market like Philadelphia, Minneapolis or this year will be entering Boston, those are intentionally multiyear plays for us to really grow out the market. So when you see us go back into Philly with the Turnersville, New Jersey store this year, that's just part of the long-term Philadelphia plan. It looks like a skew towards an existing market, but those are existing markets that are clearly under-stored and we're not where we expect to be long term. So I expect it to be a mix going forward. 
Some of the big ones that we have coming in the next 3 years or so: Boston, San Francisco and Seattle are places where we have no presence. And it's taken us, I don't know, 15 years to get to 10 stores in LA. And you'll see us continue to learn more, figure out places where we're -- zip codes where we're missing, and then try to figure out the best storing pattern to go into those bigger metro markets. So I don't read too much into that because some of -- as I said, some of it is just planned because the markets are bigger and more stores are required to fill them out.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on buybacks, it would be helpful for modeling if you could give any clarity on dollar spend for fiscal '16.
componenttext: Okay. And on buybacks, it would be helpful for modeling if you could give any clarity on dollar spend for fiscal '16.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: We don't give guidance on anything. But I mean, you can look at our release last fall and it gives you an idea of the scale that we have intentions for the longer term.
componenttext: We don't give guidance on anything. But I mean, you can look at our release last fall and it gives you an idea of the scale that we have intentions for the longer term.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: But it's also going to be a balance based on where we're trading and what we think makes the most sense.
componenttext: But it's also going to be a balance based on where we're trading and what we think makes the most sense.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just want to sneak one more in. It seems like given the harsh weather on a year-over-year basis, you may have lost some day sales and maybe next year, comp would be even stronger in retrospect. But just want to maybe ask for your -- kind of your view on t
componenttext: Just want to sneak one more in. It seems like given the harsh weather on a year-over-year basis, you may have lost some day sales and maybe next year, comp would be even stronger in retrospect. But just want to maybe ask for your -- kind of your view on the weather, if you will.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: As you probably know, James, we never like to use weather as an excuse, but it was really cold. And we did have a lot of stores closed, particularly in the back half of February. As far as attributing sales loss, we generally think we'd get it back. Bec
componenttext:
As you probably know, James, we never like to use weather as an excuse, but it was really cold. And we did have a lot of stores closed, particularly in the back half of February. 
As far as attributing sales loss, we generally think we'd get it back. Because when we're closed, everybody else is closed. It's not like milk. If you didn't sell it, you didn't sell it or a grocer. It's such an infrequent purchase. If we're closed, generally, all the competition is closed as well. So I can't attribute a specific sales loss to it, but we probably would have done a little better if it wasn't so cold. We had a bunch of stores closed in the back half, particularly in the back half of February. But as I said, I think generally, we get those sales back.

componenttext: Is there any color you could provide on that? Just because it does kind of indicate some sort of overall big-ticket demand, even if it doesn't relate directly to your business, just kind of change in behavior at all?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we didn't see much. So I mean, whether it's regional or -- I feel like we had a really good quarter and a really good year. We've got a lot of questions around gas prices and is it potential that gas -- lowering gas prices would drive sales toward
componenttext:
I mean, we didn't see much. So I mean, whether it's regional or -- I feel like we had a really good quarter and a really good year. We've got a lot of questions around gas prices and is it potential that gas -- lowering gas prices would drive sales towards kind of SUVs and V8, and we really didn't see much of that either. So I think possibly, because we have such a wide range of inventory and we appeal to such a broad range of customers, that some of those impacts are muted with us. But who knows? 
I also think as -- in terms of gas prices, that people do not expect gas to be this cheap and a car is a long-term purchase. So although you might see some shifting, it really hasn't affected us as much as you might think. Many of you think gas prices are going to go back up so...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Levin on for Rod. Just wanted to see if you could discuss some of the factors that went into you guys getting increased confidence in raising your store growth plans over the next 3 years from 10 to 15, to 13 to 16.
componenttext: It's Mike Levin on for Rod. Just wanted to see if you could discuss some of the factors that went into you guys getting increased confidence in raising your store growth plans over the next 3 years from 10 to 15, to 13 to 16.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you recall coming out of the recession and getting back into a growth plan, we wanted to have a phased build up. We wanted to make sure that we built up our infrastructure. And by infrastructure I mean the ability to go out and source real sta
componenttext: Sure. So if you recall coming out of the recession and getting back into a growth plan, we wanted to have a phased build up. We wanted to make sure that we built up our infrastructure. And by infrastructure I mean the ability to go out and source real state, the ability to make sure that we provide experience, management into all these stores, where we spend a lot of dollars on relo to make sure that, that first customer that walks in the door gets a great experience at CarMax. And our buildup over a few years, we opened 3 in the first year, then 5, then 10, then 13 for 2 years in a row. And so this is kind of in-line with continuing as -- the base has also gotten bigger during that time. I think we've added 50 stores since...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Since 2011. Increased the company size from 90-ish stores to 145 or so. So -- and we opened 13 this year and we plan on opening 14 next year. So it's right in the -- just kind of in the range of what we delivered. And we wanted to give ourselves some flex
componenttext: Since 2011. Increased the company size from 90-ish stores to 145 or so. So -- and we opened 13 this year and we plan on opening 14 next year. So it's right in the -- just kind of in the range of what we delivered. And we wanted to give ourselves some flexibility. These are big complicated stores. Sometimes 1 or 2 might slip in or out of a year, so we like to put a range around it. But we don't plan on opening 10 anymore, so we're -- that's kind of the range we think we can deliver over the next few years. So it's confidence and all the things that I talked about, and that's the reason we raised the range.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we hit on that a little earlier. But as Tom mentioned, I think our goal is to be in it programmatically. If you look at what happened in Q4, we bought back fewer shares and spent less dollars at an elevated stock price. So we put some buffers
componenttext: Yes, I think we hit on that a little earlier. But as Tom mentioned, I think our goal is to be in it programmatically. If you look at what happened in Q4, we bought back fewer shares and spent less dollars at an elevated stock price. So we put some buffers on our program based on our estimation of valuation. But in general, we want to be in the market on a continuous basis and programmatically move towards a capital structure that's got a little more leverage in it. And I think you'll see us doing that over the next couple of years.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on 2 things: One was inventory per store, which I had up kind of low double digits. So I was just trying to understand, how much of that might be anticipated build-out as you increase the unit growth versus, like, a desire to actu
componenttext:
Just wanted to follow up on 2 things: One was inventory per store, which I had up kind of low double digits. So I was just trying to understand, how much of that might be anticipated build-out as you increase the unit growth versus, like, a desire to actually increase sale rates and have more cars in the lot? 
And then secondly, with CapEx going from $310 million to $360 million, can you just help to understand how much of that is related to the remodels versus the new store acceleration, and what the major buckets of spend there?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. What was your first question again?
componenttext: Sure. What was your first question again?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Inventory.
componenttext: Inventory.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Inventory, yes, so -- yes, inventory in the quarter was up. Remember last year, we were behind on where we wanted to be. So some of it is in kind of, I would call it, an easy comparison because we were behind on inventory. This year, we did a much better
componenttext:
Inventory, yes, so -- yes, inventory in the quarter was up. Remember last year, we were behind on where we wanted to be. So some of it is in kind of, I would call it, an easy comparison because we were behind on inventory. This year, we did a much better job of building and we also had a bunch of new stores. So a lot of times when you look -- when we're in a build mode, when we get a car done and saleable, we make it salable in the store that finished it. So some stores have elevated inventory in anticipation of a store opening when we ship the cars over to the new store. So if you look at our total sales increase for the quarter, I think it was 12%. And you would expect inventory to go up kind of commensurate with that number. And then we had another during the quarter, 7% of comps. And I know inventory is slightly higher than when you add those 2 things together, but that, I think, is more of a reflection of -- we're a little behind where we wanted to be last year. 
And then your second question.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on the CapEx side, just understanding the step-up year-over-year in CapEx spend. How much is related to the new store openings increasing versus remodels and the major buckets of spend in the $360 million?
componenttext: Just on the CapEx side, just understanding the step-up year-over-year in CapEx spend. How much is related to the new store openings increasing versus remodels and the major buckets of spend in the $360 million?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the major buckets in the $360 million: Roughly $80 million of it would be on existing stores; $40 million of that would be in normal maintenance; and the other $40 million would be in the remodels that we talked about; and all the rest goes towards n
componenttext: Yes, the major buckets in the $360 million: Roughly $80 million of it would be on existing stores; $40 million of that would be in normal maintenance; and the other $40 million would be in the remodels that we talked about; and all the rest goes towards new stores. And remember, CapEx is always our best guess at the year. We have a lot of movement and a lot of timing during the year, particularly in new stores and new construction. So that's our best guess of what we'll spend this year, and that's roughly the breakdown.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And Ms. Katharine Kenny, you may begin your conference.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer, and good morning. Thank you, all, for joining our fiscal 2015 fourth quarter and year-end earnings conference call. As always, on the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our E
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer, and good morning. Thank you, all, for joining our fiscal 2015 fourth quarter and year-end earnings conference call. As always, on the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them.
For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ending February 28, 2014. A new one will be out shortly, filed with the SEC.
[Operator Instructions] Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. As you saw by now, we had both a record fourth quarter and a record fiscal year. During the year, total revenues grew to more than $14 billion and we sold nearly 1 million to
componenttext:
Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. As you saw by now, we had both a record fourth quarter and a record fiscal year. During the year, total revenues grew to more than $14 billion and we sold nearly 1 million total vehicles, more than 591,000 retail cars and 376,000 wholesale cars through our in-store auctions. Here's some -- here are some of the key highlights for the year.
Used unit comps, up 4%, and total used units grew by over 10%. Wholesale vehicle gross profit, up 16%, driven by a 10% increase in units sold and an increase in wholesale growth -- gross profit per unit of $54 per car.
CAF income, up 9% to more than $367 million. Tom will give some more details on that in a moment. Excluding the items we highlighted in the press release, net income for the fiscal year increased 16% and EPS grew 21%.
Our data indicates that for the calendar year 2014, we increased our share of the 0- to 10-year-old used vehicle market by approximately 5%. We continue to -- we also continue to focus on returning value to shareholders through our stock repurchase program. During fiscal 2015, we bought back 17.5 million shares at a cost of a little over $900 million. Since we began the program in fiscal 2013, we have purchased more than 30 million shares.
Now on to some of the key drivers for the fourth quarter. Used unit comps, up 7%, driven by an increase in traffic as well as an improvement in conversion. Total used units grew by 12%. Wholesale growth -- gross profit, up 22%, reflecting a 12% increase in units sold and an increase of $83 in gross profit per unit. CAF quarterly income, up 12% to $90 million. And again, excluding the items we shared in the press release, net income for the fourth quarter increased 20% and earnings per share, up 28%.
With that, I'll turn it over to Tom and he'll give you some details around CAF. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. CAF recorded another solid year with 9% income growth to $367 million and growth in average managed receivables of 19%. As Tom mentioned, in the fourth quarter, CAF income was $90.4 million, up 12% compared to the fou
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. CAF recorded another solid year with 9% income growth to $367 million and growth in average managed receivables of 19%. As Tom mentioned, in the fourth quarter, CAF income was $90.4 million, up 12% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2014. And Q4 average managed receivables grew 18% to $8.3 billion.
CAF's weighted average contract rate, that rate that we charge to customers, was flat to last year's fourth quarter at 7.2%. This rate continued to be relatively stable at around 7% for the past couple of years. The allowance for loan losses grew to about $82 million. This represents 1% of managed receivables, which is relatively consistent with last year. But during the quarter and the year, CAF income did benefit from favorable loss experience.
CAF net penetration was 40.9% compared to 40.1% in last year's fourth quarter. This figure includes originations from our subprime test. And if you back out those originations, this quarter's penetration would have been 40.2%, which is similar to last year. Net loan dollars originated in the quarter rose 16% to $1.2 billion, due to a combination of CarMax's unit sales growth, our modestly higher penetration and a small increase in the average amount financed.
Finally, we intend to continue with our subprime test. Recall that our primary goal for this investment was to gain knowledge regarding the space, and we expect these learnings will prove invaluable. While performance to date is in line with our expectations, we believe allowing the receivables to season deeper into their life, including maturing through a full tax season, will better equip us to assess our long-term strategy.
On average, the term of these contracts is nearly 70 months, and at fiscal year-end, the average term on our books for the loans is less than 7 months. We're comfortable continuing to originate at the current target volume, which is 5% of CarMax's subprime sales or a little less than 2% of CAF originations.
Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As far as mix of sales, sales of 0- to 4-year-old vehicles grew to approximately 75% of our total sales, the same as the third quarter but over 5 percentage points higher than last year's fourth quarter. Sales of SUVs and trucks as a percentage
componenttext:
Thank you. As far as mix of sales, sales of 0- to 4-year-old vehicles grew to approximately 75% of our total sales, the same as the third quarter but over 5 percentage points higher than last year's fourth quarter. Sales of SUVs and trucks as a percentage was similar to last year.
SG&A for the quarter increased approximately 11% to $330 million. Contributing to this growth was the addition of 18 stores since the beginning of the fourth quarter of last year and a $9 million increase in share-based compensation expense.
On a per-unit basis, SG&A decreased $23 to $2,186 compared to $2,209 in the fourth quarter of fiscal '14. During the fourth quarter, we opened 1 store in our new Cleveland market and Katharine's hometown.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Since the fourth quarter, we opened 2 more stores: one In Minneapolis, a new market for CarMax; and one yesterday in Turnersville, New Jersey, which is part of our Philadelphia market. In addition to these 2, we plan to open 12 more stores in fiscal '16,
componenttext:
Since the fourth quarter, we opened 2 more stores: one In Minneapolis, a new market for CarMax; and one yesterday in Turnersville, New Jersey, which is part of our Philadelphia market. In addition to these 2, we plan to open 12 more stores in fiscal '16, plus the relocation of our store in Rockville, Maryland.
In regard to our small-format test. We've now opened 5 stores and as a group, they are performing at or above our expectations. We expect the small-format stores to be a part of our store openings going forward. Of our 14 store openings in fiscal '16, there will be 3 small format, including our first small-format front store with production -- full production capability in the back, and that will be in Gainesville, Florida.
Also, we now plan to open between 13 and 16 stores annually over the next 3 years. Store traffic was up once again in the quarter, and our web traffic also continued to expand. For the fourth quarter, average monthly web visits grew over 9% compared to last year's fourth quarter to over 14.5 million visits. And visits to our mobile site now represent approximately 32% of the total, while visits utilizing our mobile app represent another 16% of the total.
And with that, we'll open it up for questions. Operator?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.

componenttext: So I'll ask just a couple of questions here. So a question, I guess, and a follow up. First off, just a point of clarification. You mentioned the subprime test and the continuation of that test. So are you now planning to go above the prior stated $70 million size in the test? And if so, I mean, how should we think about, I guess, what could be the new volume relative to that initial goal? And then I'll come back for the [indiscernible]

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian, I'm sorry if I wasn't clear. But I think in the release, we say we did $72 million up to the end of fiscal 2015. So that gives you -- that's what we did through the year. What I meant -- what I said is we're comfortable continuing at the same
componenttext: Yes, Brian, I'm sorry if I wasn't clear. But I think in the release, we say we did $72 million up to the end of fiscal 2015. So that gives you -- that's what we did through the year. What I meant -- what I said is we're comfortable continuing at the same pace, which is about 5% of the subprime business that CarMax does. So if subprime continues to be a similar number of our sales as last year, it would be a similar pace of volume for us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then also on this follow-up, also on the subprime business, as you look at not just what you're originating, but what your partners are originating as well, any commentary there about kind of the willingness of your partners to l
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then also on this follow-up, also on the subprime business, as you look at not just what you're originating, but what your partners are originating as well, any commentary there about kind of the willingness of your partners to lend? I guess, a couple of quarters where we saw some type of disruption. Just with a lot of grumbling through the market, what's going on out there, are you seeing any shifts at all in the willingness of your partners to lend subprime-based accounts?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look year-over-year, we're at 17% versus 17.6% as a percent of subprime in the business. Last year's fourth quarter is when we really first started feeling any changes in behavior. And as I mentioned I think on the last call, we've se
componenttext:
Well, I think if you look year-over-year, we're at 17% versus 17.6% as a percent of subprime in the business. Last year's fourth quarter is when we really first started feeling any changes in behavior. And as I mentioned I think on the last call, we've seen pretty consistent behavior out of our partners for the last several quarters. 
The key thing that we're looking at is the quality of their offers, and what that translates into is how many of those customers that receive offers from them actually convert to a sale. Our subprime partners cannot control the nature of what's coming into them because the Tier 2 lenders are looking at it ahead of time and have the first look at that. So on the basis of conversion of offers, we see their behavior to be very consistent and we're very happy with their performance.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think this might be -- in the press release, you indicated you're doing 15 remodels this year and 1 relo. And I don't really remember any remodeling program at CarMax. So can you talk about kind of what you expect to do in the remodels? If there's an
componenttext: So I think this might be -- in the press release, you indicated you're doing 15 remodels this year and 1 relo. And I don't really remember any remodeling program at CarMax. So can you talk about kind of what you expect to do in the remodels? If there's anything operationally that, that will affect? Or if it's more cosmetic? And then the relo, just where is that? And is there the opportunity for more relos in the CarMax system?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first of all, over our history, we've constantly spent capital on keeping our stores up-to-date and renovating them over time. Since we launched the next-gen concept, I forget, 4, 5 years ago now, we've now gone back in and we're applying some of
componenttext:
Sure. So first of all, over our history, we've constantly spent capital on keeping our stores up-to-date and renovating them over time. Since we launched the next-gen concept, I forget, 4, 5 years ago now, we've now gone back in and we're applying some of those technology changes with some more digital screens and some digital capabilities in the stores as well as open seating, which we really had prior to next gen, but we think it's a much more efficient use of floor space. And so the conversions are a little more extensive than they have been, because we're doing a combination of technology and converting, whether it's cubes or offices, into floor space. We just finished converting our Richmond store. It looks fantastic, and that's the oldest store in the chain. I think we completed 3 or 4 full -- of these types of convergence, and they're a little bit more expensive than the money that would have been spent so we just thought we would call it out, and we plan to do another 17 this year. 
In terms of the operational changes, it doesn't change much operationally, but I think it provides a better experience for our customers and a better working environment for our associates as well. So we've been pretty pleased with what we've done so for, and we'll gauge the results going forward and see how much more aggressively we want to spend. 
In terms of the relo, that's our Rockville store. Our Rockville store was originally a competitor who built a kind of a copy cat. It's a very small footprint. I think it's only on 5 acres or so and it's been a very successful store for us. This is just a situation where the lease was up for renewal and we took the opportunity to move. We're really only moving a short distance away from that store to a much bigger facility. And that store's been very successful for us, but was really undersized the whole time we had it. At this time, we don't have any other plans for relos. This one was just more opportunistic as the lease came up.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think the last couple of quarters, you talked about Tier 2 becoming a bit more aggressive in terms of their lending, and that was that subprime penetration was starting to moderate a little bit. But as subprime penetrations kind of rebounded, at leas
componenttext: So I think the last couple of quarters, you talked about Tier 2 becoming a bit more aggressive in terms of their lending, and that was that subprime penetration was starting to moderate a little bit. But as subprime penetrations kind of rebounded, at least, sequentially the last 2 quarters, does that mean Tier 2's pulled back a bit? Or should we just view that as more overall credit availability when you kind of look at the overall market?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Scot, this is Tom. I think it's -- you're better to view it as Tier 3 stabilizing versus reading anything into overall credit availability. Tier 2's still doing very strong for us and as I said, we're happy with our partners. We brought in some new partne
componenttext: Scot, this is Tom. I think it's -- you're better to view it as Tier 3 stabilizing versus reading anything into overall credit availability. Tier 2's still doing very strong for us and as I said, we're happy with our partners. We brought in some new partners. We have a really good, diverse stable of finance partners in Tier 2 and it's performing well for us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an idea of kind of what Tier 2 has done on the penetration rate, kind of on a year-over-year basis, Tom?
componenttext: Can you give us an idea of kind of what Tier 2 has done on the penetration rate, kind of on a year-over-year basis, Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
componenttextpreview: Typical, what we've seen is something in the low 40s for CarMax Auto Finance, and we said 20% to 25% gets financed outside the CarMax system, and the rest being kind of split between Tier 2 and Tier 3. I'd say that in the current environment, we're lookin
componenttext: Typical, what we've seen is something in the low 40s for CarMax Auto Finance, and we said 20% to 25% gets financed outside the CarMax system, and the rest being kind of split between Tier 2 and Tier 3. I'd say that in the current environment, we're looking at kind of the lower end of that 20% to 25% for other. And so Tier 2 and Tier 3 are doing 35%, and we said Tier 3 was at 17%, so that gives you a pretty good flavor.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015

componenttext: First, could you just give us the buy rate, if you did not provide that in the quarter? And then second, related to your ad spending, it appears to have declined after 4 quarters of strong growth. How should we think about ad spending going forward? And what are your key priorities for marketing under your leadership there?

componenttext: Sorry, yes, buy rate was right around 30%, very similar to last year. And in terms of ad spend, we did a Super Bowl last year. We did not do Super Bowl this year. So some of the -- most of the change is just the subtraction of Super Bowl year-over-year. But in terms of kind of a regular scheduled spend, it was in line with what we were trying to accomplish.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 02, 2015
