headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q1 FY 2016 conference call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Katharine Kenny, you may begin your call.
componenttext: Good morning. My name is, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q1 FY 2016 conference call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Ms. Katharine Kenny, you may begin your call.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. On the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO. Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's f
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. On the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO. Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual events or results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them. For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ending February 28, 2015 filed with the SEC. [Operator Instructions] . 
Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. We had a great first quarter driven by strong performance in all our key business areas and with the continuation of our store opening plan. Onto some of the highlights for t
componenttext:
Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. We had a great first quarter driven by strong performance in all our key business areas and with the continuation of our store opening plan. Onto some of the highlights for the quarter, used unit comps increased by 4.9% and total used units grew by 9.3%. Gross profit per unit relatively flat at $2,200 compared to $2,220 in the first quarter of last year. Total wholesale units grew by 4.7% and gross profit per wholesale unit of 1,032 was similar to 1,046 in the first quarter of last year. Other sales and revenues increased 14% year-over-year and CAF income grew 15% to approximately $109 million. 
I'll now turn it over to Tom to talk about financing. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, good morning, all. As Tom mentioned, CAF income grew by 15% compared to first quarter fiscal 2015 and average managed receivables grew by 17% to $8.7 billion. As mentioned, the released results for this quarter were again positively impacted
componenttext: Thanks, Tom, good morning, all. As Tom mentioned, CAF income grew by 15% compared to first quarter fiscal 2015 and average managed receivables grew by 17% to $8.7 billion. As mentioned, the released results for this quarter were again positively impacted by favorable loss experience at CAF. The weighted average contract rate, the rate we charge to the customers was 7.4%, up slightly from last year's first quarter at 7.2%. Our allowance for loan losses grew to about $84 million or 0.94% of managed receivables. CAF net penetration was 42.2% [ph], half a point of that came from loans originated under our subprime test and that compares with 41.3% in last year's first quarter. Net loan dollars originated in the quarter rose 10% to $1.4 billion, unit combination of CarMax unit sales growth and CAF's modestly higher penetration. And during the quarter, we repurchased 1.8 million shares for about $120 million. CAF down from the pace in recent quarters reflecting the increase in stock price. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. SG&A for the quarter increased approximately 11.6% to $350 million. Contributing to this growth were the addition of 16 stores since the beginning of the first quarter of last year and a $7.9 million increase in share-based compensation expense
componenttext:
Thank you. SG&A for the quarter increased approximately 11.6% to $350 million. Contributing to this growth were the addition of 16 stores since the beginning of the first quarter of last year and a $7.9 million increase in share-based compensation expense. On a per-unit basis, SG&A increased $51 to $2,098 compared to $2,047 in the first quarter of fiscal 2015, 39 of which was related to the stock-based compensation expense. During the first quarter we opened 3 stores, 2 in new markets for CarMax, Minneapolis and Gainesville, Florida. We also opened our third store in the Philadelphia market. After the first quarter ended, we opened our third and fourth stores in the Denver market, that was actually yesterday, and added a second store in the Providence market. We plan to open one more store in the second quarter in Tallahassee, Florida, which will be a new market for us. 
Our comp unit sales were driven by improved conversion and continued growth in customer traffic. Our web traffic was up almost 10% compared to the same period last year, monthly web visits grew to nearly $16 million. And now over 60% of our business are coming from something other than a laptop and a desktop. So we either a mobile device through our app or on a tablet. 
And with that, we'd be happy to take your questions. Operator?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Craig Kennison of Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Craig Kennison of Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is more of a long-term question, but we have this view that millennials might respond to your hassle-free business model better than prior generations. I'm curious what CarMax is doing to target this group any differently whether it's from a marketin
componenttext: This is more of a long-term question, but we have this view that millennials might respond to your hassle-free business model better than prior generations. I'm curious what CarMax is doing to target this group any differently whether it's from a marketing perspective or what your technology spend might look like going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Craig, and we're in the middle of investing in continued capabilities on our website and mobile devices, and I don't think that's just for millennials, I think that's really for all consumers. If you look at consumer behavior over
componenttext: That's a good question, Craig, and we're in the middle of investing in continued capabilities on our website and mobile devices, and I don't think that's just for millennials, I think that's really for all consumers. If you look at consumer behavior over the last several years, it's clearly shifting towards wanting to do more and more of whatever shopping process they're involved in online. And we see that continuing to shift, and then within that continuing to shift towards mobile. So we're working hard on our app and trying to have fantastic pictures on there. We've added zoom capability -- I mean we've added high definition and zoom capability. We are -- we've given customers the ability to transfer a car from any store to any other store, we've given the ability to pay for that online. If it's a pay transfer via credit card, they can fill out a big chunk of the paperwork online. And I think there's lots more to come there, it's just it's kind of an ongoing process in trying to stay out in front of technology. But continued investments in the website and our mobile device I think will attract not only millennials but other customers as well.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about subprime penetration? We seem to still be bouncing around a little bit and was down from 1Q last year. I guess I'm wondering is how much of that drop is from business being picked up by Tier 2 lenders and how much of that is maybe from
componenttext: Can you talk about subprime penetration? We seem to still be bouncing around a little bit and was down from 1Q last year. I guess I'm wondering is how much of that drop is from business being picked up by Tier 2 lenders and how much of that is maybe from some changes that the Tier 3 guys are making?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we talked about it a little bit last quarter we have seen pretty stable performance from our Tier 3 lenders. If you look at what they're proving in the quality of their offers, it's been pretty consistent for the last several quarters. And as
componenttext: Yes, I think we talked about it a little bit last quarter we have seen pretty stable performance from our Tier 3 lenders. If you look at what they're proving in the quality of their offers, it's been pretty consistent for the last several quarters. And as we talked about, you got to remember that their performance is a byproduct of both what they're doing on the credit front and what they're seeing coming through the pipeline. So I think it's fair to say that their behavior has been consistent and we're seeing a little bit more assertiveness in the Tier 2 space.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, so no change in terms of thought process we're going to Tier 3, they're probably just seeing less product because of the Tier 2 activity.
componenttext: All right, so no change in terms of thought process we're going to Tier 3, they're probably just seeing less product because of the Tier 2 activity.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can't speak for them, but if you look at credit quality of applications this quarter, it's up about 2 points year-over-year. That moved the mix a little bit. And I think we've done a lot of work to build a good stable of Tier 2 lenders that each brings
componenttext: I can't speak for them, but if you look at credit quality of applications this quarter, it's up about 2 points year-over-year. That moved the mix a little bit. And I think we've done a lot of work to build a good stable of Tier 2 lenders that each brings something different from on the table from a credit perspective and that adds incremental sale. So I think like I said we're happy with the performance of our Tier 3 lenders. We've seen consistent aggressiveness with them over the last several quarters. I wouldn't attribute it to anything but some things moving around.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: But just to be clear, when the Tier 2 guys may be picking up some share, we should have seen a much more profitable transaction for you, correct?
componenttext: But just to be clear, when the Tier 2 guys may be picking up some share, we should have seen a much more profitable transaction for you, correct?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as you know, we pay $1,000 per car in the Tier 3 space and we make $300 a car from the lender in the Tier 2 space. So every time we're shifting that volume, we're taking -- going from $1,000 out of pockets to $300, it is good you saw reflected in the
componenttext: Yes, as you know, we pay $1,000 per car in the Tier 3 space and we make $300 a car from the lender in the Tier 2 space. So every time we're shifting that volume, we're taking -- going from $1,000 out of pockets to $300, it is good you saw reflected in the other margin this quarter. Our finance, third-party finance net income, which is actually an expense, was actually flat year-over-year with 9% sales growth. And that's a direct result of the mix of Tier 3 being a little bit lower.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Scott, as you know, one of our main goals at  CarMax is to make sure that when customers show up at the store that they have access to credit and we always talk about global approval rating which is of applicants, how many get an approval from one of
componenttext: And Scott, as you know, one of our main goals at  CarMax is to make sure that when customers show up at the store that they have access to credit and we always talk about global approval rating which is of applicants, how many get an approval from one of our lenders starting with CAF and then heading down to all of our other partners. And that number is over 90%. So we're pretty pleased with the credit offering that we have for our customers when they show up at a store, whether it's through CAF or one of our partners.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Nagel from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Nagel from Oppenheimer.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question, a follow-up, kind of shoved into  one here. For the question on the buyback and Tom, you discussed this a bit in your prepared comments maybe an explanation why we saw a lower buyback here in Q1 versus the prior quarters. Can you give u
componenttext: I have a question, a follow-up, kind of shoved into  one here. For the question on the buyback and Tom, you discussed this a bit in your prepared comments maybe an explanation why we saw a lower buyback here in Q1 versus the prior quarters. Can you give us a little more color there on how you're thinking about that buyback relative to the stock price and maybe how we should consider the cadence of buybacks in coming quarters?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, I don't really want in a position to get into what we're going to do in future quarters, but I can tell you that our intentions are very much that it's a priority for us to return capital to shareholders. And as we talked about the last couple of qu
componenttext: Okay, I don't really want in a position to get into what we're going to do in future quarters, but I can tell you that our intentions are very much that it's a priority for us to return capital to shareholders. And as we talked about the last couple of quarters to move our capital structures to ones with a little bit more leverage in it. And that is something we're committed to do over the medium- to long-term. In any given quarter, we might see some bounce around because rather than having a trading mentality, we're trying to take a programmatic approach to buying back stock. We set a program and we let it run for a period of time. That program is going to have a guideline in it that allows for more share repurchase at lower stock prices. And dialing it back as the stock goes up. So we just kind of look at it from a longer-term perspective. We'll adjust those parameters as appropriate going forward, but that's pretty much as much as I could say. We have a program in place that dialed back at higher stock prices. We saw stock price increase significantly over the last several months. And as time goes forward, we'll adjust it as appropriate but keeping an eye on the fact that we do want to keep making progress towards leveraging the capital structure.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then my follow-up question, unrelated, just an update from an ARPU perspective, is CarMax still listing cars on AutoTrader.com and cars.com? Is [indiscernible] you utilize?
componenttext: That's helpful. And then my follow-up question, unrelated, just an update from an ARPU perspective, is CarMax still listing cars on AutoTrader.com and cars.com? Is [indiscernible] you utilize?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this time, it's not, Brian. We have gone on and off testing with cars.com and autotrader.com and we'll continue to test whatever listing sites that had incremental sales and that are worth the investment. With the growth of CarMax.com up to 16 million
componenttext: At this time, it's not, Brian. We have gone on and off testing with cars.com and autotrader.com and we'll continue to test whatever listing sites that had incremental sales and that are worth the investment. With the growth of CarMax.com up to 16 million hits a month, we're a pretty prominent website particularly in all the markets we operate in. And we haven't found that there is incremental value there. So at this time, we're mostly just using our own website. We are continuing to test, but we don't have any cars on cars.com or autotrader.com at this time.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia of William Bares.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia of William Bares.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess just 2 really quick questions. Tom, can you talk about why average selling price was down? I don't think I've ever seen that before at CarMax.And then secondarily, the stock comp, the $7.9 million, is there going to be accelerated stock comp all y
componenttext: I guess just 2 really quick questions. Tom, can you talk about why average selling price was down? I don't think I've ever seen that before at CarMax.And then secondarily, the stock comp, the $7.9 million, is there going to be accelerated stock comp all year and how do we think about that in the G&A line?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the first part, I think we were down, I'm getting the number here, we were down a couple of hundred bucks, and I'm with you, Sharon, I don't generally expect ASPs to go down. So I don't have a great explanation for it. I think lower prices are better f
componenttext: So the first part, I think we were down, I'm getting the number here, we were down a couple of hundred bucks, and I'm with you, Sharon, I don't generally expect ASPs to go down. So I don't have a great explanation for it. I think lower prices are better for our customers. I don't think there really is an indication of much of anything because the move was so modest. What was it last quarter?  We were roughly flat last quarter, I think we were up $100. So I haven't really read too much into it, it's such a small change in price. And then your second question, Sharon?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: The stock comp, I think you had $7.9 million of incremental stock compensation this quarter. I'm just trying to figure out if there's accelerated stock compensation all year, how we should think about that in G&A?
componenttext: The stock comp, I think you had $7.9 million of incremental stock compensation this quarter. I'm just trying to figure out if there's accelerated stock compensation all year, how we should think about that in G&A?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's largely going to be driven by how the stock performs. And a big chunk of that is in our restricted stock unit that go to the vast majority of the associates who are in the equity program, largely in our stores, and that's a cash-settled expense for
componenttext: That's largely going to be driven by how the stock performs. And a big chunk of that is in our restricted stock unit that go to the vast majority of the associates who are in the equity program, largely in our stores, and that's a cash-settled expense for us, and it's subject to variable accounting. So there's going to be largely based on how the stock performs and a number of other factors.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of MAtt Nemer from wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of MAtt Nemer from wells Fargo.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just piggyback on Craig's question around mobile and web capabilities. Just wondering if you can give us an update on the EasyShop program and what we can expect in terms of future web capabilities over the next year or 2?
componenttext: I wanted to just piggyback on Craig's question around mobile and web capabilities. Just wondering if you can give us an update on the EasyShop program and what we can expect in terms of future web capabilities over the next year or 2?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, so that was -- we originally called that out as a test, and EasyShop was kind of a branded thing within the website. We're really not calling it that anymore. It's now really just expanded capabilities throughout the website and we'll continue
componenttext: Yes, Matt, so that was -- we originally called that out as a test, and EasyShop was kind of a branded thing within the website. We're really not calling it that anymore. It's now really just expanded capabilities throughout the website and we'll continue to test those capabilities when we find something that works, we'll roll it to the whole chain. So the things I mentioned earlier, the ability to transfer a car, the ability to pay for a car, the ability to make an appointment, the ability to put a car on hold remotely, all those things are rolled for the company now, but we stopped branding it. We just realized it worked better, it's just part of the capability of our normal website. I really can't give you what I think the other things would be, the capability that we would add going forward other than we're working really hard to try to make sure that customers can do whatever part of the transaction they want to do from home we want to make sure we give them that capability. So that's kind of where we're focused and we want to improve their experience. We want to make sure we have the best search engine, we want to make sure we have the best touchscreen experience and we want to make sure we have the best mobile experience. And the other thing I would say is we need to hold ourselves to a standard of the experiences that people have in other parts of their lives and not just their experience that they have when they're shopping for a car. So the bar has definitely been raised as it relates to experiences online and experiences with mobile devices, but we're working real hard to stay in front of it.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up, I'm just wondering if you could give us an update on the small store, small-market format.
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up, I'm just wondering if you could give us an update on the small store, small-market format.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think we mentioned we were going to open 5 stores, read the results for some period of time and then evaluate our plan going forward. On our last call, I mentioned that we feel very confident in the way we performed so far. And if you look at ou
componenttext: Yes, so I think we mentioned we were going to open 5 stores, read the results for some period of time and then evaluate our plan going forward. On our last call, I mentioned that we feel very confident in the way we performed so far. And if you look at our growth plans going forward, the 13 to 16 stores over the next few years, embedded in that will be small format stores. So we've identified right now at least 80 markets that meet that criteria and that will be part of our regular growth program going forward. Last month, the store that I mentioned in Gainesville, Florida is getting a little bit of a hybrid. It has a small format front end which means we operate it with the overhead structure that we've created for the small format stores, but we have a full production shop in the back. So we're always going to be working on our formats and try to find out what's the most efficient way to run a store at various volumes. And we have incredible variation and incredible capabilities as a company to be able to go after just about any market now. We can open a market with selling as few as 75 cars a month and we can run stores that sell as many as 1,000 cars a month. So I'm really proud of what we've accomplished in being able to address all kinds of different market sizes.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler of Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: My primary question relates to the wholesale business. Obviously, units will show volatility from time-to-time and the profitability of the wholesale business was terrific. But the unit growth and the ratio of wholesale to units sold was a little bit lowe
componenttext: My primary question relates to the wholesale business. Obviously, units will show volatility from time-to-time and the profitability of the wholesale business was terrific. But the unit growth and the ratio of wholesale to units sold was a little bit lower, then we have seen any insight as to what drove that this quarter and how you're thinking about the wholesale business generally this year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, I talked about this a number of times, I really don't worry about the wholesale business in any given quarter. We think about it over a very long period of time. If you look at it over a long period of time it has essentially grown with unit sales.
componenttext: Matt, I talked about this a number of times, I really don't worry about the wholesale business in any given quarter. We think about it over a very long period of time. If you look at it over a long period of time it has essentially grown with unit sales. We're not worried at all that it grew 5%. I'm glad that it grew 5%. It's a very, very big business for us, it's a profitable business for us, it requires an incredible amount of effort in the stores. You think about every time we open up a new production store and even in a new market, we got to run another business within it. We have to have great customer service, we have to attract dealers to our auctions everyday, and we have to give those, it was a great experience because they have other choices and they can go in other places. So again, it's a big business. It grew 5% in the quarter, not quite where the retail growth was, but you've been following us for a long time. You've seen that number dramatically in the other direction as well sometimes. So we're really thinking about that business over the long haul. And also as you know, that business is now an independent business. It's attached to retail. Almost all the cars sold in wholesale are direct acquisitions from consumers, many of those who are buying cars from us, so we have to make sure that we're competitive. So I was very pleased with the quarter for wholesale.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, and Katharine, hopefully you won't count this follow-up as an actual question, but just the stock comp, you now disclosed 3 or 4 subcategories within SG&A. Is the stock comp number spread amongst all of them or is it focused on compensatio
componenttext: That's helpful, and Katharine, hopefully you won't count this follow-up as an actual question, but just the stock comp, you now disclosed 3 or 4 subcategories within SG&A. Is the stock comp number spread amongst all of them or is it focused on compensation?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's all in compensation, and Matt, one point in that, almost all of the variability in our stock-based competition expenses is non-executive comp, just to make that point.
componenttext: It's all in compensation, and Matt, one point in that, almost all of the variability in our stock-based competition expenses is non-executive comp, just to make that point.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And it seems like, since you offered, seems like on a per vehicle basis, when you exclude the stock comp, the delta was actually quite favorable, pretty well-controlled year on year.
componenttext: And it seems like, since you offered, seems like on a per vehicle basis, when you exclude the stock comp, the delta was actually quite favorable, pretty well-controlled year on year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Exactly. And remember, carrying -- that's what's 16 more stores in the base than there were last year which as you know in the early part of the stores are very SG&A-inefficient until they grow to where we expect them to grow. And with -- we've always sai
componenttext: Exactly. And remember, carrying -- that's what's 16 more stores in the base than there were last year which as you know in the early part of the stores are very SG&A-inefficient until they grow to where we expect them to grow. And with -- we've always said we think we need mid- to high single digits comps to get some leverage there. I was really pleased with the way SG&A ran during the quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Montani of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Montani of Evercore ISI.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask first off, on vehicle demographics if you could share the penetration of your 4 year old vehicles, I think it was 75% last quarter and growing pretty nicely. So could you just update us there on what you're seeing?
componenttext: Just wanted to ask first off, on vehicle demographics if you could share the penetration of your 4 year old vehicles, I think it was 75% last quarter and growing pretty nicely. So could you just update us there on what you're seeing?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, for the quarter it was 76%. You mentioned 75% was in the fourth quarter, and that's on top of 73% the year prior. So I think our pre-recession, that number was 85%. And then coming out of the recession it was 70%. So yes, we've see some shifting back
componenttext: Yes, for the quarter it was 76%. You mentioned 75% was in the fourth quarter, and that's on top of 73% the year prior. So I think our pre-recession, that number was 85%. And then coming out of the recession it was 70%. So yes, we've see some shifting back towards we've been expecting this with the shifting in supply, with the change in the SAAR. But from quarter-to-quarter, it was relatively flat from the fourth quarter to this quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to follow-up on that if I could, you mentioned that the buy rate was a little bit lower this quarter. Can you just share with us kind of what's going on to drive that? Is there anything from a pricing dynamic that's impacting you in any way there
componenttext: And just to follow-up on that if I could, you mentioned that the buy rate was a little bit lower this quarter. Can you just share with us kind of what's going on to drive that? Is there anything from a pricing dynamic that's impacting you in any way there? And also what the penetration is of retail used units that were from the appraisal wins this quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was still a very good number, we are buying around 30%, that's pretty good for us. Modest fluctuations in the buy rate, we called it out only because it was there, but it's not something that I really can add any color to because I don't think the
componenttext: Yes, it was still a very good number, we are buying around 30%, that's pretty good for us. Modest fluctuations in the buy rate, we called it out only because it was there, but it's not something that I really can add any color to because I don't think there's much to it.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Marty of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Marty of Bank of America.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Lyn Suzukin on for John. With the loan charge-off rates running lower-than-expected, do you think CAF would be comfortable taking on a little more risk and expanding that subprime test even further?
componenttext: This is actually Lyn Suzukin on for John. With the loan charge-off rates running lower-than-expected, do you think CAF would be comfortable taking on a little more risk and expanding that subprime test even further?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the 2 are actually unrelated. We're looking at the subprime test as a almost as a different line of business, it's a different pool of credit. And as we've talked about before, we're constantly testing within our core CAF business, different pocke
componenttext: I think the 2 are actually unrelated. We're looking at the subprime test as a almost as a different line of business, it's a different pool of credit. And as we've talked about before, we're constantly testing within our core CAF business, different pockets of credit, both pricing and what we'll approve on an ongoing basis. And to the extent it makes sense, by keep a lot of the profile intact and then we roll those things out. As far as of the current environment having an impact on that, these are anywhere from 5 to 6 year loans. And I think the results in any one quarter, a couple of quarters, aren't going to -- are no reason to go out and swing your credit policy for what you're going to be collecting in 5 years.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: It makes sense. What do you attribute those lower loss rates to this quarter?
componenttext: It makes sense. What do you attribute those lower loss rates to this quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: The losses are really a combination of how many people are going bad and how well we're doing recovering [indiscernible] that have gone bad. And we had some success in doing a little bit better on the recovery side, but the vast majority of what we're see
componenttext: The losses are really a combination of how many people are going bad and how well we're doing recovering [indiscernible] that have gone bad. And we had some success in doing a little bit better on the recovery side, but the vast majority of what we're seeing in loss performance is just that fewer people are going bad, and I think that's not inconsistent with what's going on in the lending industry in general right now, at least with the higher credit levels.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Aram Rubinson of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Aram Rubinson of Wolfe Research.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Chris on for Aram. I got a question on the direct operating expenses on CAF. You did a very nice job of managing it over time. It seemed to swell a little bit in Q4, we're now in Q1 it came back down a percentage of AR. What do you think
componenttext: This is actually Chris on for Aram. I got a question on the direct operating expenses on CAF. You did a very nice job of managing it over time. It seemed to swell a little bit in Q4, we're now in Q1 it came back down a percentage of AR. What do you think about how you manage that over time as you tended to grow your book? And two, if the subprime test proves successful, what does that mean if you're direct expenses in CAF?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: We try to manage those expenses over time as efficiently as we can. Unfortunately, it's not only our activity that impact that. So if you think about what's entailed in the finance business, there's a lot of activity contacting customers. If you're in an
componenttext: We try to manage those expenses over time as efficiently as we can. Unfortunately, it's not only our activity that impact that. So if you think about what's entailed in the finance business, there's a lot of activity contacting customers. If you're in an environment where people are less delinquent and there's fewer losses, there's still people not paying which we are today, that means we're making less calls, probably we need less resource to do that. If the world changes, we need to pay more attention and be making more calls, that would have an impact on your cost. I think the team down at CAF has done a great job of getting more efficient in both those types of environments and will try to continue to do so. And as far as Tier 3, as we roll that out to the extent we roll that out, you would expect it would be a more high touch business and it would have some impact on CAF's overhead cost, but we're not at a point where we can forecast that for you.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton from KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Irina up for Brett Hoselton. Quick question for you guys on the used vehicle sourcing. We've been expecting an acceleration in off lease supply to drive that supply of zero to 4 year old car inventory. And what I'm saying is on the industry report
componenttext: This is Irina up for Brett Hoselton. Quick question for you guys on the used vehicle sourcing. We've been expecting an acceleration in off lease supply to drive that supply of zero to 4 year old car inventory. And what I'm saying is on the industry reports, from the certified vehicle sales we're seeing double-digit increase through March, 11% up, and your increase is substantially below that. And I'm wondering if you're not getting those cars yet or if there's some sort of a bottleneck in inventory supply, or any commentary you can give us on what you're seeing in terms of zero to 4 year old vehicle supply coming in.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: You can't just look at CPO by itself you have to look at the total comps for the industry. If you look at the average of all the publicly traded new car dealers, used comps during the first quarter were at 5%, so about in line with where we were. Within t
componenttext: You can't just look at CPO by itself you have to look at the total comps for the industry. If you look at the average of all the publicly traded new car dealers, used comps during the first quarter were at 5%, so about in line with where we were. Within that is where you see the growth in CPOs. So there is a distinction there that you have to make. Lease percentage right now I think in the new car industry, it's somewhere around 30% and when you see that supply coming back it is really 2 or 3 years later after you see a high lease percentage. So I'm not sure that we've seen much of it yet, but it's never been a problem for us to source cars. And when cars are at a high lease percentage, when you look out 2 and 3 years later, generally, they're more organized at the auction, so it's a little easier for us actually to buy those cars when we see them come back to the marketplace. But we really haven't seen lease percentage change our ability to source cars over time, and we've been at this for over 20 years. So we actually think it's not a bad thing at all that there's a higher percentage of leases right now and over the next 2 or 3 years, that will give us more access to those cars.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong of CL King and Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong of CL King and Associates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your weighted average contract rate for CAF was 7.4 versus 7.2 a year ago. Was there a mix going on there or are you seeing overall interest rates that you're getting some consumers starting to go up?
componenttext: Your weighted average contract rate for CAF was 7.4 versus 7.2 a year ago. Was there a mix going on there or are you seeing overall interest rates that you're getting some consumers starting to go up?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't really read too much into for that much of a lift, but as I said, we've been in environments where rates are going down. We all want to make sure we're staying with the market in environments where we see rates going up, we want to be testing a
componenttext: I wouldn't really read too much into for that much of a lift, but as I said, we've been in environments where rates are going down. We all want to make sure we're staying with the market in environments where we see rates going up, we want to be testing as well. So we have been doing some test with increased rates in certain pockets, but like I said, I wouldn't read much in the difference in weighted average contract, it's pretty consistent.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Remember too that we are very market-driven with a 3-day guarantee for our customers to go get a better loan somewhere else and we unwind it free of cost. So that is kind of a check and balance on how much rate we can actually get out of our consumers. Bu
componenttext: Remember too that we are very market-driven with a 3-day guarantee for our customers to go get a better loan somewhere else and we unwind it free of cost. So that is kind of a check and balance on how much rate we can actually get out of our consumers. But we think it's a huge competitive advantage that not only CarMax Auto Finance but all our other lenders as well, provide customers that opportunity to go get a better deal somewhere else if they like in the first 3 business days and get out of it at no cost whatsoever. So it's a good check and balance, but it's a great offering for the consumer.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, understood. And then just as a quick follow-up, could you tell us what your originations were for the quarter for your CAF subprime test?
componenttext: Right, understood. And then just as a quick follow-up, could you tell us what your originations were for the quarter for your CAF subprime test?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: It was about $15 million, as we talked about it end of last year, we're comfortable continuing at that pace of about 5% of the Tier 3 originations. I think we're just under $90 million in total originations to date now.
componenttext: It was about $15 million, as we talked about it end of last year, we're comfortable continuing at that pace of about 5% of the Tier 3 originations. I think we're just under $90 million in total originations to date now.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Levin of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Levin of Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to kind of follow-up on CAF, we've been expecting to see the collateral spreads kind of tighten gradually over time, but the last 3 quarters have been kind of holding steady at about 6.3%. Does this kind of feel like a near-term equilibrium that you
componenttext: Just to kind of follow-up on CAF, we've been expecting to see the collateral spreads kind of tighten gradually over time, but the last 3 quarters have been kind of holding steady at about 6.3%. Does this kind of feel like a near-term equilibrium that you guys are seeing, or would expect to see some contraction as we kind of move forward and as that moves rates?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you hit the nail in the head. It's going to depend on what goes on with the rates. As we've talked about before, our ability to manage that spread is very much market-driven, and to the extent we see cost of funds going up because the benchmarks a
componenttext: I think you hit the nail in the head. It's going to depend on what goes on with the rates. As we've talked about before, our ability to manage that spread is very much market-driven, and to the extent we see cost of funds going up because the benchmarks are moving up, we'll clearly test and see what we can manage that spread to, but it's going to be driven by what the market will bear, what our competitors are doing and what makes sense for the customer. So it's very hard to speculate. But I mean, we have seen spread compression if you look year-over-year, we just managed to outgrow that from an income perspective with growth in the portfolio overall, larger originations in those prior years and some favorable loss performance in recent quarters.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of BRIC Nelson from Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of BRIC Nelson from Stephens.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: CFPB is now overseas the large non bank auto finance provider bank account under the loan jurisdiction, is there any change required from your operating -- from adopting standpoint or cost standpoint that you've got those [indiscernible]?
componenttext: CFPB is now overseas the large non bank auto finance provider bank account under the loan jurisdiction, is there any change required from your operating -- from adopting standpoint or cost standpoint that you've got those [indiscernible]?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the short answer is yes, we do expect there to be greater cost in administration. Now the flip side of that is the announcement last week didn't tell us anything new from what we've been planning for, for quite some time. As we've expected al
componenttext: Yes, I think the short answer is yes, we do expect there to be greater cost in administration. Now the flip side of that is the announcement last week didn't tell us anything new from what we've been planning for, for quite some time. As we've expected all along, capital would be subject to the bureau's supervisory authority as a larger participant. The definition of larger participant isn't really that large, it's about 10,000 loans a year in origination. So a vast majority of auto lenders are subject to it. But I think what it means for us is we're going to continue, as we have been, to refine our compliance program and meet the bureau's expectation. We're keeping attention to industry developments and looking at our practices, every time we learn more about what the Bureau is interested in, making sure that we do our best to comply with what they think they want to see. In answer to your question, there's going to be some administrative costs around that, just like we expect with the Dodd-Frank [indiscernible] B2 with the extended reporting requirements, it will be a cost of doing business. And we'll let you know what it is, material when the time comes.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham of Wedbush.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham of Wedbush.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question's around conversion, Tom, you mentioned in terms of conversion helping comps but how this level of improvement compared to recent quarters?
componenttext: My question's around conversion, Tom, you mentioned in terms of conversion helping comps but how this level of improvement compared to recent quarters?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's another one that's pretty volatile over time, and I still think of it as we have to look at a very much longer period of time. And I always felt that over time, we would get our comp sales improvement from a combination of traffic and conversion. S
componenttext: That's another one that's pretty volatile over time, and I still think of it as we have to look at a very much longer period of time. And I always felt that over time, we would get our comp sales improvement from a combination of traffic and conversion. So there have been quarters where conversion has outpaced traffic and there were quarters where traffic has outpaced conversion. In this particular quarter, we said it was divided between the 2 to deliver the 5% comp, but there's volatility in both of those things and I expect it to be volatile going forward. But I think over a long period of time I expect to get improvements out of both. So I'm not sure that really answers your question, but I can tell you we've had quarters where conversion improvement has been higher this quarter, but we've had some quarters where we've been flat or behind as well. So it's really you have to look at it over a much longer period of time, I don't think one quarter is a good proxy for the long-term although in this quarter, we have a little from both.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up, maybe is there anything you could point to in terms of the trends in conversion rates in certain sectors, like your customer population, whether it be credit tiers or otherwise, and whether or not inventory levels are affecting conversio
componenttext: Just a follow-up, maybe is there anything you could point to in terms of the trends in conversion rates in certain sectors, like your customer population, whether it be credit tiers or otherwise, and whether or not inventory levels are affecting conversion, those type of things?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a really good question. We spend a lot of time trying to figure that out and we don't have a lot of success. So I'd say it comes from all kinds of different areas. There's an argument that people are more prepared when they show up in the store bec
componenttext: That's a really good question. We spend a lot of time trying to figure that out and we don't have a lot of success. So I'd say it comes from all kinds of different areas. There's an argument that people are more prepared when they show up in the store because they spend more time in the website. There's an argument for more inventory for selection for the customer. You can clearly see impacts from movements in credit. That impact conversion as well. We have extensive training programs going on in our stores in all areas of the company, which I think helped conversion, of course. We can buy cars a little bit better, have the right selection in individual  stores even without having more cars. So we always say around here, conversions is a very big word and it includes lots of things. So I really can't attribute specific points to any one of them.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Whiston of Morningstar.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Whiston of Morningstar.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: More of a strategic question for you, we're in a rather robust part of the economic cycle. I'm sure you're always optimistic about all phases of the company, but in particular given where we are on the cycle, what parts of your business do you think you'r
componenttext: More of a strategic question for you, we're in a rather robust part of the economic cycle. I'm sure you're always optimistic about all phases of the company, but in particular given where we are on the cycle, what parts of your business do you think you're most excited about over the next 12 months?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: As you said, we're excited about all parts of our business. I think for me it's 2 things, it's the ability to continue -- continuously improve our existing store base, which has gotten quite large, and then our ability to enter new markets successfully, w
componenttext: As you said, we're excited about all parts of our business. I think for me it's 2 things, it's the ability to continue -- continuously improve our existing store base, which has gotten quite large, and then our ability to enter new markets successfully, whether they're small markets or medium-sized markets or metro markets. And then to be able to deliver a consumer offer that has all kinds of advantages against the competition that allow us to continue to succeed. So I'm really excited about the core business. In the last several months, I visited lots of our stores that have been around for 15 or 20 years. Some are hitting all-time highs in sales and then I've been to some of our new brand openings, and I'm always -- it always gets me excited to see how engaged people are to come and work for  CarMax and deliver a great consumer offer. So again, for me, it's continuing to grow the existing stores and being able to go after new markets as well.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then just one other question, it's been tax refund time recently. I'm just curious did you see meaningful uptake in business versus tax refund seasons or was it a little bit down or flat?
componenttext: That's helpful. And then just one other question, it's been tax refund time recently. I'm just curious did you see meaningful uptake in business versus tax refund seasons or was it a little bit down or flat?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're really well passed tax refund season now, for us, that's January, February, March timeframe. And over the last couple of years, we've seen some volatility around timing from just tax refund in general. But whatever you would have seen from tax refun
componenttext: We're really well passed tax refund season now, for us, that's January, February, March timeframe. And over the last couple of years, we've seen some volatility around timing from just tax refund in general. But whatever you would have seen from tax refunds, you would have already seen in our business through the fourth quarter and then now that the first quarter's over. So it's always a big time of the year for us, particularly coming out of the winter, and we had a big year this year as well.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of the average gain of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of the average gain of Morgan Stanley.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the question on millennials and tech, CarMax has always led with technology and trends in this business, but there is some serious money being spent by these peer-to-peer business models and getting a lot of traction millennials as we
componenttext: Just following up on the question on millennials and tech, CarMax has always led with technology and trends in this business, but there is some serious money being spent by these peer-to-peer business models and getting a lot of traction millennials as well. We've talked about this earlier and you said you're keeping a close eye on these models and while you may not see them as direct competitors, is that an opportunity [indiscernible] or is that something you can pursue in your future and if so, how quickly can you do that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, and I have the same answer as before. We're keeping a close eye on it, and we'll decide if that's something we need to go after. As of this moment, we're not heading down the peer-to-peer path, but if you really think about the way
componenttext: That's a good question, and I have the same answer as before. We're keeping a close eye on it, and we'll decide if that's something we need to go after. As of this moment, we're not heading down the peer-to-peer path, but if you really think about the way CarMax works, the fact that we make a cash offer on every car is enabling a lot of peer-to-peer transactions. And some of those are coming through us that would have otherwise gone peer-to-peer. So a customer would normally put their car online and before -- or put it up in their yard and put a for sale sign on. Now they're bringing a lot of those customers are bringing their cars directly to us and selling it to us. So it may not be exactly the way you're thinking about it, but I think we're getting plenty of customers who would have gone through that peer-to-peer channel and are deciding to sell their car directly to CarMax.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up, would you allow an acquisition of that kind in this space, or would you do it organically?
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up, would you allow an acquisition of that kind in this space, or would you do it organically?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're evaluating all different options and we're open to any way that makes our business better and delivers a better return for our shareholders.
componenttext: We're evaluating all different options and we're open to any way that makes our business better and delivers a better return for our shareholders.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from the line of Stifel.
componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Stifel.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping it I apologize if I missed the prepared remarks, there's another question [indiscernible] but hoping to get an update on the vehicle transfer activity, so the propensity for consumers to order a vehicle from outside their home and have it shi
componenttext: I was hoping it I apologize if I missed the prepared remarks, there's another question [indiscernible] but hoping to get an update on the vehicle transfer activity, so the propensity for consumers to order a vehicle from outside their home and have it shipped to their closest store and then as a follow-up, any insight you could provide near-term on sort of retail activity, particularly given some of the storms and flooding that we've been hearing in the Texas and the southern region?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the first question, that number has been around 30% for quite a long time now. But that's a big number. We sold 600,000 cars last year which means we transferred roughly 200,000 cars at the customer's request to the store nearest them and then sold
componenttext: So on the first question, that number has been around 30% for quite a long time now. But that's a big number. We sold 600,000 cars last year which means we transferred roughly 200,000 cars at the customer's request to the store nearest them and then sold the car. So we're transferring as many cars or more than anybody else at the customer's request. When they see a great presentation of that car through our website, with 40 high-definition pictures and zoom capability, I think we'll continue to make progress there. But the number has been relatively flat, but again it's a very, very big number. In terms of our regional differences, we never comment on regional differences. The only thing I'd tell you is I continue to be very proud of our CarMax team wherever we have a disaster in any area that involves large-scale loss of products, we are able to be there for the consumer when they are ready to buy something else. And we also are a place where people could get rid of their cars, whether they -- if a car has flood damage or hail damage, we still make an offer on the car, we wholesale that car. We won't retail one of those cars, but we still are there for the consumer when they need us in markets that have some trouble. But I can't really comment on any difference to the performance.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 19, 2015

componenttext: I will now turn the call back over to the speakers. So Mark.

componenttext: Okay, well, being there is no further question I want to thank everybody for your interest in CarMax and for joining us on our call today. And I especially want to thank our over 22,000 CarMax associates nationwide for all you do everyday to make CarMax such a success, and we'll talk to you guys next quarter. Thank you.
