componenttext: Good morning. My name is Tanisha and will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q2 FY 2016 conference call. [Operator Instructions] Ms. Katharine Kenny, you may begin your conference.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone. On the call with me today for our second quarter fiscal 2016 earnings conference call are Tom Folliard, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO. Before we begin, let
componenttext: Thank you, and good morning, everyone. On the call with me today for our second quarter fiscal 2016 earnings conference call are Tom Folliard, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO. Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them. For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 28, 2015 filed with the SEC. [Operator Instructions] Thanks. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. As you saw, we had a record second quarter due to the continued growth in our store base and solid performances in used and wholesale unit sales, as well as CarMax Auto Finan
componenttext: Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. As you saw, we had a record second quarter due to the continued growth in our store base and solid performances in used and wholesale unit sales, as well as CarMax Auto Finance. Here are some of the key highlights for the quarter. Used unit comps increased by 4.6% and total used units rose by 9.2%. Gross profit per unit was flat at $2,166 compared to $2,173 in the second quarter of last year. Total wholesale units grew by 8.7%, partially driven by one more auction date in the quarter compared to last year. Without the additional day of auctions, wholesale units would have grown about 5%. Gross profit for our wholesale unit of $951 grew nearly 9% compared to $874 in the second quarter of last year and CAF income grew 6% to approximately $98 million, and I'll turn it over to Tom to give us some more details on finance. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. As Tom mentioned, CAF income grew 6.2% compared to the second quarter of fiscal 2015, and average managed receivables grew by 16% to $9 billion or just under $9 billion. The weighted average contract rate, the rate ch
componenttext: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. As Tom mentioned, CAF income grew 6.2% compared to the second quarter of fiscal 2015, and average managed receivables grew by 16% to $9 billion or just under $9 billion. The weighted average contract rate, the rate charged to customers, was up -- was 7.2%, up slightly from last year's second quarter at 7.0%. Our allowance for loan losses grew about -- to about $88 million or 0.96% of managed receivables. CAF net penetration was 42.7%, 0.5 point of which came from loans originated under our sub-prime test. That compares with 40.7% in last year's second quarter, of which 0.6% related to loans originated under that test. Net loan dollars originated in the quarter rose 14% to $1.3 billion due to combination of CarMax unit sales growth and higher penetration in CAF. Finally, during the second quarter, we repurchased 3.9 million shares for about $250 million.  Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This quarter, our comp unit sales were driven by improved conversion achieved by our store teams. Our total web traffic increased nearly 12% compared to the same period last year, and now approximately 65% of our visits are coming from somethin
componenttext:
Thank you. This quarter, our comp unit sales were driven by improved conversion achieved by our store teams. Our total web traffic increased nearly 12% compared to the same period last year, and now approximately 65% of our visits are coming from something other than a laptop or a desktop. As for our sales mix this quarter, 0 to 4 year old vehicles increased by 5% to 79% of our total sales, and SUVs and trucks were down slightly from 24% to 22% compared to last year's second quarter. For SG&A, excluding the $21 million reduction in the last second quarter's SG&A, due to the receipt of legal settlement proceeds, SG&A for this second quarter increased approximately 4% to $331 million. Contributing to this growth was the addition of 16 stores since the beginning of second quarter last year, partially offset by a decrease of $10.5 million in share-based compensation expense. On a per-unit basis, excluding the settlement gain, SG&A decreased $100 to $2,083. The stock-based compensation expense decrease accounted for 78 of that leverage. 
During the second quarter, we opened 4 stores, 3 in existing markets, 1 in Providence and 2 in Denver and a small format store in Tallahassee, which is a new market for CarMax. After the second quarter ended, we opened 2 more stores, our sixth store in the Houston market and our second store in Minneapolis. And we also relocated our Rockville, Maryland store to its new larger location in Gaithersburg. Also, during the quarter, we notified Nissan that we would be terminating our new car franchise at White Marsh, which is just outside Baltimore, and our Chrysler -- and we notified Chrysler that we would be terminating our new car franchise at our Norcross store in Atlanta. Both terminations will become effective in the third quarter. 
And with that, we'd be happy to take your questions. Operator?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Brian Nagel of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Brian Nagel of Oppenheimer.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So my question, I want to focus on the used car unit comp. So if I look at the number, that might be the 4.6% you put was very respectable given what we've seen elsewhere from other dealers or even other retailers. But Tom, as you look at the data, and ma
componenttext: So my question, I want to focus on the used car unit comp. So if I look at the number, that might be the 4.6% you put was very respectable given what we've seen elsewhere from other dealers or even other retailers. But Tom, as you look at the data, and maybe take a step back from the data, you had a 4.6% here in Q2, a 4.9% in Q1, and it was only a few quarters before that used car units unit comps were tracking upwards in the upper single digits. Is there something to explain as you look at that? There's some -- there's kind of downshift we've seen in the trend there.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, I don't know that there's something to explain. We have very big stores, average volume of 320 cars a month. I'm very pleased with the 4.6% comp in one of our -- the first and second quarter are 2 highest volume quarters of the year. At the same ti
componenttext: Brian, I don't know that there's something to explain. We have very big stores, average volume of 320 cars a month. I'm very pleased with the 4.6% comp in one of our -- the first and second quarter are 2 highest volume quarters of the year. At the same time, we're building stores, continuing to refine our model, continuing to develop our website and our apps so our customers have a better experience. And our store teams continue to execute very, very well. So I don't spend too much time -- we don't spend too much time trying to analyze a couple of point here or there in the quarter when you're building a business over a very long period of time. So we're very pleased with the performance of the business in the quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. If I could just follow-up on that. I mean, as we think about, you've parsed -- already answered this, but as we think about the third and fourth quarters, where the comparisons lease on a single year basis get more difficult, is that something tha
componenttext: Got it. If I could just follow-up on that. I mean, as we think about, you've parsed -- already answered this, but as we think about the third and fourth quarters, where the comparisons lease on a single year basis get more difficult, is that something that you manage around in any way?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: As you know, we don't give any guidance, any forward-looking guidance, but I will tell you that when we look at the business each year and over a long period of time, a lot of our training analysis is going to take into account whatever the factors were i
componenttext: As you know, we don't give any guidance, any forward-looking guidance, but I will tell you that when we look at the business each year and over a long period of time, a lot of our training analysis is going to take into account whatever the factors were in the years prior. So it matters what the comps were the year before, but it only matters in our forecasting at the beginning of the year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Nemer of Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Nemer of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just to follow up on Brian's question, I'm just curious if the later Labor Day holiday this year potentially impacted the result. I would assume, it looked like August was a bit of a tougher month from a unit standpoint for the auto industry and that s
componenttext: So just to follow up on Brian's question, I'm just curious if the later Labor Day holiday this year potentially impacted the result. I would assume, it looked like August was a bit of a tougher month from a unit standpoint for the auto industry and that some of the sales had shifted to September.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's possible, but we don't really look at it. I mean, we don't really think of it in that level of detail. To me, Labor Day, it was in the third quarter last year, and it's in the third quarter this year. So the only real difference would be the Saturday
componenttext: It's possible, but we don't really look at it. I mean, we don't really think of it in that level of detail. To me, Labor Day, it was in the third quarter last year, and it's in the third quarter this year. So the only real difference would be the Saturday and Sunday of Labor Day compared to the year prior. So it might meant something in there, but we don't really consider -- I mean, we didn't consider it to be any factor in the quarter. We maybe would have called it out.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. And then just as a follow-up, your advertising expense was up about 18% year-over-year and combined with the recent NFL affiliations, I'm just wondering if this signals a change in strategy, and perhaps, we could see some higher ad expe
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. And then just as a follow-up, your advertising expense was up about 18% year-over-year and combined with the recent NFL affiliations, I'm just wondering if this signals a change in strategy, and perhaps, we could see some higher ad expense per vehicle on a go-forward basis?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our sales are up a little over 9%, and so if we had just flat advertising per car, the expense would have been up 9%. It was up 18%. A good portion of the difference between those 2 is we actually had ad production during the quarter, and we did not have
componenttext: Our sales are up a little over 9%, and so if we had just flat advertising per car, the expense would have been up 9%. It was up 18%. A good portion of the difference between those 2 is we actually had ad production during the quarter, and we did not have ad production during the quarter last year, and that's a big chunk of it. Another big chunk of it is we've outsourced our media buying, so some of those dollars have just moved from 1 bucket to the other, where we used to have that in -- not in SG&A, but in corporate overhead. So there's really not much to read into in terms of this quarter. In terms of the affiliations with sports games, we have gotten bigger. We are entering some big metro markets, but none of that expense would have really shown up in the second quarter because they're only starting now. We have a big launch in Denver. As you know, we have 2 stores that we had prior to this year. We added 2 more. We have a fifth store in Colorado Springs. That's a big market for us. In terms of New England and the Boston market, we have 2 stores in the Hartford market. We have 2 stores in the Providence, Rhode Island market. In December of this year, we'll launch Boston officially, and we'll have 3 stores: 1 in Danvers, 1 in Norwood, and 1 in West Borough. We're continuing to look at sites. We own a site in Portland, Maine. We're looking in Manchester and Nashua, New Hampshire. So when we think about New England as a broad market, we have a huge investment coming there over the next several years. And as you know, Matt, Boston's a little bit of a sports town, and you really have to try and connect with your customer base. And I think that affiliating yourself with at least one of the sports teams is something you need to do. And then we also just announced a partnership with University of Minnesota, as we're opening up the Minneapolis market, where we opened up our second store there. So we've done some sports marketing in the past. I think this got a little bit more press because it was a little bit more bigger, but as a company, we've gotten a lot bigger too.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sounds good. Looks like based on your store openings, that the -- either the Raiders or the 49ers are going to be next.
componenttext: Sounds good. Looks like based on your store openings, that the -- either the Raiders or the 49ers are going to be next.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the Raiders beat the Ravens, so maybe they're not as bad as everyone thinks.
componenttext: Well, the Raiders beat the Ravens, so maybe they're not as bad as everyone thinks.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Aram Rubinson of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Aram Rubinson of Wolfe Research.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little bit of the lay of the land of new competitors as you see it? And also kind of where you sit and handicap yourself on your own e-commerce capabilities, your Internet site? What, again, are the capabilities that you believe you've g
componenttext: Can you give us a little bit of the lay of the land of new competitors as you see it? And also kind of where you sit and handicap yourself on your own e-commerce capabilities, your Internet site? What, again, are the capabilities that you believe you've got that are virtuous to you and what capabilities do you really need to still work on? And how do you think -- and when do you think you're going to start attacking some of those?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I don't know that we have anything that's just virtuous to us where nobody else can do it. It's a big market, and what we're trying to do is make sure our customers can do as much of the transaction as they want to do from home, and we've definitely se
componenttext: So I don't know that we have anything that's just virtuous to us where nobody else can do it. It's a big market, and what we're trying to do is make sure our customers can do as much of the transaction as they want to do from home, and we've definitely seen the sentiment shift, where customers are looking to do more and more research, more and more pieces of the transaction from home, and in some cases, the entire transaction from home. Our current capabilities are our customer can, obviously, do all kinds of inventory searches. We have 50,000 cars online. I think that's the huge competitive advantage for us is the selection of inventory and the ability to transfer cars at the customer's request. And as you know, Aram, that's about 1/3 of our total sales. We also give the customer the ability to put a car on hold. We give the customer the ability to transfer a car. If it's a paid transfer, they can do it with a credit card without speaking to anybody, and have that car transferred to the store of their choice. They can fill out a big chunk of the paperwork from home. We have tested online credit applications, and we are continuing to enhance our capabilities there. We've seen some startups and some smaller competitors that are doing kind of beginning to end transactions online. I don't think anybody's in a better position than we are to be able to do those things, and those are some of the things that we'll continue to work on and continue to evaluate as our business grows. But I think we have a bunch of significant competitive advantage. The one I mentioned, which I think is the most significant, is the selection of inventory that we have and the ability to transfer it. As a company last year, we moved 2 million cars. We sold 600,000, but cars moving from store to store, moving from auction to store, we moved over 2 million cars. We have a very extensive network of -- and ability to move cars very quickly at the customer's request, but I think we need to keep working on our app. We need to keep working on our capabilities, and we need to make sure we stay out in front of the consumer, and give them the capability to do what they want to do from home.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia of William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia of William Blair.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 2 questions, I guess. Tom, there are a lot of investors that -- soon to be concerned about off-lease vehicles and what's going to happen there, and that this time might be different than prior years, where there are a lot of off-lease vehicles. Can you
componenttext: So 2 questions, I guess. Tom, there are a lot of investors that -- soon to be concerned about off-lease vehicles and what's going to happen there, and that this time might be different than prior years, where there are a lot of off-lease vehicles. Can you kind of give us your perspective on how CarMax has done in years where there have been a lot of off-lease vehicles coming up and whether or not your ability to procure those vehicles are -- is any different than it would have been, say, 10, years ago?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Sharon. I don't remember exactly because remember that the supply comes back 2, 3 years after the lease rate is at whatever it is. Right now, it's pretty high. I think it's in the high-20s as a percent of new car sales. I've always
componenttext: That's a good question, Sharon. I don't remember exactly because remember that the supply comes back 2, 3 years after the lease rate is at whatever it is. Right now, it's pretty high. I think it's in the high-20s as a percent of new car sales. I've always said before, cars tend to come back, whether they are leased or sold, not totally predictable, but at a somewhat predictable rate, as the years roll forward. Lease -- when it's a very high lease percentage, it's kind of more predictable. So if there's a bunch of leases going out now, if it's almost 30% of new car sales, 2 years out, 3 years out, we're going to see a lot of leases coming back. They tend to be a lot more organized at the auction, maybe even a little bit easier for us to have access to. In terms of our capabilities, we are much more organized today than we were 10 years ago. We're much more analytical about the way we approach car buying at the auction, and I think we're in a better position today to optimize the inventory that we acquire at the auction because of all the analytics that we've put into it, and all the digital capabilities that we've given our buyers. Our buyers are now all using tablets at the auctions. We're tracking every single car that a buyer at CarMax looks at, at the auction, and deciding whether or not that car's worthy. And then the next time a buyer goes to the auction, they don't have to look at that same car and we're saving enormous amount of time in evaluating cars at the auction. We have all the auctions on a program where the CarMax buyers are buying under one kind of generic card, and we can analytically decide where those cars go later. If you back up 10 or 15 years, we used to buy on a store-by-store basis. So I'm really pleased with the progress we've made and our ability to analyze and purchase inventory, and then I think -- I really do think that leasing provides a more organized way because you'll see a lot of the big leasing companies will run hundreds and hundreds of cars a week on a very regular basis at the auction, and it's pretty predictable, and we have the ability to look at that inventory in advance, and decide which ones we are or are not going to bid on.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then a question for the other Tom, obviously, the leverage on SG&A this quarter was largely related to the share-based comp decline. Can you talk about in the back half of the year what kind of comp you need to hold your SG&A?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then a question for the other Tom, obviously, the leverage on SG&A this quarter was largely related to the share-based comp decline. Can you talk about in the back half of the year what kind of comp you need to hold your SG&A?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we've talked about in the past, Sharon, is we -- kind of mid-single digit comp for -- to get at SG&A leverage. If you look at this quarter, I think we levered about $23, as you back out the stock-based comp. There's some timing going on there, so
componenttext: I think we've talked about in the past, Sharon, is we -- kind of mid-single digit comp for -- to get at SG&A leverage. If you look at this quarter, I think we levered about $23, as you back out the stock-based comp. There's some timing going on there, so I feel like, as the comps were up this quarter, we are right at the inflection point or thereabouts. When I say some timing, I think there's favorability in prior years that I wouldn't give a huge amount of credit for leveraging this quarter. So we're still in growth mode. I think we're still in the state of mind that we need comps above this or a little north of it to get meaningful leverage.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison of Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison of Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a regulatory question. I'm curious if the government were to pass some law requiring CarMax to fix recalls, would you be able to seek reimbursement from the OEM in the same way that a franchise dealer would?
componenttext: It's a regulatory question. I'm curious if the government were to pass some law requiring CarMax to fix recalls, would you be able to seek reimbursement from the OEM in the same way that a franchise dealer would?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The way we would do it is the cars would go to the franchise dealer and the franchise dealer would fix them under warranty, and then it would get reimbursed for it, and we would go back and get the car. We are not authorized to do repairs of any kind that
componenttext: The way we would do it is the cars would go to the franchise dealer and the franchise dealer would fix them under warranty, and then it would get reimbursed for it, and we would go back and get the car. We are not authorized to do repairs of any kind that run through the warranty system, and that's the category that recalls under. So for us, it would be -- we would have to take the car to a franchise dealer where it would be repaired. They would get reimbursed. We will get the car back, but it will be at no cost to us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, and then just following up on that, Volkswagen has a big recall they've announced. What's your exposure overall to Volkswagen vehicles?
componenttext: Got it, and then just following up on that, Volkswagen has a big recall they've announced. What's your exposure overall to Volkswagen vehicles?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The Volkswagen, which just came out, so we're really still just evaluating it. It only relates to diesel product. We have about -- I mentioned earlier, we have about 50,000 cars online. We have only a couple of hundred diesel product Volkswagen or Audis,
componenttext: The Volkswagen, which just came out, so we're really still just evaluating it. It only relates to diesel product. We have about -- I mentioned earlier, we have about 50,000 cars online. We have only a couple of hundred diesel product Volkswagen or Audis, so very, very small.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, you talked about or highlighted that conversion rates drove the comp. Does that imply that traffic did not contribute to the comp this quarter?
componenttext: Tom, you talked about or highlighted that conversion rates drove the comp. Does that imply that traffic did not contribute to the comp this quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It does, and as I said before, Scot, I never focus on one quarter's traffic or conversion. I always feel like, and it has been true over a very long period of time, I feel like our comps will be driven roughly half and half by traffic increases and conver
componenttext: It does, and as I said before, Scot, I never focus on one quarter's traffic or conversion. I always feel like, and it has been true over a very long period of time, I feel like our comps will be driven roughly half and half by traffic increases and conversion increases over time, and that has been true for a very long period of time. I think it will be true going forward. So in any given quarter, and it has happened in the past, our comps could be driven by just traffic increases and no conversion increases or vice versa. This is a quarter where our store teams did a great job of converting the customers that they had in addition to constantly optimizing our finance offer and all the other things that go into conversion, buying the right product, having it at the right store and at the right time, and that's what delivered our comps this quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know you guys don't typically give a lot of detail regarding kind of trends during the quarter, but in taking a look at geography, did you see anything noticeable? I mean, obviously, you have a lot of exposure in Texas, for instance, which is starting t
componenttext: I know you guys don't typically give a lot of detail regarding kind of trends during the quarter, but in taking a look at geography, did you see anything noticeable? I mean, obviously, you have a lot of exposure in Texas, for instance, which is starting to have maybe some issues in certain areas just because of all the energy-related exposure there.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're right at the beginning, Scot. We don't give any guidance or trending during the quarter or market-specific data.
componenttext: Yes, you're right at the beginning, Scot. We don't give any guidance or trending during the quarter or market-specific data.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You can't blame a guy for trying. Last question is...
componenttext: You can't blame a guy for trying. Last question is...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's probably the eighth or ninth time you've asked in 10 years so...
componenttext: It's probably the eighth or ninth time you've asked in 10 years so...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know. Keep trying, right? Is there anything you could put your finger on that drove the gross profit dollars per unit on the wholesale side? I mean, it was a pretty big spike, and I know there are is some natural volatility to that category, but I was j
componenttext: I know. Keep trying, right? Is there anything you could put your finger on that drove the gross profit dollars per unit on the wholesale side? I mean, it was a pretty big spike, and I know there are is some natural volatility to that category, but I was just wondering if there was anything you can kind of point to this particular quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's -- as I've always said, it's not a -- we sell cars to the top bidder. So it's not a manageable business for us within a very -- I mean, it is within a narrow range, obviously, because we've been able to do it, but within $50 or so, it's not really --
componenttext: It's -- as I've always said, it's not a -- we sell cars to the top bidder. So it's not a manageable business for us within a very -- I mean, it is within a narrow range, obviously, because we've been able to do it, but within $50 or so, it's not really -- it kind of comes out the way it does. If you look at the first quarter this year, it was I think right around $1,000. So we have normally a little seasonal drop in margin per car from the first quarter to the second quarter, and that's what I would -- I would look at it more sequentially than I would year-over-year. So we came off of $1,000 in the first quarter, and we're down to $950 in the second quarter. Last year's sequential drop was a little bit steeper, but I didn't see anything unusual there.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler of Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: My primary question relates to SUVs. You disclosed the change in mix. I'm interested in your read on what's transpiring in pricing in the SUV market, and also whether we think, perhaps, some of the change in traffic trends would have reflected consumers'
componenttext: My primary question relates to SUVs. You disclosed the change in mix. I'm interested in your read on what's transpiring in pricing in the SUV market, and also whether we think, perhaps, some of the change in traffic trends would have reflected consumers' awareness of where you are in the SUV market.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, our sales were down 2% in SUVs, and medium SUVs and trucks, so 24% down to 22%. It's still a really big number for us. So I don't think traffic had anything to do with it, and as you know, we try to manage our inventory based on turns and consumer de
componenttext: Yes, our sales were down 2% in SUVs, and medium SUVs and trucks, so 24% down to 22%. It's still a really big number for us. So I don't think traffic had anything to do with it, and as you know, we try to manage our inventory based on turns and consumer demand. I don't view 2% as a very big move, that's in a year-over-year basis. It's still almost 1/4 of all of our sales, so still a really big chunk of our sales.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: To the extent that, that happened during the quarter when -- for the market more broadly, at least on the new cars, so I presumably used parallel this. SUVs gained share within the mix. Was that a function of pricing in that market at a moment when gas pr
componenttext: To the extent that, that happened during the quarter when -- for the market more broadly, at least on the new cars, so I presumably used parallel this. SUVs gained share within the mix. Was that a function of pricing in that market at a moment when gas prices are down, and there's lots of demand for that product?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: What I've seen in that product is prices have gone up because there's more demand. So I think the lowering of gas prices has caused some higher prices when you're looking to buy those cars at auction, but not something that caused it to move meaningfully
componenttext: What I've seen in that product is prices have gone up because there's more demand. So I think the lowering of gas prices has caused some higher prices when you're looking to buy those cars at auction, but not something that caused it to move meaningfully one way or the other in terms of our sales.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just one quick financial question. You had on the warranty side, you got dinged a little bit, I guess, by a warranty cancellation reversal, some accruals there. Can you quantify that for us, please?
componenttext: Got it. And then just one quick financial question. You had on the warranty side, you got dinged a little bit, I guess, by a warranty cancellation reversal, some accruals there. Can you quantify that for us, please?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Matt, it's Tom. That reserve has gotten to be a really big number over time. It's over $100 million now, and we're going to have movement on any given quarter as we learn new things about the business. So I don't think we want to get in the habit of
componenttext: Hey, Matt, it's Tom. That reserve has gotten to be a really big number over time. It's over $100 million now, and we're going to have movement on any given quarter as we learn new things about the business. So I don't think we want to get in the habit of calling out everything that isn't adjustment in that line because, frankly, it's going to be -- it's part of life, going forward, and we don't want to call it out as a one timer. I can tell you though, margin and penetration in that space are relatively consistent with what we've been seeing over the last year, so we're happy with how the business is going. So absent the adjustment, you would have expected to see that line item increase relatively close to where unit growth was.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, one additional thing, as you go back 1.5 years ago, when we had the much bigger reserve, which we announced, called out and talked about, we also said from that point forward, we would look at this in a much more granular way on a more frequent basi
componenttext: Matt, one additional thing, as you go back 1.5 years ago, when we had the much bigger reserve, which we announced, called out and talked about, we also said from that point forward, we would look at this in a much more granular way on a more frequent basis. So whether it's a reserve of the size that Tom mentioned, you could expect us to be looking at it more frequently, and probably make adjustments, as necessary, on a quarterly basis. And unless they're material or something worthy of discussing, it will just be part of us normally running that business.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky of KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Quick question for you guys on CAF. The income growth slowed substantially sequentially. It was even down. Wondering if there's anything to point out there. Any material changes in the strategy or in terms of the end-markets, anything of note?
componenttext: Quick question for you guys on CAF. The income growth slowed substantially sequentially. It was even down. Wondering if there's anything to point out there. Any material changes in the strategy or in terms of the end-markets, anything of note?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think from the perspective of CAF, it was kind a straightforward and a boring quarter, which is what we like to see. That means everything's going as expected. If you remember, last quarter, and I believe the quarter before, we have some adjustment
componenttext: Yes, I think from the perspective of CAF, it was kind a straightforward and a boring quarter, which is what we like to see. That means everything's going as expected. If you remember, last quarter, and I believe the quarter before, we have some adjustments -- or not adjustments, but changes in our loss expectations, which were favorable and actually boosted income growth in those quarters. This quarter, we've seen lots of experience come in, as expected, right where we booked it which is how we like to see things. So there's nothing different going on. It's just a matter of we've seen losses come in exactly as we've been planning them.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And there was a lot of detailed discussion in terms of the used vehicle and the trend there and year-over-year comps and all this other stuff, but can you talk in a broader -- kind of in a broader level any material changes in terms of consumer dem
componenttext: Great. And there was a lot of detailed discussion in terms of the used vehicle and the trend there and year-over-year comps and all this other stuff, but can you talk in a broader -- kind of in a broader level any material changes in terms of consumer demand out there? You mentioned there's a mix shift in SUVs. Do you see demand holding as it was before, slowing down or anything of note?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nothing really. If you look at this quarter -- if you look at the first quarter and the second quarter, they're very, very similar, a little over 9% total sales growth. So that's our new stores kicking in about half of the company growth, and then comps o
componenttext: Nothing really. If you look at this quarter -- if you look at the first quarter and the second quarter, they're very, very similar, a little over 9% total sales growth. So that's our new stores kicking in about half of the company growth, and then comps of 4.5% to 5%. So looks very similar to the first quarter, nothing of note.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rick Nelson of Stephen.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rick Nelson of Stephen.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you discuss the sub-product market, kind of what you're seeing in terms of appetite from your lender's side on how the Tier 3 proportion was down sequentially and year-over-year?
componenttext: Can you discuss the sub-product market, kind of what you're seeing in terms of appetite from your lender's side on how the Tier 3 proportion was down sequentially and year-over-year?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the Tier 3 portion was down only very slightly year-over-year, just a couple of 1/10 of a point. But I think as we mentioned last quarter on the call, we've seen pretty consistent behavior from our Tier 3 lenders. And when I say consistent be
componenttext: Yes, I think the Tier 3 portion was down only very slightly year-over-year, just a couple of 1/10 of a point. But I think as we mentioned last quarter on the call, we've seen pretty consistent behavior from our Tier 3 lenders. And when I say consistent behavior, it doesn't necessarily mean what percentage of sales are getting down by Tier 3 because they are impacted by what is actually slowing down through the channel, and that they're able to see. So if there's a change in credit mix or if our other Tier 2 lenders are becoming more aggressive, it changes the nature of what they're seeing. What we look at is their behavior on how many of the applications that they see they approve, and if they convert and on those basis, we've seen pretty consistent behavior.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. And to follow it up with kind of a question about the CFPB [indiscernible] the non-bank auto finance companies, just like CarMax, have been any changes that you've implemented operationally?
componenttext: Okay, got you. And to follow it up with kind of a question about the CFPB [indiscernible] the non-bank auto finance companies, just like CarMax, have been any changes that you've implemented operationally?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, the larger participant ruling is out there, and frankly, nothing was of any surprise for us. There's no direct impact on our dealer operations, but as we expected all along, CarMax Auto Finance will be subject to the Bureau's supervisory authority.
componenttext: Sure, the larger participant ruling is out there, and frankly, nothing was of any surprise for us. There's no direct impact on our dealer operations, but as we expected all along, CarMax Auto Finance will be subject to the Bureau's supervisory authority. And what that means is they will be interacting with them in the future, if we're pretty certain. As far as what we've been doing, we've been paying careful attention to developments in the industry, as we see new announcements and new actions by them. We've been accessing our practices, as we see what we think are the expectations of the Bureau, and we've been working hard to make sure that our compliance and programs is up to snuff, and we'll be ready for examination if and when it comes.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the same-store sales and the showroom traffic, I mean, obviously, it sounds like the showroom traffic was pretty stagnant or up only slightly year-over-year. So Tom, what do think is driving that? I mean, we're at a point where miles d
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the same-store sales and the showroom traffic, I mean, obviously, it sounds like the showroom traffic was pretty stagnant or up only slightly year-over-year. So Tom, what do think is driving that? I mean, we're at a point where miles driven is increasing, gas prices are low, rates are low, employment's improving. It just seems like we're in an environment where showroom traffic for you should really be stepping up. I mean, is there something going on with the relative price of used cars versus new cars? Just trying to understand what -- why showroom traffic isn't up a lot.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: As I said earlier, I don't think it's something you can look at on a quarter-to-quarter basis and get a true read. And then because we have so much traffic both on our website and in our stores, if customers are not visiting as many places as they used to
componenttext: As I said earlier, I don't think it's something you can look at on a quarter-to-quarter basis and get a true read. And then because we have so much traffic both on our website and in our stores, if customers are not visiting as many places as they used to visit before because they're more prepared before they show up, then that could change the quality of traffic and that's just as good as getting more traffic. So there are just so many factors that are involved in there. I don't think there's any one item that we could point to and say this is why traffic was up or down at any given quarter, and again, we're trying to manage it over a much longer period of time. I don't have a great answer there.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, no, it just seems like the factor should be moving for you in the right direction here. And then maybe just a second question, as we look at the store openings, obviously, you guys are doing a great job there. What would it take to accelerate y
componenttext: Okay. Yes, no, it just seems like the factor should be moving for you in the right direction here. And then maybe just a second question, as we look at the store openings, obviously, you guys are doing a great job there. What would it take to accelerate your plan for store opening? I mean, the business is operating very well. You're executing on these store openings well. I mean, could you ramp-up the pace of openings?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we clearly could from a financial standpoint. We are very focused on making operational improvements in our existing stores and growing store base as well, and we don't want to do one at the expense of the other. Some of these markets that we're o
componenttext: I mean, we clearly could from a financial standpoint. We are very focused on making operational improvements in our existing stores and growing store base as well, and we don't want to do one at the expense of the other. Some of these markets that we're opening and some of the stores that we're opening in the next couple of years are very big and very complicated. When you think about us opening a big production store in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Boston, Seattle, all markets, which we have construction coming in the next few years, they're not just a store that opens themselves a few hundred cars a month. We also reconditioned in some cases, 2,000 cars a month and then run an 800 or 1,000 car a week auction. So we're starting up really a business within a business when you think about the auctions, and then building a giant reconditioning center, in some cases, attached. So it -- really, one store for us in some cases is very, very complicated. And if you look at, as I said, our opening plan over the next several years, we're going into some pretty big metro markets, building some pretty big complicated stores, and what we don't want to do is accelerate the growth base, and say, "Oh, we opened 2 more extra stores this year, but the ones that we did open, we didn't open as well and we lost the ability to improve execution." So I don't know exactly what the right number is, but I can tell you that at this pace of about a store a month, I feel like it's a pretty aggressive growth pace, and I'm really comfortable that we're growing the business effectively, and at the same time, not losing track of maybe the most important thing, which is improving existing store execution.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rod Lache of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rod Lache of Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Levin, on for Rod. Tom, I remembered last quarter, you're a little puzzled by the down year-over-year ASPs, kind of saw something small similar to this quarter. Just wondering if you guys are getting a better handle of what might be going on or
componenttext: It's Mike Levin, on for Rod. Tom, I remembered last quarter, you're a little puzzled by the down year-over-year ASPs, kind of saw something small similar to this quarter. Just wondering if you guys are getting a better handle of what might be going on or if some of the used car supply might be starting to get better affordability for your consumers. Just any kind of beginning of a trend here?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Puzzled is a good word. I think I probably was a little puzzled in the first quarter. But this quarter, our ASPs are actually up sequentially, and I think ASPs should be looked at on a sequential basis more than a year-over-year basis. I think it's the mo
componenttext: Puzzled is a good word. I think I probably was a little puzzled in the first quarter. But this quarter, our ASPs are actually up sequentially, and I think ASPs should be looked at on a sequential basis more than a year-over-year basis. I think it's the more relevant data point. And I think we're up like $150 from the first quarter to the second quarter, and I'm sure that a lot of it for us is mix-related. It turned into a much bigger deal at the end of the first quarter last year when we were down by $300. I think people thought it was some type of an indicator of other things in the marketplace, and honestly, we just didn't see it that way and it hasn't born out to be that way. So we manage the business on a per-unit basis, not on a revenue basis. So we don't really look at it that closely. But coming from the first quarter, second quarter, we're up $150 so...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. Maybe just on CAF, looks like the collateral spread is starting to stabilize here around 6.2%. Do you guys still feel like that might have a little room to soften from here or with rates possibly on the rise in the near future, are you getti
componenttext: Got it, okay. Maybe just on CAF, looks like the collateral spread is starting to stabilize here around 6.2%. Do you guys still feel like that might have a little room to soften from here or with rates possibly on the rise in the near future, are you getting the ability to kind of raise prices to end consumers at this point?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the answer to both of this is probably a bit of a yes. It's going to be a byproduct of where we -- what customers are demanding what the market is for auto loans and what cost of financing does. We saw our cost on the last deal tick up about 20 ba
componenttext: I think the answer to both of this is probably a bit of a yes. It's going to be a byproduct of where we -- what customers are demanding what the market is for auto loans and what cost of financing does. We saw our cost on the last deal tick up about 20 basis points, which we see in any given period. Not a big deal, but they actually were up relative to the last 3 deals. We are constantly testing both up and down in different pockets of the business to make sure we're optimizing what we have available for the customers, and we're going to manage the spread to whatever the market will allow us. So hopefully, I tried to answer, but I think -- but the answer is -- if the market -- if rates go up and we're not able to raise APRs, we'll continue to see some compression. If the market allows us to keep that spread there, we'll do that, but we're absolutely going to be a competitive lender and be providing excellent opportunities for our customers from a financing perspective.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll just say, if you look at this over a very long period of time, as Tom mentioned, we're one of the lenders in our store and we have to be competitive and we also give our customers 3 business days to go get a better deal somewhere else and they can tu
componenttext: I'll just say, if you look at this over a very long period of time, as Tom mentioned, we're one of the lenders in our store and we have to be competitive and we also give our customers 3 business days to go get a better deal somewhere else and they can turn it in with no charge. And generally, over time, at a raising rate environment, spreads tend to compress, and in an environment where rates are going down, spreads tend to widen. Other than that, we're not in the business to try to predict where it's going to go, but there's been a lot of talk about cost of funds increasing over time, and we'll see what happens.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think I said this on last quarter's call, we've been in rate environments where benchmarks are significantly higher than they are today and live with similar spreads to what we're doing today. That doesn't mean that it's the case in the future,
componenttext: Yes, and I think I said this on last quarter's call, we've been in rate environments where benchmarks are significantly higher than they are today and live with similar spreads to what we're doing today. That doesn't mean that it's the case in the future, but it's a point of reference you want to look back at. In the mid-2000s, we were in a higher rate environment with pretty strong spreads of CAF.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham of Wedbush.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham of Wedbush.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is just a follow-up on CAF. Obviously, penetration improved a little bit year-over-year about 200 basis points. Would you say that you guys were a little bit more aggressive in terms to get that type of penetration or is there anything e
componenttext: My first question is just a follow-up on CAF. Obviously, penetration improved a little bit year-over-year about 200 basis points. Would you say that you guys were a little bit more aggressive in terms to get that type of penetration or is there anything else you can point to there?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there's a couple of things going on from that perspective. Part of it's what's coming in the door. Credit quality in the door was up a couple of points year-over-year, so that naturally would lend towards CAF getting more of the volume. Also, we h
componenttext: I think there's a couple of things going on from that perspective. Part of it's what's coming in the door. Credit quality in the door was up a couple of points year-over-year, so that naturally would lend towards CAF getting more of the volume. Also, we have been a bit more aggressive on our testing and we probably did take a little volume from Tier 2. You can see that in the other financing margin line, where even given the fact that Tier 3 was down a little bit, that we had a slight increase in fees paid to other financial parties that's because Tier 2 was down a little bit as well.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, that's helpful. And then secondly, in terms of inventory, the ability, Tom, you spoke to the huge competitive advantage you guys have there, but it seems like, nowadays, almost every other used car in a given market is online, and customers are wi
componenttext: Got it, that's helpful. And then secondly, in terms of inventory, the ability, Tom, you spoke to the huge competitive advantage you guys have there, but it seems like, nowadays, almost every other used car in a given market is online, and customers are willing to travel a bit further to buy those cars. Does that sort of change the competitive dynamics in your view or not?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It depends on who the competitor is that they then go and buy the car from. I mean, we've been consistently the retailer that offers a no-haggle price, easy access to financing, with no negotiation, a cash offer on every car, a 30-day warranty, a 5-day mo
componenttext: It depends on who the competitor is that they then go and buy the car from. I mean, we've been consistently the retailer that offers a no-haggle price, easy access to financing, with no negotiation, a cash offer on every car, a 30-day warranty, a 5-day money back guarantee, 3 days to go get a better loan somewhere else. We stand behind the product that we sell. We have a seamless process. Our sales consultants are not paid a commission based on which car you buy or how much profit we make. So I don't think it's just the fact that the car is available. I think it still goes back to the process that the customer has to go through, and whether or not they're comfortable doing that. And I think that's something that we continue to have a very large competitive advantage on. So the market is extremely fragmented, and the fact that all of those cars online doesn't change the fact that when the customer goes and actually goes through the process, they still have to go through a process in a way that makes them uncomfortable.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, and so increased price transparency isn't really a big issue for you guys because of the offer that you had all around, not just price?
componenttext: Got it, and so increased price transparency isn't really a big issue for you guys because of the offer that you had all around, not just price?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, increased price transparency is price transparency on the price of the car only, which is almost always negotiable, and then the price of the trade, which is always negotiable, and then the price of the financing which is ridiculously negotiable, an
componenttext: Well, increased price transparency is price transparency on the price of the car only, which is almost always negotiable, and then the price of the trade, which is always negotiable, and then the price of the financing which is ridiculously negotiable, and then the price of all the add-on products, like an extended service plan or accessories which are also negotiable. So when you look at it from top to bottom and the fact that we are straightforward and transparent on all of the pieces of the transaction, I think we have a significant competitive advantage, and it shows up in our volumes.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong of CL King & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong of CL King & Associates.

componenttext: I just have one question on CAF. Your weighted contract rate was up a little bit year-over-year but down sequentially. Are there any seasonal factors involved or was it more the customer mix? How should we kind of look at that?

componenttext: Yes, Q4 and Q1 are typically lower credit mixes. So you might see a little bit of stuff skewed beyond down towards our Bs and Cs then, but I don't think there's anything to read into it. There's nothing from a behavioral perspective that we did differently.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015

componenttext: Okay, so you were just kind of consider that it's still within the norm?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015

componenttext: Going back to the NFL endorsement deals, should we think of this more as a kind of a very large scale trial or should we expect more deals like this going forward, because as you noted, you are a bigger company?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015

componenttext: Like any other advertising program that we have tried or run in the past, we'll evaluate it based on its performance and determine if it should be a bigger piece of what we do going forward. We've been a sponsor of the Los Angeles Clippers for almost 10 years now, so this isn't our first sports sponsorship. It's just our first NFL sponsorship.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and you mentioned at the beginning of the call, about 65% of your business is coming from something other than a laptop or desktop. Is there anything that a smartphone or tablet user cannot do today that someone on a laptop or desktop can do?
componenttext: Okay, and you mentioned at the beginning of the call, about 65% of your business is coming from something other than a laptop or desktop. Is there anything that a smartphone or tablet user cannot do today that someone on a laptop or desktop can do?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That was just 65% of our web hits, not 65% of our business. So it's 65% of the total hits coming to our website are coming from a tablet or a -- we have a different site for each, so there's a mobile site you go through on the mobile device and then there
componenttext: That was just 65% of our web hits, not 65% of our business. So it's 65% of the total hits coming to our website are coming from a tablet or a -- we have a different site for each, so there's a mobile site you go through on the mobile device and then there's an app. And the app has somewhat limited capability, but all the things that we think are most important, the ability to search for a car, the ability to look at 40 high-definition pictures, the ability to zoom in on each one of them, the ability to find a store and contact a sales consultant, and we're continuing to work on adding additional capabilities. But clearly, there are more capabilities on a desktop just because there's more room, and there's more -- just more access for the customer to do more things online, but we're continuing to work on our app, and continuing to give the customer more capabilities based on their demands.

componenttext: Okay, can you transfer on an app?

componenttext: Can you transfer on an app, you cannot transfer on the app right now. You can't go in and enter your credit card information and transfer a car, no.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Montani of Evercore ISI.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask on the retail gross profit per-unit, which was quite consistent there. A lot of the public competitors on the dealer side have been seeing mid-single digit declines, and you guys have been really persistent. So can you just discuss some of
componenttext: I wanted to ask on the retail gross profit per-unit, which was quite consistent there. A lot of the public competitors on the dealer side have been seeing mid-single digit declines, and you guys have been really persistent. So can you just discuss some of the levers you might have and how should we think about that going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've been pretty consistent with managing our margins over a pretty long period of time now. I can't comment on the way others manage their business, but we're pretty, pretty confident in our ability to manage margin through all kinds of different enviro
componenttext: We've been pretty consistent with managing our margins over a pretty long period of time now. I can't comment on the way others manage their business, but we're pretty, pretty confident in our ability to manage margin through all kinds of different environments, even going back to the recession. We're able to manage margin pretty effectively and inventory turns during that time, which is the most significant single piece of volatility that we've seen in our time running the business. So we feel pretty confident in our ability to be pretty consistent with our margins.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one other issue was on the buyback potential. From a debt-to-cap standpoint, I think, that you all said that there's opportunity there to perhaps be a little bit more per aggressive. So maybe for Tom Reedy, if you could just go through how you're
componenttext: And just one other issue was on the buyback potential. From a debt-to-cap standpoint, I think, that you all said that there's opportunity there to perhaps be a little bit more per aggressive. So maybe for Tom Reedy, if you could just go through how you're thinking about that, and then also what are the metrics you would use to evaluate if you want to get more aggressive with the buyback.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, what we -- I mean, our -- we try to be pretty consistent in our approach and kind of the fundamental to it was that we, obviously, are continuing having a priority of returning capital to shareholders as it's appropriate, and we also believe
componenttext: Yes, I think, what we -- I mean, our -- we try to be pretty consistent in our approach and kind of the fundamental to it was that we, obviously, are continuing having a priority of returning capital to shareholders as it's appropriate, and we also believe that we could use a little additional leverage in our capital structure. We talked about getting back to levels that are closer to where we ran pre-recession than where we are today. We made some progress. We bought back about $1.8 billion since the start of the program or about 15% of the shares are outstanding as of October of 2012, but we still think -- as you've seen, we've made a little bit a progress on the cash balance this past quarter, gone down about $250 million. But to get back to the levels we're considering, we would need significantly more debt than we have today. So I think we'd expect to continue on with the program as is. As far as how aggressive we get, we've stepped up the program with some -- bumpers in place that essentially govern our buy volume based on stock price and valuation, allow us to be a little more aggressive as price and valuation drop and vice versa. As price and valuation are up, we review that on an ongoing basis and we'll adjust it as appropriate. As you saw this quarter, stock price was down. We were a bit up on our volume. Last quarter was the opposite. So you can see -- we do take a bit of a view on what -- how much volume to buy given prices, but remember, it's going to be a programmatic approach over time.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky of KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky of KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have one follow-up question on the recall question. It was asked earlier. AutoNation made a move to ground all vehicles under recall. There was a recent attempt to implement the law similar to that. It didn't work right now, and in near-term, nobody exp
componenttext: I have one follow-up question on the recall question. It was asked earlier. AutoNation made a move to ground all vehicles under recall. There was a recent attempt to implement the law similar to that. It didn't work right now, and in near-term, nobody expects that. But longer term, it could become an issue if the industry moves in that direction. So I was just wondering if you have discussed that internally. If this is a concern, why -- how material is just the higher cost issue, maybe higher inventory cost? And if it's not a concern, then why not?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it is a concern, we've talked about it at length. It's something that we're always trying to do what's the most transparent thing that we can do for our customers. Some things to remember is we're in a different -- we are almost exclusively used car
componenttext:
Well, it is a concern, we've talked about it at length. It's something that we're always trying to do what's the most transparent thing that we can do for our customers. Some things to remember is we're in a different -- we are almost exclusively used cars. We operate almost no new car franchises, and actually, 2 last as of this quarter. We're down to just 2 Toyota stores, 1 in Baltimore, 1 in Kenosha, and all of -- any repairs that are under warranty, which include recalls, for us have to be taken to a dealer and done at that location. If there were laws, as we have always complied with all the laws, if there was a law passed that required us to fix recalls, we would absolutely do that. But then everybody would be in the exact same boat, and all others who sell used cars would have to get those repaired at manufacturer's locations. We think the most important thing is to make sure that customers are fully informed of whether or not there's an open recall on the car and also of how important it is to register on a manufacturer's website. We may sell them a car and a week later, a recall may come out, and if they haven't registered with the manufacturer, then they won't ever know about that. Every customer that buys a car at CarMax is made aware in several different points of the transaction about recalls. We have a direct link on our website to the database. It is -- automatically populates the vend for the customer, so they can see exactly what's going on with that individual car. And then at the point of sale, our sales consultants are walking through with the customer exactly what I just said, whether or not the car has an open recall, and the importance of registering with the manufacturer on their website, so they can be notified of recalls going forward. So we're absolutely committed to transparency. And if there's any changes in the law, obviously, we'll comply with all those laws.
Okay. All right, thanks very much for your interest in CarMax, and thanks to all of our associates for all they do everyday, and we'll talk to you next quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 22, 2015
