headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question relates to SUVs. I know you guys were down about 200 basis points year-on-year. Do you have a sense for what the used market is doing for SUV mix, in general? In other words, do you think used market sales of -- do you think the mix of S
componenttext: My first question relates to SUVs. I know you guys were down about 200 basis points year-on-year. Do you have a sense for what the used market is doing for SUV mix, in general? In other words, do you think used market sales of -- do you think the mix of SUVs to the market is down, is flat, is it up? Or are you differing in the way you're indexing SUVs versus your competition?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure versus the broader competition, Matt, but we were up a point compared to the second quarter, and we still sold a lot of trucks and SUVs in the quarter, 23% of our total sales. But as I mentioned, our prices were pretty high in the quarter. An
componenttext: I'm not sure versus the broader competition, Matt, but we were up a point compared to the second quarter, and we still sold a lot of trucks and SUVs in the quarter, 23% of our total sales. But as I mentioned, our prices were pretty high in the quarter. And as you know, we buy a lot of cars the auction return to make sure we always deliver a great value to our customers. So there are times in the quarter we just didn't think it was worth overpaying at the expense of to the consumer. I think this is probably short-lived. Obviously, it's driven by low gas prices. We've seen bigger increases in new car sales as it relates to SUVs and trucks compared to the used car market increases. But ultimately, these cars will all come back into the market at some point.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

componenttext: And my follow-up for you briefly, the advertising dollar shift into Q3, was that out of Q2 or out of Q4?

componenttext: Really, we just wanted to point out that we launched a new campaign during the quarter and that this just -- it wouldn't be a typical increase for us in terms of our quarter-over-quarter expense, given that the sales level that we had. So we weren't really trying to stay came from a place to the other. This is not what you expect to confirm us on a year-over-year basis. We did create and launched a new campaign during the quarter that started in September.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

componenttext: And how do you guys feel that campaign as you measure, given where the sales force you measure the return on that ad campaign, I know it's early to judge but your own evaluation.

componenttext: Yes, it's very early to judge. Particularly when you have a new broadcast company, it's mostly around brand building and not necessarily for short-term sales gain. You guys know we're not promotional. We don't have sales. So most of our campaigns are long-term brand building.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first, I think, my first question is just basically following to what Matt asked. But Tom, thanks for laying out some of the extra comment there with regard to sales in the quarter. How do we think about -- if you take those individually, how do we thi
componenttext: So first, I think, my first question is just basically following to what Matt asked. But Tom, thanks for laying out some of the extra comment there with regard to sales in the quarter. How do we think about -- if you take those individually, how do we think about the, I guess, the trajectory from here? I mean, it seems the comments you made some of those factors will begin to abate here. But maybe a little more color on that as to how we should think about these factors going into the balance of this fiscal year and into 2016.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: One, it's very difficult to attribute a number of points the factors. It's just all things that we noted during the quarter. We also had our toughest comparison of the year, which I didn't mention. And our 2-year stack comp in the third quarter was actual
componenttext: One, it's very difficult to attribute a number of points the factors. It's just all things that we noted during the quarter. We also had our toughest comparison of the year, which I didn't mention. And our 2-year stack comp in the third quarter was actually higher than it was in the second quarter. But I think each of these things had a little bit of an impact on our ability to deliver during the quarter. Most of them, I think, are short-lived. It's very difficult to predict events and when things are going to change and supply, but I think we've got done a really nice job over the last several years of being able to adjust and adapt to changing trends in the discuss marketplace, I think we'll do the same here. I just about the things we should have pointed out during the quarter. A lot of the supply stuff is going to take care of itself over time. And we're going to take advantage of the things that present themselves to us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then so maybe a follow-up to that, I think there's a lot of comments or commentary all about their about new competitive coming into your marketplace. Have you seen anything new with respect to this -- your stores that may compete more directl
componenttext: Got it. And then so maybe a follow-up to that, I think there's a lot of comments or commentary all about their about new competitive coming into your marketplace. Have you seen anything new with respect to this -- your stores that may compete more directly with some of these new competition?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we -- it's an ever-changing marketplace. A lot of the stuff we've seen is around additional capabilities, which we're working really hard to continue to increase for our customers. And as I mentioned, remember, our average store sold 340 cars a mo
componenttext: I mean, we -- it's an ever-changing marketplace. A lot of the stuff we've seen is around additional capabilities, which we're working really hard to continue to increase for our customers. And as I mentioned, remember, our average store sold 340 cars a month during the quarter. If you look at industry data, the average new car dealer sells about 50 cars a month. So it's really hard to see that we're losing ground, and a lot of that stuff that you read about for -- from new competition are very small players in very limited markets. So it's not likely that we're seeing an impact across the nation for our 153 stores when a lot of the fresh around very small players in limited markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, obviously, you've seen the cycles in terms of kind of how the wholesale market adjust to maybe supply/demand anomalies. So on this whole kind of conversation around SUVs, could you kind of provide some historical perspective perhaps about
componenttext: Okay. And then, obviously, you've seen the cycles in terms of kind of how the wholesale market adjust to maybe supply/demand anomalies. So on this whole kind of conversation around SUVs, could you kind of provide some historical perspective perhaps about anomalies you might have seen in the past and kind of how long a correction may take in the pricing on the wholesale market?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I can probably comment on some anomalies in the past, but in terms of how long a correction takes, I think, there's too many macro factors involved. But we are seeing, the highest SAAR we've ever seen and the bigger the increase of the SAARs relat
componenttext: I mean, I can probably comment on some anomalies in the past, but in terms of how long a correction takes, I think, there's too many macro factors involved. But we are seeing, the highest SAAR we've ever seen and the bigger the increase of the SAARs related to trucks and SUVs, if I was thinking about that over a long period of time, that means a couple of years of now, we're seeing a lot of trucks and SUVs out in the wholesale market, which if there's demand, then we'll be able to take advantage of that and buy and sell them. I think the other big variable that's impossible to predict is first, gas prices; and second, the impact of gas prices. I know you remember back in the spring of '08 when gas hit $4, nobody would buy an SUV of any kind. But in October of that same year, gas was below $2 and things kind of went back to where they were. Since then, when we've seen gas prices increase, we haven't seen the same knee-jerk reaction that we saw. So gas prices have been pretty low for a while, and I think it's provided a boost for trucks and SUVs. But it's really hard to say what will happen on Florida. I just think our model is best equipped to take advantage of whatever the market brings. We're not holding to any manufacturer or any type of product, and we want to sell whatever the customer wants to buy.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to violate Katharine's 2-question rule. Just one last follow-up, I guess. What you're seeing right now, would you characterize as kind of normal ebbs and flows that you've seen in the market over time? Or is there anything that gives you longer-ter
componenttext: I want to violate Katharine's 2-question rule. Just one last follow-up, I guess. What you're seeing right now, would you characterize as kind of normal ebbs and flows that you've seen in the market over time? Or is there anything that gives you longer-term more fundamental concerns?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't see anything that causes us long-term concerns.
componenttext: Yes, we don't see anything that causes us long-term concerns.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of technology, could you cover, Tom, your priorities for the next 12 months in terms of digital and technology initiatives?
componenttext: And then in terms of technology, could you cover, Tom, your priorities for the next 12 months in terms of digital and technology initiatives?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, our priorities are somewhat unchanged. We want to keep making sure that our customers have a great experience regardless of how they interact with CarMax. It could be from a desktop, it could be from a mobile device, a tablet or in the store, and we
componenttext: Well, our priorities are somewhat unchanged. We want to keep making sure that our customers have a great experience regardless of how they interact with CarMax. It could be from a desktop, it could be from a mobile device, a tablet or in the store, and we're very focused on making the transition from their digital experience to the store simple and seamless so that the experience they have online matches up with the experience that they have in the store. And we're also pushing real hard over the next 12 months or so to make sure that our store teams are to move that's available regarding the individual customers to try to make their experience more personalized. We have a very big database of customers, and we're going to make sure that we can access that information that our associates in the store can access of information customers arrive. And also, we just want to keep increasing capabilities of customers they want to do more and more of the transaction online.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy of Bank of America.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a first question, Tom, as we think about sort of these tougher comps, I mean, basically, we're looking at multi-decade lows in the 0 to 5 [indiscernible] portion of the fleet in absolute terms. And certainly, 30-plus year lows as far as the percentag
componenttext: Just a first question, Tom, as we think about sort of these tougher comps, I mean, basically, we're looking at multi-decade lows in the 0 to 5 [indiscernible] portion of the fleet in absolute terms. And certainly, 30-plus year lows as far as the percentage of the total population of cars outstanding. So I mean, as we see that 0 to 5 bucket grow in the next 1, 2 or 3 years, don't you just sort of naturally -- would you just naturally expect your same-store sales to recover as the market to recover sort of the pressure we're seeing here of the function of supply?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we expect us to be able to comp our stores over a long period of time. And I think there's lots of external factors that either help or aren't. I've always felt like the supply of 0- to 5-year old cars increasing is good for us. It's an area where i
componenttext: Well, we expect us to be able to comp our stores over a long period of time. And I think there's lots of external factors that either help or aren't. I've always felt like the supply of 0- to 5-year old cars increasing is good for us. It's an area where it on a market share basis, if you look at an individual year-to-year basis, we have -- it's been kind of our sweet spot. So I mean, I agree, as the supply increases there, I think we'll do better in those segments. What I feel even -- what I also feel good about is coming out of the recession, we did a really good job of figuring out our older cars as well. And I feel like we can do both. So we look at the CarMax consumer offering of 0 to 10-year old cars, and I think we're pretty good across the spectrum at near new cars and then older cars with higher miles. I don't think everybody does good as the book initiative as we do. I don't think nobody is in a good position to take advantage of those sales as we are.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just sort of a follow-up in the second question. I mean, when you look at the gap of new versus used pricing and then you look at the financing offerings that are at a new vehicle dealers for new vehicles. It just seems like it's very compe
componenttext: Okay. And then just sort of a follow-up in the second question. I mean, when you look at the gap of new versus used pricing and then you look at the financing offerings that are at a new vehicle dealers for new vehicles. It just seems like it's very compelling for a 0 to 5 or even 0 to 10 consumer to into buying a new vehicle. I mean, if you look at as your to 5 year old car, basically, the gap on a monthly payment basis $100 or actually potentially significant and less depending on what kind of financing they get at the new vehicle dealership. I mean, how do you kind of fight that tide? I mean, and do you think you just need that supply plus pricing to come down to great a wider gap to drive those consumers back to used vehicles? Because it's incredible tight right now less than it would change him if there's anything you can do to help change it.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's not like this doesn't happen. It hasn't happened before. There are always pockets or segment near new cars that given the incentive environment whether it's through cashback or leasing, oftentimes, consumers will make that decision. It doesn't
componenttext: Well, it's not like this doesn't happen. It hasn't happened before. There are always pockets or segment near new cars that given the incentive environment whether it's through cashback or leasing, oftentimes, consumers will make that decision. It doesn't mean they won't come back to us through 3 or 4, 5 years later when they're buying something different. And I do want to point out our average car is around on $20,000 and the average new car is around $33,000. So the difference, on average, has not come down at all. In fact, it's widened. But it's always true that at any given point in time, given -- depending on the incentive environment that there is some close calls there, and I think it was especially true this quarter, and that's why I pointed out.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of James Albertine of Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of James Albertine of Stifel.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just another follow-up on the trends you're seeing in the new cycle. And quite frankly, you lived through a lot of obstacles and a lot of other headwinds over the last 20 years and looks like nothing you can't weather. And it seems like this time might be
componenttext: Just another follow-up on the trends you're seeing in the new cycle. And quite frankly, you lived through a lot of obstacles and a lot of other headwinds over the last 20 years and looks like nothing you can't weather. And it seems like this time might be a little different, particularly among the domestic manufacturers, given the propensity to lease. Is there a high likelihood that some of this new vehicles that are selling on the SUV and truck side go back to dealers rather than hitting the auction market and that -- could that limit your availability of supply in the coming years? Or is that something that you considered and aren't really worried about?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's something we've lived through before in terms of percent of new car sales that are leased. I think the number now is around 30%. It's been this high at times before. Generally, what that means is 2, 3 years down the road, those cars will come b
componenttext: Well, it's something we've lived through before in terms of percent of new car sales that are leased. I think the number now is around 30%. It's been this high at times before. Generally, what that means is 2, 3 years down the road, those cars will come back to the market in a kind of a more organized way. And dealers won't be able to absorb the volume that comes back, and a lot of those cars end up at auction. And that's what's happened historically. And we've been able to take advantage of that in the past. I really look at a high lease environment as a negative for us when you think about supply 2 or 3 years later. If you think about this cycle of getting out of a new car, if it remains to the people get out of their car every 3 to 5 years, it really doesn't make any difference whether it comes back to lease channel or it comes back as an individual car, eventually they end up in the open market place, and we have an opportunity to buy them.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, and that ties, I think, with your 340 cars per month kind of versus 50 per month average that you made earlier. There's just not a capacity for the dealers to handle the off lease. So I appreciate that color. And then a quick follow-up on the cred
componenttext: Got it, and that ties, I think, with your 340 cars per month kind of versus 50 per month average that you made earlier. There's just not a capacity for the dealers to handle the off lease. So I appreciate that color. And then a quick follow-up on the credit market now that we've finally seen a rate increase and if you look over the last few CAF securitizations, it appears as though the spread might be stabilizing. But really wanted to get kind of update there as to what you think -- if we are in stabilization point or even know that rates are up sort of optically consumers are now expecting higher rates, does that allow you now to sort of increase the APR may be even see that spread expand in the near term?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. As far as the spread to the customer goes, that's going to be really market-dependent up as we've said in the past. Our first goal of CarMax out was a competitive offer to the customer, and we will go where the market dictates we go. That sai
componenttext: This is Tom. As far as the spread to the customer goes, that's going to be really market-dependent up as we've said in the past. Our first goal of CarMax out was a competitive offer to the customer, and we will go where the market dictates we go. That said, we're constantly testing both up in town to make sure we're optimizing CarMax sales and income at the same time. As you know we have seen cost of funds increasing this year. Have seen testing rates upwards of with it. But I really can't give you any kind of forward-looking on where that spend will go because it's going to be market raised base. Historically, as rates have come up, we've been a little bit as the market has slower to adjust upward because that rates conversely when rates come down, the usual downward because the market's going to drive that as well, and you see a little bit of a benefit. But as far as going forward, yes, the market will tell. I think now that The Fed defense has given some guidance, I think about where they're that stabilize things from the perspective of spread and the asset back to market our spreads gap up last year versus prior deals even though we are in the lower interest rate environment. But I think some of that was uncertainty around what that was going to do.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me just ask one other one, if that's okay. Just following up on your digital capabilities that you're talking about adding, how should we think about the kind of investments required to bring those up to what you're talking about?
componenttext: Okay. Let me just ask one other one, if that's okay. Just following up on your digital capabilities that you're talking about adding, how should we think about the kind of investments required to bring those up to what you're talking about?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of the investment can be done within our normal spend over the course of the year. We have a pretty significant spend in both IT and marketing and a lot of the investments that we'll be making can go over that to cars. But we are looking forwa
componenttext: Well, a lot of the investment can be done within our normal spend over the course of the year. We have a pretty significant spend in both IT and marketing and a lot of the investments that we'll be making can go over that to cars. But we are looking forward at what types of the investments might we need to make. And when we have something to talk about there, we'll let everyone know.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky of KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions for you. The lower floor traffic that you called out in your release, what do you think are the drivers? Is it the lack of the SUVs and trucks you pointed out as a difficult supply is now worse? Or is it perhaps competition and new entrants
componenttext: Two questions for you. The lower floor traffic that you called out in your release, what do you think are the drivers? Is it the lack of the SUVs and trucks you pointed out as a difficult supply is now worse? Or is it perhaps competition and new entrants into the market to a competing in the stand-alone used vehicle stores?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's really hard to say. But I do want to point out, we did get enough traffic to sell 340 cars a month per store. And it was only slightly down. And then conversion was slightly up. And we ended up where we ended up. But in terms of traffic through the d
componenttext: It's really hard to say. But I do want to point out, we did get enough traffic to sell 340 cars a month per store. And it was only slightly down. And then conversion was slightly up. And we ended up where we ended up. But in terms of traffic through the door, I think there's a chance that customers are being more prepared and are more likely to buy when they show up. And for us, if we can get traffic that's more prepared and more likely to buy, that's just as good for us as it is as we got plain old extra traffic. So it's not as easy an answer as you might think. But we had a lot of traffic in our stores during the quarter. It's slightly down compared to last year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the second question for you. You mentioned in your opening remarks one of the impact in the comps was the lower supply of 0- to 5-year-old cars, is that as in general to what we've been hearing? Or are you seeing an actual sequential pullback in this
componenttext: And the second question for you. You mentioned in your opening remarks one of the impact in the comps was the lower supply of 0- to 5-year-old cars, is that as in general to what we've been hearing? Or are you seeing an actual sequential pullback in this supply from the, let's say, in the second or the first quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, while I mentioned supply, I said the supply was down in 5 to 10-year-old cars, not 0 to 5. And in 5 to 10-year-old cars, it just makes sense since the SAAR that you're building 6, 7 or 8 was dramatically lower than what the SAAR is today. Rememb
componenttext: Actually, while I mentioned supply, I said the supply was down in 5 to 10-year-old cars, not 0 to 5. And in 5 to 10-year-old cars, it just makes sense since the SAAR that you're building 6, 7 or 8 was dramatically lower than what the SAAR is today. Remember, we had SAARs as low as 10 in September of '08. So I was referencing the supply of older cars.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Montani of Evercore.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Montani of Evercore.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about if you could just talk us through how you think about managing the business in terms of balancing inventory turns with gross profit dollars per unit. Generally speaking, some of the publicly traded dealer peers have shown a little bi
componenttext: I wanted to ask about if you could just talk us through how you think about managing the business in terms of balancing inventory turns with gross profit dollars per unit. Generally speaking, some of the publicly traded dealer peers have shown a little bit higher unit comps but also shown greater erosion in terms of GPUs. So just trying to think through how you run the business and any tests you may have had tweaking either those 2 elements.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've talked about this in the past. We run pricing test in a pretty regular basis. You can also seen we've been very consistent with the margins of that we've been able to achieve. So look, there's no way to go back and say, "What if we have lower p
componenttext: Yes, we've talked about this in the past. We run pricing test in a pretty regular basis. You can also seen we've been very consistent with the margins of that we've been able to achieve. So look, there's no way to go back and say, "What if we have lower prices, how many more cars would we have sold?" My guess is we'll probably give up a little bit of share by maintaining our prices during the quarter, but it's impossible to quantify. I don't think, however, that we gave up gross margin dollars. And I don't think that we -- I think we try to make the decision that's in the best interest of our shareholders each and every quarter. So we did see the decline in margins that some of the other publicly traded auto retailers reported ending September. And it maybe helped their comps a bit, but as far as we are concerned, we can only make the best decision we can with the information that we have, and that's what we did during the quarter. And we're okay with the results.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could just follow up on one, which is the leverage point. I believe in the past, you said 4% to 5% being the comp that you would need to show leverage. And obviously, the commentary today is that there's no change to the outlook for fu
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could just follow up on one, which is the leverage point. I believe in the past, you said 4% to 5% being the comp that you would need to show leverage. And obviously, the commentary today is that there's no change to the outlook for future year store growth. So should we assume that's the same because I know there's a lot of initiatives that you guys are working on in terms of cost to try and prove that as well.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think -- we've always said kind of mid-single digits. We've never really put an exact number on it. It's also dependent on the rate of growth during any given quarter. It's also dependent on the type of growth during the quarter open up the big me
componenttext: Yes, we think -- we've always said kind of mid-single digits. We've never really put an exact number on it. It's also dependent on the rate of growth during any given quarter. It's also dependent on the type of growth during the quarter open up the big metro markets more expensive than opening up smaller stores. And as you saw during this quarter, there's occasionally some timing of expenses that's going to impact it but, I think, if you think about it over a long period of time with the growth plan that we have publicly announced mid-single-digits or so, I think we can leverage our SG&A dollars.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong of CL King & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong of CL King & Associates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just getting back to the SUV light truck mix. If we look at total industry sales 2012 through '14, about 50% of total sales were white trucks, so call it SUVs and pickups. Your sales and inventory mix clearly is much less. So are you seeing -- are you not
componenttext: Just getting back to the SUV light truck mix. If we look at total industry sales 2012 through '14, about 50% of total sales were white trucks, so call it SUVs and pickups. Your sales and inventory mix clearly is much less. So are you seeing -- are you not seeing that many of those vehicles available for sale? Or is it they are maybe not in the condition that you want to re-retail? Like -- there seems to be a disconnect there.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Did you say -- I didn't hear what you said about the mix. Did you say 50%?
componenttext: Did you say -- I didn't hear what you said about the mix. Did you say 50%?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: 50% of all car -- your vehicles sold from 2012 to 2014 were light classified as light trucks, so SUVs and pickups basically.
componenttext: 50% of all car -- your vehicles sold from 2012 to 2014 were light classified as light trucks, so SUVs and pickups basically.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I haven't heard that number before but I believe you, but that's never been the case for us. I mean, we always been in the mid-20s. So this isn't...
componenttext: Yes. I haven't heard that number before but I believe you, but that's never been the case for us. I mean, we always been in the mid-20s. So this isn't...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's not the same metric.
componenttext: It's not the same metric.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hold on a second.
componenttext: Hold on a second.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: This metric includes, it's much broader. Ours is just like large SUVs.
componenttext: This metric includes, it's much broader. Ours is just like large SUVs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our 23% is medium and large SUVs and pickup trucks. I think the 50% includes crossovers and smaller SUVs. So that's not in our number. And I don't have that number handy to tell you what the mix was. I think, in general, over time, we are going to look a
componenttext: Our 23% is medium and large SUVs and pickup trucks. I think the 50% includes crossovers and smaller SUVs. So that's not in our number. And I don't have that number handy to tell you what the mix was. I think, in general, over time, we are going to look a lot like the industry looks. Our sample is very large. We're very widespread across the country. And in general, we're going to look like the industry looks over time. I mean, that's where our supply comes from, and we're going to match up consumer demand. It's never going to be exact particularly on a quarter-to-quarter basis, but if you look at what we have is certainly, reported in trucks and SUV's, it's generally in the mid-20s, sometimes in the high 20s. This quarter was 23%. It was up a point from the time before. Remember that we're talking about 2 different measures.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. Do you feel like maybe you're missing some opportunities then with the SUVs or not necessarily?
componenttext: Okay, got it. Do you feel like maybe you're missing some opportunities then with the SUVs or not necessarily?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said, I think during the quarter, there was a chance that we could have paid more. It's not like the cars weren't out there. But we're always trying to deliver a great value for the consumer as well. So there are always times when certain thing
componenttext: Well, as I said, I think during the quarter, there was a chance that we could have paid more. It's not like the cars weren't out there. But we're always trying to deliver a great value for the consumer as well. So there are always times when certain things at the auction, we just think they're too expensive, and we don't want to buy them and then turn around and resell them. So we wait. And I think the same thing is true here. We've been around a long time we've seen cycles carbon cycles go down and as I mentioned earlier, who knows what happens with gas prices. You see a big spike in gas prices and there's a good chance our SUV mix will go up will because those cars would be cheaper and be a better value to our customers. But I did mention it during the quarter. We saw that there was a lot of pressure on SUV pricing.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, that makes sense if I can just sneak one in, extended protection plan revenue light vehicle sales all that? Anything to call out there?
componenttext: Got it. Okay, that makes sense if I can just sneak one in, extended protection plan revenue light vehicle sales all that? Anything to call out there?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nothing in particular. In general, we do expect our business to grow with unit sales. This quarter, we had some adjustments in the return reserves. Remember that's like $100 million reserve, kind of reserve and we're going to see some small movements and
componenttext: Nothing in particular. In general, we do expect our business to grow with unit sales. This quarter, we had some adjustments in the return reserves. Remember that's like $100 million reserve, kind of reserve and we're going to see some small movements and bad based in experience we see it as it goes word. So nothing really exciting to report. It's just an adjustment.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes on the line of Rick Nelson of Stephens.
componenttext: Your next question comes on the line of Rick Nelson of Stephens.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering you're either seeing any changes of retail vehicles. Obviously, one of the allegedly group sees those sales. I think you enhance their brand name and obviously, you guys have a very strong brand name. But any thoughts there? And in ge
componenttext: I was just wondering you're either seeing any changes of retail vehicles. Obviously, one of the allegedly group sees those sales. I think you enhance their brand name and obviously, you guys have a very strong brand name. But any thoughts there? And in general, how do repos operationally?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: We talked about this in the last call, we don't have -- we're not authorized to repair because of that our stores. And obviously, we call environment has change over the last several years. We think that was think is being completely transfer and with our
componenttext: We talked about this in the last call, we don't have -- we're not authorized to repair because of that our stores. And obviously, we call environment has change over the last several years. We think that was think is being completely transfer and with our customers making sure that they're fully informed. And also that they register on the main website because I mean we can sell them a car today and a recall can come next week, and it wouldn't have mattered whether or not we did anything for the car, and I think it's very important that they're notified. we're the only retailer that -- we're the only car retailer that has a direct link to the website. And it's VIN-specific, and we pre-populate the VIN and so any customer that's on the CarMax website can recall the information in each and every individual car. And then, during the sales process, we'll make sure that we point out to every customer the recall status. We help them register with a manufacturer and historically, the relationship, as it relates to recalls of between the manufacturer the customer wants of the car and we want to make sure that customers are fully informed get that information going forward. So our policy is 100% transparency as it relates to recalls.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, great. Understood. And then just, in general, where do you guys third-party lead generators what are the proportion of sales through those sites in the quarter?
componenttext: Great, great. Understood. And then just, in general, where do you guys third-party lead generators what are the proportion of sales through those sites in the quarter?

componenttext: We never talked about proportion of sales, but we've been asked about Cars.com and AutoTrader.com, and we have not used those sites for a long time.

componenttext: What I'm basically asking, are you having inventory issues there? It sounds like similar to what you're talking about with SUVs that at all?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Tom Reedy, you mentioned before Q&A that you're on the low end of your leverage. So can we infer that you're not going to pay back the incremental revolver borrowing anytime soon?
componenttext: Okay. And then Tom Reedy, you mentioned before Q&A that you're on the low end of your leverage. So can we infer that you're not going to pay back the incremental revolver borrowing anytime soon?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair -- I mean, the revolver balance is going to be something that's quite seasonal. As you know we buy inventory in the fall and we sell through it in the winter and into the spring. So it's there to manage liquidity. But as I mentioned, I
componenttext: I think that's fair -- I mean, the revolver balance is going to be something that's quite seasonal. As you know we buy inventory in the fall and we sell through it in the winter and into the spring. So it's there to manage liquidity. But as I mentioned, I think we've kind of got a target range of leverage we'd like to manage to. I would expect to keep adding debt as we go forward and buying back stock to manage to that level. And it wouldn't be out of the question for us to do something. Think about the revolvers kind of like if you look at our Cotuit facilities on the asset back side. It's something that we can use manage liquidity, but then when you get into critical mass, it would take it out of a longer-term instrument.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain of Morgan Stanley.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our most important metric is sales. And then we've just been able to manage gross profit per unit very consistently over time. We want to make sure that given our consumers value. One of the things that we are very focused on is continuing to aggressively
componenttext: Our most important metric is sales. And then we've just been able to manage gross profit per unit very consistently over time. We want to make sure that given our consumers value. One of the things that we are very focused on is continuing to aggressively manage our costs because the price of the consumer it is not just of the margin but also because that we put during the reconditioning process, and we continue to put enormous efforts around the engineering that we -- we have turned our reconditioning process into an engineer process, and we want to continue to try to figure out on lower our cost so we can still deliver great price to the consumer in maintain our margin so that we're deliver a good return for our shareholders.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

componenttext: Understood. And then on a most strategic front, I wanted to talk about their partnerships with like our share of business. As we see some of these businesses, big and small, looking to partner with dealers on 2 fronts, either to buy or sell your car or in some cases, just utilize the used car sitting on delivering us and others are free. How do you feel about these partnerships between guys sharing firms and dealer businesses? Are there potential hurdles of this type of arrangements? Or maybe there are no issues and it make sense to make some money on used cars while sitting on the loan?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: We haven't really explored those avenues for us. The one thing I would say is it is an incredibly fragmented business and a huge marketplace. There are over 40 million cars  used cars sold annually in the U.S. We're a very small fraction of that. So as I
componenttext: We haven't really explored those avenues for us. The one thing I would say is it is an incredibly fragmented business and a huge marketplace. There are over 40 million cars  used cars sold annually in the U.S. We're a very small fraction of that. So as I said, we haven't looked at those things in particular, but we try to pay attention to all of things that are available in the market place and see if we think there's an opportunity for us. But right now, our biggest opportunity is continue to grow the business in markets that we're not in, continue to add stores back into places where we already have a presence. We're only reaching was 60% of the U.S. population. I think we have incredible growth in front of us. And right now, those are the kinds of things that we're focused on.

componenttext: Yes, I think the way I can respond to that is that like I said, our going to be a market-driven lender at CAF, and we're going to make sure we're doing the best thing for our customers. But as I said, we'll stay competitive. If we see the need to move, we will, but at this point, we don't feel going to any longer-term financing.

componenttext: Well, Matt, as I said, I think we've kind of got into the lower end of the leverage range that we've been targeted. Can't comment on what would do anything because market conditions could be  in the future, could be all over the board. I just think you should take away that we're going to continue using it. We're going to continue using a programmatic approach. You saw in the quarter that we stepped up volume based on what the stock price did. But a go-forward basis, it's probably more of the managing the structure perspective rather than moving to a new capital structure.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and thank you for joining our earnings conference call. On the call with me today, as usual, are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO. Let me remind you that our statemen
componenttext:
Thank you, and thank you for joining our earnings conference call. On the call with me today, as usual, are Tom Folliard, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO. 
Let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them.
For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 28, 2015, filed with the SEC.
Before I turn the call over to Tom, I would like to mention that our next regularly scheduled Richmond Home Office Analyst Day will take place on January 20. If you're interested in attending, please let us know. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. You saw, we had a challenging third quarter, due primarily to slightly negative used unit comps. Here are some of the key highlights for the quarter.Used unit comps decreased by 0.
componenttext:
Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. You saw, we had a challenging third quarter, due primarily to slightly negative used unit comps. Here are some of the key highlights for the quarter.
Used unit comps decreased by 0.8%, while total used units grew by 3.2%. Gross profit per used unit of $2,160 was in line with gross profit per unit of $2,172 in the third quarter of last year. And total wholesale units grew 3.4%, about the same rate as total retail units. Gross profit per wholesale unit grew by $22 to $949 per car sold. CAF income also grew 3% to approximately $92 million. I'll turn it over to Tom Reedy to talk about finance. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. As Tom mentioned, CAF income grew by 3% compared to third quarter fiscal '15, and average managed receivables grew by 15% to $9.3 billion. The weighted average contract rate charged to customers was 7.3%, up somewhat
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. As Tom mentioned, CAF income grew by 3% compared to third quarter fiscal '15, and average managed receivables grew by 15% to $9.3 billion. The weighted average contract rate charged to customers was 7.3%, up somewhat from last year's third quarter of 7.0%. Our total interest margin declined to 6.0% of average managed receivables from 6.4% in the third quarter of last year and 6.2% last quarter.
We saw some tick-up in charge-offs during the quarter, which resulted in a modest increase in the loss provision. However, at $91 million, our ending allowance for loan losses was 0.97% of managed receivables, consistent with last year's third quarter at 0.98%.
CAF net penetration was 42.9% compared with 41.8% in last year's third quarter. The increase reflects a mix shift towards higher credit applications in the stores. The percent of CAF penetration attributable to our subprime test was unchanged at about 0.5%. Net loan dollars originated in the quarter rose 6% year-over-year to $1.2 billion due to combination of CarMax unit sales growth and higher penetration.
As you saw on the press release, Tier 3 financing, as a percent of sales is 150 basis points lower than in the third quarter of fiscal 2015. This decrease was primarily due to the mix shift I mentioned with regard to CAF penetration. In Q3, we experienced a year-over-year decline in the number of credit applications across the lower end of credit, but moderate growth at the higher end.
During the third quarter, we repurchased 7.7 million shares for about $446 million. We ended the quarter at the low end of our target range for leverage, which is book debt-to-capital after backing up the notes in receivables associated with nonrecourse securitizations of 35% to 45%. Going forward, we expect to continue using share repurchase as a means of managing capital structure and returning value to shareholders.
Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. As a percentage of our sales mix this quarter, 0- to 4-year-old cars increased to approximately 81% compared to 75% in the third quarter of last year and 79% in the second quarter. SUVs and trucks, as a percentage of sales, were 23%, down from
componenttext:
Thank you. As a percentage of our sales mix this quarter, 0- to 4-year-old cars increased to approximately 81% compared to 75% in the third quarter of last year and 79% in the second quarter. SUVs and trucks, as a percentage of sales, were 23%, down from 25% in last year's third quarter, but up slightly from 22% in the second quarter.
Our lower used unit comps were primarily result of modestly lower traffic in our stores, partially offset by better conversion. Total web traffic increased by 7% compared to the same period last year. We believe our cost may have been impacted by several factors of note this quarter. First, we've seen a decrease in the supply of 5- to 10-year-old cars, as you would expect. Second, we've seen very aggressive promotions and lease offerings from new vehicles that appear to be pressuring sales of 0- and 1-year-old cars. Wholesale prices of SUVs and trucks have increased, so some don't represent a good value for our customers. And as Tom mentioned, Tier 3 was down about 150 basis points due to lower credit applications. Now despite these factors, we still sold over 154,000 cars during the quarter, which is the most ever in a third quarter for the company. And our average store during the quarter sold 340 cars.
SG&A for the third quarter increased about 7% to $338 million. Contributing to this growth was the 10% increase in our store base since the beginning of the third quarter of last year, partially offset by a decrease of $6.5 million in share-based compensation expense. In addition, our advertising expense grew by about $9 million year-over-year, reflecting the timing of expenses related to our new ad campaign. 
During the third quarter, we opened 2 stores in existing markets, our sixth store in Houston and our second store in Minneapolis. We also relocated our Rockville, Maryland store to its new larger location in Gaithersburg. And after the end of the quarter, we entered the Boston market with the opening of 2 stores in Danvers and Norwood.
And with that, operator, we will open it up for questions.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler of Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question relates to SUVs. I know you guys were down about 200 basis points year-on-year. Do you have a sense for what the used market is doing for SUV mix, in general? In other words, do you think used market sales of SUV -- do you think the mix
componenttext: My first question relates to SUVs. I know you guys were down about 200 basis points year-on-year. Do you have a sense for what the used market is doing for SUV mix, in general? In other words, do you think used market sales of SUV -- do you think the mix of SUVs to the market is down, is flat, is it up? Or are you differing in the way you're indexing on SUVs versus your broader competition?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure versus the broader competition, Matt, but we were up a point compared to the second quarter, and we still sold a lot of trucks and SUVs in the quarter, 23% of our total sales. But as I mentioned, our prices were pretty high during the quarter
componenttext: I'm not sure versus the broader competition, Matt, but we were up a point compared to the second quarter, and we still sold a lot of trucks and SUVs in the quarter, 23% of our total sales. But as I mentioned, our prices were pretty high during the quarter. And as you know, we buy a lot of cars at the auction and our buyers are trying to make sure we always deliver a great value to our customers. So there are times during the quarter and we just didn't think it was worth overpaying at the expense of given a great value to the consumer. I think this is probably short lived. Obviously, it has been driven by low gas prices. We've seen bigger increases in new car sales as it relates to SUVs and trucks compared to the used car market increases. But ultimately, these cars will all come back into the market at some point.

componenttext: Really, we just wanted to point out that we launched a new campaign during the quarter and that this just -- it wouldn't be a typical increase for us in terms of our quarter-over-quarter expense, given that the sales level that we had. So we weren't really trying to say came from one place to the other. Just, this is not what you -- did expect typically from us on a year-over-year basis. We did create and launched a new campaign during the quarter that started in September.

componenttext: Yes, it's very early to judge. Particularly when you have a new broadcast campaign, it's mostly around brand building and not necessarily for short-term sales gain. You guys know we're not promotional. We don't have sales. So most of our campaigns are long-term brand building.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first, I think, my first question is just basically follow up to what Matt asked. But Tom, thanks for laying out some of the extra cover there with regard to sales in the quarter. How do we think about -- if you take those individually, how do we think
componenttext: So first, I think, my first question is just basically follow up to what Matt asked. But Tom, thanks for laying out some of the extra cover there with regard to sales in the quarter. How do we think about -- if you take those individually, how do we think about the, I guess, the trajectory from here? I mean, it seems that the comments you made that some of those factors will begin to abate here. But maybe a little more color on that as to how we should think about these factors going into the balance of this fiscal year and into 2016.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: One, it's very difficult to attribute a number of points to each of the factors. It's just all things that we noted during the quarter. We also had our toughest comparison of the year, which I didn't mention. And our 2-year stack comp in the third quarter
componenttext: One, it's very difficult to attribute a number of points to each of the factors. It's just all things that we noted during the quarter. We also had our toughest comparison of the year, which I didn't mention. And our 2-year stack comp in the third quarter was actually higher than it was in the second quarter. But I think each of these things had a little bit of an impact on our ability to deliver during the quarter. Most of them, I think, are short lived. It's very difficult to predict trends and when things are going to change and supply, but I think we've done a really nice job over the last several years of being able to adjust and adapt to changing trends in the used car marketplace, I think we'll do the same here. I just thought those are the things we should have pointed out during the quarter. A lot of the supply stuff is going to take care of itself over time. And we're going to take advantage of the things that present themselves to us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then so maybe a follow-up to that, I think there's a lot of comments or commentary out there about new competitors coming into your marketplace. Have you seen anything new with respect to this -- your stores that may compete more directly with
componenttext: Got it. And then so maybe a follow-up to that, I think there's a lot of comments or commentary out there about new competitors coming into your marketplace. Have you seen anything new with respect to this -- your stores that may compete more directly with some of these new competition?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we -- it's an ever-changing marketplace. A lot of the stuff we've seen is around additional capabilities, which we're working really hard to continue to increase for our customers. And as I mentioned, remember, our average store sold 340 cars a mo
componenttext: I mean, we -- it's an ever-changing marketplace. A lot of the stuff we've seen is around additional capabilities, which we're working really hard to continue to increase for our customers. And as I mentioned, remember, our average store sold 340 cars a month during the quarter. If you look at industry data, the average new car dealer sells about 50 cars a month. So it's really hard to say that we're losing ground, and a lot of the stuff that you read about for -- from new competition are very small players in very limited markets. So it's not likely that we're seeing an impact across the nation for our 153 stores when a lot of the pressure is seen around very small players in limited markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, obviously, you've seen these cycles, in terms of, kind of how the wholesale market adjust to maybe supply/demand anomalies. So on this note, kind of conversation around SUVs, could you kind of provide some historical perspective perhaps ab
componenttext: Okay. And then, obviously, you've seen these cycles, in terms of, kind of how the wholesale market adjust to maybe supply/demand anomalies. So on this note, kind of conversation around SUVs, could you kind of provide some historical perspective perhaps about anomalies you might have seen in the past and kind of how long a correction might take in the pricing on the wholesale market?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I can probably comment on some anomalies in the past, but in terms of how long the correction takes place, it is, I think, there's too many macro factors involved. But we are seeing, the highest SAAR we've ever seen and the bigger of the increase
componenttext: I mean, I can probably comment on some anomalies in the past, but in terms of how long the correction takes place, it is, I think, there's too many macro factors involved. But we are seeing, the highest SAAR we've ever seen and the bigger of the increase of the SAAR is related to trucks and SUVs, if I was thinking about that over a long period of time, that means a couple of years from now, we'll see a lot of trucks and SUVs out in the wholesale market, which if there's demand, then we'll be able to take advantage of that and buy and sell them. I think the other big variable that's impossible to predict is first, gas prices; and then second the impact of gas prices. I know you remember back in the spring of '08 when gas hit $4, nobody would buy an SUV of any kind. But in October of that same year, gas was below $2 and things kind of went back to where they were. Since then, when we've seen gas prices increase, we haven't seen the same knee-jerk reaction that we saw. So gas prices have been pretty low for a while, and I think it's provided a boost for trucks and SUVs. But it's really hard to say what will happen in Florida. I just think our model is best equipped to take advantage of whatever the market brings. We're not holding to any manufacturer or any type of product, and we want to sell whatever the customer wants to buy.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

componenttext: I want to violate Katharine's 2-question rule. Just one last follow-up, I guess. What you're seeing right now, would you characterize as kind of normal ebbs and flows that you've seen in the market over time? Or is there anything like as you longer-term more of fundamental concerns?
