componenttext: We did not quantify it, but of the $9 million difference year-over-year, the majority of it was around the new launch.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, obviously, you've seen these cycles, in terms of kind of how the wholesale market adjusts to maybe supply/demand anomalies. So on this whole kind of conversation around SUVs, could you kind of provide some historical perspective perhaps ab
componenttext: Okay. And then, obviously, you've seen these cycles, in terms of kind of how the wholesale market adjusts to maybe supply/demand anomalies. So on this whole kind of conversation around SUVs, could you kind of provide some historical perspective perhaps about anomalies you might have seen in the past and kind of how long a correction might take in the pricing on the wholesale market?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I can probably comment on some anomalies in the past, but in terms of how long the correction takes there's -- I think, there's too many macro factors involved. But we are seeing the highest SAAR we've ever seen and the bigger of the increase of t
componenttext: I mean, I can probably comment on some anomalies in the past, but in terms of how long the correction takes there's -- I think, there's too many macro factors involved. But we are seeing the highest SAAR we've ever seen and the bigger of the increase of the SAAR is related to trucks and SUVs. If I was thinking about that over a long period of time, that means a couple of years from now, we'll see a lot of trucks and SUVs out in the wholesale market, which if there's demand, then we'll be able to take advantage of that and buy and sell them. I think the other big variable that's impossible to predict is first, gas prices, and then second the impact of gas prices. I know you remember back in the spring of '08 when gas hit $4, nobody would buy an SUV of any kind. But in October of that same year, gas was below $2 and things kind of went back to where they were. Since then, when we've seen gas prices increase, we haven't seen the same knee-jerk reaction that we saw. So gas prices have been pretty low for a while, and I think it's provided a boost for trucks and SUVs. But it's really hard to say what will happen going forward. I just think our model is best equipped to take advantage of whatever the market brings. We're not holding to any manufacturer or any type of product, and we want to sell whatever the customer wants to buy.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to violate Katharine's 2-question rule. Just one last follow-up, I guess. What you're seeing right now, would you characterize as kind of the normal ebbs and flows that you've seen in the market over time? Or is there anything that gives you longer
componenttext: I want to violate Katharine's 2-question rule. Just one last follow-up, I guess. What you're seeing right now, would you characterize as kind of the normal ebbs and flows that you've seen in the market over time? Or is there anything that gives you longer-term more fundamental concerns?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we don't see anything that causes us long-term concerns.
componenttext: No, we don't see anything that causes us long-term concerns.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison of Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison of Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know it's early, but you did just enter the Boston market. And I'm curious if you've seen any or had any surprises as you enter that market.
componenttext: I know it's early, but you did just enter the Boston market. And I'm curious if you've seen any or had any surprises as you enter that market.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've been over for less than a week. So I really couldn't -- I'm not going to comment.
componenttext: We've been over for less than a week. So I really couldn't -- I'm not going to comment.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Even from a staffing standpoint, you're able to staff the different types of positions you need?
componenttext: Even from a staffing standpoint, you're able to staff the different types of positions you need?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: We were able to staff. I will say Boston was a bit challenging with staffing, but our teams did a great job of finding a bunch of really great people, and we're very excited about our go-forward there.
componenttext: We were able to staff. I will say Boston was a bit challenging with staffing, but our teams did a great job of finding a bunch of really great people, and we're very excited about our go-forward there.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of technology, could you cover, Tom, your priorities for the next 12 months in terms of digital and technology initiatives?
componenttext: And then in terms of technology, could you cover, Tom, your priorities for the next 12 months in terms of digital and technology initiatives?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, our priorities are somewhat unchanged. We want to keep making sure that our customers have a great experience regardless of how they interact with CarMax. It could be from a desktop, it could be from a mobile device, a tablet or in the store, and we
componenttext: Well, our priorities are somewhat unchanged. We want to keep making sure that our customers have a great experience regardless of how they interact with CarMax. It could be from a desktop, it could be from a mobile device, a tablet or in the store, and we're very focused on making the transition from their digital experience to the store simple and seamless so that they -- the experience they have online matches up with the experience that they have in the store. And we're also pushing real hard over the next 12 months or so to make sure that our store teams are equipped with information that's available regarding the individual customers to try to make their experience more personalized. We have a very big database of customers, and we're working to make sure that we can access that information and that our associates in the store can access the information when the customers arrive. And also, we want to just keep increasing capabilities of customers if they want to do more and more of the transaction online.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy of Bank of America.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a first question, and Tom, as we think about sort of these tougher comps, I mean, basically, we're looking at multi-decade lows in the 0- to 5-year-old portion of the fleet in absolute terms. And certainly, 30-plus year lows as far as the percentage
componenttext: Just a first question, and Tom, as we think about sort of these tougher comps, I mean, basically, we're looking at multi-decade lows in the 0- to 5-year-old portion of the fleet in absolute terms. And certainly, 30-plus year lows as far as the percentage of the total population of cars outstanding. So I mean, as we see that 0- to 5-year-old bucket grow in the next 1, 2 or 3 years, don't you just sort of naturally -- wouldn't you just naturally expect your same-store sales to recover as addressable market recovers? And sort of the pressure we're seeing here is just function of the supply?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I expect us to be able to comp our stores over a long period of time. And I think there's lots of external factors that either help or hurt. I've always felt like the supply of 0- to 5-year-old cars increasing is good for us. It's an area where on a
componenttext: Well, I expect us to be able to comp our stores over a long period of time. And I think there's lots of external factors that either help or hurt. I've always felt like the supply of 0- to 5-year-old cars increasing is good for us. It's an area where on a market share basis, if you look at an individual year-to-year basis, we have -- it's been kind of our sweet spot. So I mean, I agree, as the supply increases there, I think we'll do better in those segments. What I feel even -- what I also feel good about is coming out of the recession, we did a really good job of figuring out how to sell older cars as well. And I feel like we can do both. So you look at the CarMax consumer offer on its 0- to 10-year-old cars, and I think we're pretty good across the spectrum at near-new cars and then older cars with higher miles. I don't think anybody does as good a job reconditioning as we do. I don't think anybody is in a better position to take advantage of those sales as we are.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just sort of a follow-up on the second question. I mean, when you look at the gap of new versus used pricing and then you look at the financing offerings that are at -- in the new vehicle dealers for new vehicles. It just seems like it's ve
componenttext: Okay. And then just sort of a follow-up on the second question. I mean, when you look at the gap of new versus used pricing and then you look at the financing offerings that are at -- in the new vehicle dealers for new vehicles. It just seems like it's very compelling for a 0 to 5 or even 0 to 10 consumer to trip into buying a new vehicle. I mean, if you look at a 0- to 5-year-old car, basically, the gap on a monthly payment basis is $150 or actually potentially significantly less depending on what kind of financing they get at the new vehicle dealership. I mean, how do you kind of fight that tide? I mean, and do you think you just need that supply plus pricing to come down to create a wider gap to drive those consumers back into used vehicles? Because it's incredibly tight right now. I'm just trying to understand how that dynamic might change, and if there's anything you can do to help change it.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's not like this doesn't happen -- it hasn't happened before. There are always pockets or segments of near-new cars that given the incentive environment whether it's through cashback or leasing, oftentimes, consumers will make that decision. It do
componenttext: Well, it's not like this doesn't happen -- it hasn't happened before. There are always pockets or segments of near-new cars that given the incentive environment whether it's through cashback or leasing, oftentimes, consumers will make that decision. It doesn't mean they won't come back to us 3 or 4 or 5 years later when they're buying something different. And I do want to point out our average car is around $20,000 and the average new car is around $33,000. So the difference, on average, has not come down at all. In fact, it's widened. But it's always true that at any given point in time, given -- depending on the incentive environment that there are some close calls there, and I think it was especially true this quarter, and that's why I pointed it out.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of James Albertine of Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of James Albertine of Stifel.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just another follow-up on the trends you're seeing in the new cycle. And quite frankly, you've lived through a lot of obstacles and a lot of other headwinds over the last 20 years. It doesn't seem like there's anything you can't weather. But it seems like
componenttext: Just another follow-up on the trends you're seeing in the new cycle. And quite frankly, you've lived through a lot of obstacles and a lot of other headwinds over the last 20 years. It doesn't seem like there's anything you can't weather. But it seems like this time might be a little different, particularly among the domestic manufacturers, given the propensity to lease. Is there a higher likelihood that some of this new vehicles that are selling on the SUV and truck side go back to dealers rather than hitting the auction market and that -- could that limit your availability of supply in the coming years? Or is that something that you've considered and aren't really worried about?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's something we've lived through before in terms of percent of new car sales that are leased. I think the number now is around 30%. It's been this high at times before. Generally, what that means is 2, 3 years down the road, those cars will come b
componenttext: Well, it's something we've lived through before in terms of percent of new car sales that are leased. I think the number now is around 30%. It's been this high at times before. Generally, what that means is 2, 3 years down the road, those cars will come back to the market in a kind of a more organized way. And dealers won't be able to absorb the volume that comes back, and a lot of those cars end up at auction. And that's what's happened historically. And we've been able to take advantage of that in the past. I never look at a high lease environment as a negative for us when you think about supply 2 or 3 years later. If you think about this cycle of people getting out of a new car, if it remains that people get out of their car every 3 to 5 years, it really doesn't make any difference whether it comes back through a lease channel or it comes back as an individual car. Eventually, they end up in the open market place, and we have an opportunity to buy them.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, and that ties, I think, with your 340 cars per month kind of versus 50 per month average that you made earlier. There's just not the capacity for the dealers to handle the off lease. So I appreciate that color. And then a quick follow-up on the cr
componenttext: Got it, and that ties, I think, with your 340 cars per month kind of versus 50 per month average that you made earlier. There's just not the capacity for the dealers to handle the off lease. So I appreciate that color. And then a quick follow-up on the credit market now that we've finally seen a rate increase, and if you look over the last few CAF securitizations, it appears as though the spread might be stabilizing. But really wanted to get kind of update there as to what you think -- if we are near that stabilization point. Or even now that rates are up, sort of optically, consumers are now expecting higher rates. Does that allow you now to sort of increase the APR and maybe even see that spread expand in the near term?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. As far as the spread to the customer goes, that's really going to be market-dependent as we've said in the past. Our first goal of CarMax Auto Finance is to a provide a competitive offer to the customer, and we will go where the market dictat
componenttext: This is Tom. As far as the spread to the customer goes, that's really going to be market-dependent as we've said in the past. Our first goal of CarMax Auto Finance is to a provide a competitive offer to the customer, and we will go where the market dictates we go. That said, we're constantly testing both up and down to make sure we're optimizing CarMax sales and CAF income at the same time. We have seen a little bit of cost of funds increase this year. We have been testing rates upward a little bit. But I really can't give you any kind of forward-looking theory on where that spread will go because it's going to be market rate based. Historically, as rates have come up, we've been a little bit, as the market has, slower to adjust upward because rates tend to be sticky. And conversely when rates have been coming down, they're usual a little slow to adjust downward because the market is going to drive that as well, and you see a little bit of a benefit. But as far as going forward, the market will tell. I think now that the Fed has given some guidance, I think, about where they're going with interest rates that's stabilized things from the perspective of spread in the asset-backed market. We saw our spreads gap up in the last year versus prior deals even though we are in a lower interest rate environment. But I think some of that was uncertainty around what the Fed was going to do.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Lyn Walter (sic) [Walther] of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Lyn Walter (sic) [Walther] of Wells Fargo.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just regarding traffic, can you talk about was that consistent throughout the quarter? Any regions that you saw more impact than others?
componenttext: Just regarding traffic, can you talk about was that consistent throughout the quarter? Any regions that you saw more impact than others?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't give regional or quarterly  differences. I said what it was for the quarter, and that's all the information we give.
componenttext: Yes, we don't give regional or quarterly  differences. I said what it was for the quarter, and that's all the information we give.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me just ask one other one then, if that's okay. Just following up on your digital capabilities that you're talking about adding. How should we think about the kind of investments required to bring those up to what you're talking about?
componenttext: Okay. Let me just ask one other one then, if that's okay. Just following up on your digital capabilities that you're talking about adding. How should we think about the kind of investments required to bring those up to what you're talking about?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of the investment can be done within our normal spend over the course of the year. We have a pretty significant spend in both IT and marketing and a lot of the investments that we'll be making can go over that normal course. But we are looking
componenttext: Well, a lot of the investment can be done within our normal spend over the course of the year. We have a pretty significant spend in both IT and marketing and a lot of the investments that we'll be making can go over that normal course. But we are looking forward at what types of bigger investments might we need to make. And when we have something to talk about there, we'll let everyone know.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky of KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions for you. The lower traffic that you called out in your release, what do you think are the drivers? Is it the lack of the SUVs and trucks you pointed out as a difficult supply right now? Or is it perhaps competition and new entrants into the
componenttext: Two questions for you. The lower traffic that you called out in your release, what do you think are the drivers? Is it the lack of the SUVs and trucks you pointed out as a difficult supply right now? Or is it perhaps competition and new entrants into the market who are competing in the stand-alone used vehicle stores?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's really hard to say. But I do want to point out, we did get enough traffic to sell 340 cars a month per store. And it was only slightly down. And then conversion was slightly up. And we ended up where we ended up. But in terms of traffic through the d
componenttext: It's really hard to say. But I do want to point out, we did get enough traffic to sell 340 cars a month per store. And it was only slightly down. And then conversion was slightly up. And we ended up where we ended up. But in terms of traffic through the door, I think there's a chance that customers are being more prepared and are more likely to buy when they show up. And for us, if we could get traffic that's more prepared and more likely to buy, that's just as good for us as it is if we just got plain old extra traffic. So it's not as easy an answer as you might think. But we had a lot of traffic in our stores during the quarter. It was just slightly down compared to last year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the second question for you. You mentioned in your opening remarks one of the headwinds impacting the comps was the lower supply of 0- to 5-year-old cars. Is that as in general to what we've been hearing? Or are you seeing an actual sequential pullbac
componenttext: And the second question for you. You mentioned in your opening remarks one of the headwinds impacting the comps was the lower supply of 0- to 5-year-old cars. Is that as in general to what we've been hearing? Or are you seeing an actual sequential pullback in this supply from, let's say, in the second or the first quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, when I mentioned supply, I said the supply was down in 5 to 10-year-old cars, not 0 to 5. And in 5 to 10-year-old cars, it just makes sense since the SAAR that you're building off of in years 6, 7 or 8 was dramatically lower than what the SAAR i
componenttext: Actually, when I mentioned supply, I said the supply was down in 5 to 10-year-old cars, not 0 to 5. And in 5 to 10-year-old cars, it just makes sense since the SAAR that you're building off of in years 6, 7 or 8 was dramatically lower than what the SAAR is today. Remember, we had a SAAR as low as 10 in September of '08. So I was referencing the supply of older cars.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Montani of Evercore.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Montani of Evercore.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about if you could just talk us through how you think about managing the business in terms of balancing inventory turns with gross profit dollars per unit. Generally speaking, some of the publicly traded dealer peers have shown a little bi
componenttext: I wanted to ask about if you could just talk us through how you think about managing the business in terms of balancing inventory turns with gross profit dollars per unit. Generally speaking, some of the publicly traded dealer peers have shown a little bit higher used unit comps but then they've also shown greater erosion in terms of GPUs. So just trying to think through how you would run the business and any tests you may have had tweaking either those 2 elements.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've talked about this in the past. We run pricing tests on a pretty regular basis. You can also see we've been very consistent with the margins that we've been able to achieve. So look, there's no way to go back and say, "Look what if we had lower
componenttext: Yes, we've talked about this in the past. We run pricing tests on a pretty regular basis. You can also see we've been very consistent with the margins that we've been able to achieve. So look, there's no way to go back and say, "Look what if we had lower prices, how many more cars would we have sold?" My guess is we probably gave up a little bit of share by maintaining our prices during the quarter, but it's impossible to quantify. I don't think, however, that we gave up gross margin dollars. And I don't think that we -- I think we try to make the decision that's in the best interest of our shareholders each and every quarter. So we did see the decline in margins that some of the other publicly traded auto retailers reported ending September. And it maybe helped their comps a little bit, but as far as we are concerned, we can only make the best decision we can with the information that we have, and that's what we did during the quarter. And we're okay with the results.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could just follow up on one, which is the leverage point. I believe in the past, you've said 4% to 5% being the comp that you would need to show leverage. And obviously, the commentary today is that there's no change to the outlook for
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could just follow up on one, which is the leverage point. I believe in the past, you've said 4% to 5% being the comp that you would need to show leverage. And obviously, the commentary today is that there's no change to the outlook for future year store growth. So should we assume that's the same because I know there's a lot of initiatives that you guys are working on in terms of cost to try and improve that as well.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think -- we've always said kind of mid-single digits. We've never really put an exact number on it. It's also dependent on the rate of growth during any given quarter. It's also dependent on the type of growth during the quarter, opening up in a b
componenttext: Yes, we think -- we've always said kind of mid-single digits. We've never really put an exact number on it. It's also dependent on the rate of growth during any given quarter. It's also dependent on the type of growth during the quarter, opening up in a big metro market is more expensive than opening up smaller stores. And as you saw during this quarter, there's occasionally some timing of expenses that's going to impact it. But I think, if you think about it over a long period of time with the growth plan that we have publicly announced mid-single digits or so, I think we can leverage our SG&A dollars.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong of CL King & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong of CL King & Associates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just getting back to the SUV light-truck mix. If we look at total industry sales 2012 through '14, about 50% of total sales were light trucks, so call it SUVs and pickups. Your sales and inventory mix clearly is much less. So are you seeing -- are you not
componenttext: Just getting back to the SUV light-truck mix. If we look at total industry sales 2012 through '14, about 50% of total sales were light trucks, so call it SUVs and pickups. Your sales and inventory mix clearly is much less. So are you seeing -- are you not seeing that many of those vehicles available for sale? Or is it they are maybe not in the condition that you want to re-retail? What, like what -- there seems to be a disconnect there.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Did you say -- I didn't hear what you said about the mix. Did you say 50%?
componenttext: Did you say -- I didn't hear what you said about the mix. Did you say 50%?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: 50% of all car -- vehicles sold from 2012 to 2014 were light, classified as light trucks, so SUVs and pickups, basically.
componenttext: 50% of all car -- vehicles sold from 2012 to 2014 were light, classified as light trucks, so SUVs and pickups, basically.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I haven't heard that number before but I believe you, but that's never been the case for us. I mean, we've always been in the mid-20s. So this isn't...
componenttext: Yes. I haven't heard that number before but I believe you, but that's never been the case for us. I mean, we've always been in the mid-20s. So this isn't...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's not the same metric.
componenttext: It's not the same metric.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hold on a second.
componenttext: Hold on a second.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: His metric included crossover -- it's much broader. Ours is just light trucks, medium and large SUVs.
componenttext: His metric included crossover -- it's much broader. Ours is just light trucks, medium and large SUVs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our 23% is medium and large SUVs and pickup trucks. I think the 50% includes crossovers and smaller SUVs. So that's not in our number. And I don't have that number handy to tell you what the mix was. I think, in general, over time, we are going to look a
componenttext: Our 23% is medium and large SUVs and pickup trucks. I think the 50% includes crossovers and smaller SUVs. So that's not in our number. And I don't have that number handy to tell you what the mix was. I think, in general, over time, we are going to look a lot like the industry looks. Our sample is very large. We're very widespread across the country. And in general, we're going to look like the industry looks over time. I mean, that's where our supply comes from, and we're going to match up with consumer demand. It's never going to be exact, particularly on a quarter-to-quarter basis. But if you look at what we have historically reported in trucks and SUV's, it's generally been in the mid-20s, sometimes the high 20s. This quarter was 23%. It was up a point from the time before. Remember that we're talking about 2 different measures.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. Do you feel like maybe you're missing some opportunity then with the SUVs or not necessarily?
componenttext: Okay, got it. Do you feel like maybe you're missing some opportunity then with the SUVs or not necessarily?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said, I think during the quarter, there was a chance that we could have paid more. It's not like the cars weren't out there. But we're always trying to deliver a great value to the consumer as well. So there are always times when certain things
componenttext: Well, as I said, I think during the quarter, there was a chance that we could have paid more. It's not like the cars weren't out there. But we're always trying to deliver a great value to the consumer as well. So there are always times when certain things at the auction, we just think they're too expensive, and we don't want to buy them and then turn around and resell them. So we wait. And I think the same thing is true here. We've been around a long time, we've seen cycles go up and cycles go down and as I mentioned earlier, who knows what happens with gas prices. You see a big spike in gas prices and there's a good chance our SUV mix would go up during that time because those cars would be cheaper and be a better value to our customers. But I did mention it during the quarter. We saw that there was a lot of pressure on SUV pricing.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, that makes sense. If I could just sneak one quick one in. Extended protection plan revenues lag vehicle sales a little bit? Anything to call out there?
componenttext: Got it. Okay, that makes sense. If I could just sneak one quick one in. Extended protection plan revenues lag vehicle sales a little bit? Anything to call out there?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Nothing in particular. In general, we'd expect that business to grow with unit sales. This quarter, we had some adjustments in the return reserve. Remember that's like $100 million reserve, $100-plus million reserve and we're going to see small movements
componenttext: Nothing in particular. In general, we'd expect that business to grow with unit sales. This quarter, we had some adjustments in the return reserve. Remember that's like $100 million reserve, $100-plus million reserve and we're going to see small movements in that based on experience as we see it as it goes forward. So nothing really exciting to report. It's just an adjustment.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rick Nelson of Stephens.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rick Nelson of Stephens.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Nick Zangler in for Rick. I was wondering, are you guys considering any changes in the policy of selling recalled vehicles? Obviously, one of the larger dealer groups ceased those sales, I think, to enhance their brand name. And obviously, you guy
componenttext: This is Nick Zangler in for Rick. I was wondering, are you guys considering any changes in the policy of selling recalled vehicles? Obviously, one of the larger dealer groups ceased those sales, I think, to enhance their brand name. And obviously, you guys have a very strong brand name, but any thoughts there? And in general, how do recalled cars affect you, operationally?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We talked about this on the last call. Remember we don't have -- we're not authorized to repair recalls at our stores. And obviously, the recall environment has changed over the last several years. We think the most important thing is being completel
componenttext: Yes. We talked about this on the last call. Remember we don't have -- we're not authorized to repair recalls at our stores. And obviously, the recall environment has changed over the last several years. We think the most important thing is being completely transparent with our customers and making sure that they're fully informed. And also that they register on the manufacture's website because -- I mean we could sell them a car today and a recall could come out next week, and it wouldn't have mattered whether or not we did anything for the car. And we think it's very important that they're notified. We're the only retailer that -- we're the only car retailer that has a direct link to NHTSA website. And it's VIN-specific, and we pre-populate the VIN. So any customer that's on the CarMax website can look up all recall information on each and every individual car. And then, during the sales process, we make sure that we point out to every customer the recall status. We help them register with the manufacturer. And historically, the relationship as it relates to recalls is between the manufacturer and the customer who owns the car, and we want to make sure that customers are fully informed and get that information going forward. So our policy is 100% transparency as it relates to recalls.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, great. Understood. And then just, in general, where do you guys stand with third-party lead generators? What was the proportion of sales through those sites in the quarter?
componenttext: Great, great. Understood. And then just, in general, where do you guys stand with third-party lead generators? What was the proportion of sales through those sites in the quarter?

componenttext: We never talked about proportion of sales. But we've been asked about Cars.com and AutoTrader.com, and we have not used those sites for a long time.

componenttext: I don't think so.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Tom Reedy, you mentioned before Q&A that you're on the low end of your leverage. So can we infer that you're not going to pay back the incremental revolver borrowing anytime soon?
componenttext: Okay. And Tom Reedy, you mentioned before Q&A that you're on the low end of your leverage. So can we infer that you're not going to pay back the incremental revolver borrowing anytime soon?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair to say. I mean, the revolver balance is going to be something that's quite seasonal. As you know we buy up inventory pretty significantly in the fall and we sell through it in the winter and into the spring. So it's there to manage liq
componenttext: I think that's fair to say. I mean, the revolver balance is going to be something that's quite seasonal. As you know we buy up inventory pretty significantly in the fall and we sell through it in the winter and into the spring. So it's there to manage liquidity. But as I mentioned, I think we've kind of got a target range of leverage we'd like to manage to. I would expect us to keep adding debt as we go forward and buying back stock to manage to that debt level. And it wouldn't be out of the question for us to do something. If you think about the revolvers kind of like you look at our conduit facilities on the asset backed side. It's something that we can use to manage liquidity, but then when you've got critical mass you would take it out with a longer-term instrument.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain of Morgan Stanley.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on Mike's question earlier. So If I'm hearing you right, stable GPU seems to be the more important metric here for CarMax, am I thinking about it right? Or how would you characterize your most important metric? Is it comp or is
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on Mike's question earlier. So If I'm hearing you right, stable GPU seems to be the more important metric here for CarMax, am I thinking about it right? Or how would you characterize your most important metric? Is it comp or is it GPU?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our most important metric is sales. And then we've just been able to manage gross profit per unit very consistently over time. We want to make sure that we're giving our consumers a great value. One of the things that we are very focused on is continuing
componenttext: Our most important metric is sales. And then we've just been able to manage gross profit per unit very consistently over time. We want to make sure that we're giving our consumers a great value. One of the things that we are very focused on is continuing to aggressively manage our costs because the price to the consumer is not just the margin but also the cost that we put into a car during the reconditioning process. And we continue to put enormous efforts around the engineering that we -- we have turned our reconditioning process into an engineering process. And we want to continue to try to figure out how to lower our cost so we can still deliver a great price to the consumer and maintain our margin so that we're delivering a good return for our shareholders.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then on a more strategic front, I wanted to talk about dealer partnerships with ride and car sharing businesses. We see some of these businesses, big and small, looking to partner with dealers on 2 fronts, either to buy or sell the car or
componenttext: Understood. And then on a more strategic front, I wanted to talk about dealer partnerships with ride and car sharing businesses. We see some of these businesses, big and small, looking to partner with dealers on 2 fronts, either to buy or sell the car or in some cases, just utilize that used car sitting on dealer lots and pay dealers a fee. How do you feel about these partnerships between ride sharing firms and dealer businesses? Are there potential hurdles in this type of arrangement? Or maybe there are no issues and it makes sense to make some money on used cars while it's sitting on the lot?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: We haven't really explored those avenues for us. The one thing I would say is it is an incredibly fragmented business and a huge marketplace. There are over 40 million cars -- used cars sold annually in the U.S. We're a very small fraction of that. So as
componenttext: We haven't really explored those avenues for us. The one thing I would say is it is an incredibly fragmented business and a huge marketplace. There are over 40 million cars -- used cars sold annually in the U.S. We're a very small fraction of that. So as I said, we haven't looked at those things in particular, but we try to pay attention to all the things that are available in the market place and see if we think they're an opportunity for us. But right now, our biggest opportunity is to continue to grow the business in markets that we're not in, continue to add stores back into places where we already have a presence. We're only reaching about 60% of the U.S. population. I think we have incredible growth in front of us. And right now, those are the kinds of things that we're focused on.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Iannarone of RBC Market.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Iannarone of RBC Market.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Robert Iannarone on for Scot Ciccarelli. Just a couple of quick questions for you. Some of the credit data that we've tracked has indicated an outsized growth in the 72-month plus financing arm. I was just wondering if you could give us any commentary on
componenttext: Robert Iannarone on for Scot Ciccarelli. Just a couple of quick questions for you. Some of the credit data that we've tracked has indicated an outsized growth in the 72-month plus financing arm. I was just wondering if you could give us any commentary on what you're seeing in customer behavior in their desire for longer-term loans for their vehicles?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the way I can respond to that is that like I said, we're going to be a market-driven lender at CAF, and we're going to make sure we're doing the best thing for our customers. And it's always a balancing act. So we're going to be continually t
componenttext: Yes, I think the way I can respond to that is that like I said, we're going to be a market-driven lender at CAF, and we're going to make sure we're doing the best thing for our customers. And it's always a balancing act. So we're going to be continually testing and seeing what makes sense. I think recent -- the data you might be pointing to, recent Experian data shows about 15% of used volumes getting done at terms longer than 72. We're not sure how much of that is actually pushing out more than a couple of months. But as I said, we'll stay competitive. If we see the need to move, we will. But at this point, we don't feel compelled to rush into any longer-term financing.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one more on advertising. So second quarter in a row now, we've seen the advertising expense tick up. You certainly commented on this in the last couple of calls for us. Just wondering if we should expect that to normalize going forward now
componenttext: Great. And just one more on advertising. So second quarter in a row now, we've seen the advertising expense tick up. You certainly commented on this in the last couple of calls for us. Just wondering if we should expect that to normalize going forward now that you're in the Boston market and you've launched this new campaign.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're going to make decisions throughout the quarter as well. But as I said, this increase on a quarter-over-quarter basis would not be typical for us.
componenttext: Yes, we're going to make decisions throughout the quarter as well. But as I said, this increase on a quarter-over-quarter basis would not be typical for us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

componenttext: I have 2 follow-ups for you. The first relates to write-downs. What can you talk about in terms of the drivers of the tick-up in write-downs? How would you relate it to underwriting standards? You talked about seeing higher quality credit applications, et cetera. Just give us a sense, if you could, about how to think about those write-downs and how we might model them out from here?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015

componenttext: Are you talking about CAF losses?

componenttext: Correct.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Matt. I think when I mentioned about the close in the quarter it was a quarterly -- this quarter phenomenon. For the last several, several, several quarters, in fact most of them, we've seen growth in kind of all areas in the credit spectrum. T
componenttext: I'm sorry, Matt. I think when I mentioned about the close in the quarter it was a quarterly -- this quarter phenomenon. For the last several, several, several quarters, in fact most of them, we've seen growth in kind of all areas in the credit spectrum. This quarter, we saw a decline in application volume and lower FICO stuff and a continued growth in the higher-end stuff, the 650-plus. That's what I meant by the traffic. That's unrelated to what's going on with charge-offs. Charge-offs has to do with what's in the portfolio and what's been put in there over the last several years. And the way I characterize it is, we've had a long string of favorable experience and at some point, it was -- the tide was going to turn and things were probably going to normalize. I'd probably characterize it as giving back some of the favorable experience we've had over the last several quarters. It's too early to tell what that means from a go-forward perspective. But as I mentioned, the reserve balance today is at the same level as a percent of receivables as it was last year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And is there anything that you saw on recent delinquency data that would lead you to be incrementally concerned? Did you feel like the book is still in very good shape.
componenttext: And is there anything that you saw on recent delinquency data that would lead you to be incrementally concerned? Did you feel like the book is still in very good shape.

componenttext: Got it. And then my next question, just, you bought back an awful lot of stock during what was obviously a tough quarter. What would you need to see? What would it take in terms of the fundamentals of the business to lead you to slow that buyback down?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Dec 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Matt, as I said, I think we've kind of got into the lower end of the leverage range that we've been targeting. And on a go-forward, we'll continue to manage the capital structure going forward. I can't comment on what would compel us to do anything
componenttext: Well, Matt, as I said, I think we've kind of got into the lower end of the leverage range that we've been targeting. And on a go-forward, we'll continue to manage the capital structure going forward. I can't comment on what would compel us to do anything because market conditions could be -- in the future could be all over the board. I just think you should take away that we're going to continue using it. We're going to continue using a programmatic approach. You saw during the quarter that we stepped up volume based on what the stock price did. But on a go-forward basis, it's probably more of a managing the structure perspective rather than moving to a new capital structure.

componenttext: All right. There are no more calls. I want to thank everybody for your interest in CarMax. Thanks for joining us. Goodbye.
